I have been playing this game since 2019, yet the issues this game had back then are still present now.

Changes that shouldn't take more than one update end up taking years (if they even happen). The developers are still repeating the same mistakes they "learned" from years ago, there doesn't seem to be any quality control in terms of balance or gameplay.

The game doesn't appreciate the time you spend on it or the money you put into it, I just cannot recommend this buggy mess, the worst part is that it will most likely never change, there is no competetion to push the developers into the right direction and partly because of their awful legacy code still influencing their decisions to this day.

DBD is a really fun game with cool events for different seasons loads of challenges to keep you motivated and really nice graphics. The game does have some toxic players but most matches are fun. I tend to main killer but with the recent 2v8 matches I was able to get a better grasp of how to play survivor better which was something i struggled with a bit. the tutorial isn't great so i do recommend looking up vids for better ones. This game does offer custom matches so you can choose to play with friends as well which can be a great way to learn the game and each characters strengths and weaknesses. overall a fun game with lots of cool characters and pretty graphics. I truly  recommend this one if you are a horror movie fan.

This game perfectly balances panic, betrayal, and pure chaos!

As a survivor, you get to sprint in circles around a small wooden hut while being chased by a 7ft maniac with an eye watering weapon and bad personal hygiene. Your aim (alongside staying alive) is to fix generators that have a personal vendetta against you, causing tiny heart attacks with every skill check. And after all that; the majority of matches will end with you screaming into the void while decorating a hook as your so called teammates leg it out of the freshly opened door.

As a killer, it‚Äôs even better. You chase someone for what seems to be a lifetime as you swing your oversized murder stick like you're trying to shoo away a mosquito, and still somehow manage to feel like a God! You curse every blind and every single pallet stun becomes a personal insult. Every hook is a triumph, with every survivors scream an applause for your dedication to the cause.

In short: This game is a rage baiting masterclass in panic-induced cardio, emotional trauma, and chaotic fun with enough salt in the community to give you hypernatremia!

Would recommend!

I'm gonna be honest with you all. I really loved that game. I put over 1000 hours into it on PS4, but that was many years ago. Now the game is taking its last dying breaths. Why? Because it's not only toxic, it's just not fun anymore.

A few minutes ago, I played my first match as killer this year (I honestly never played killer much on Steam before), and with the SBMM (matchmaking system) they came up with, you'd expect a complete killer rookie to get matched with at least a couple of rookie survivors, right? Think again. Because what I got were four complete tryhard veteran survivors with flashbangs, flashlights, and all sorts of sweaty perks.

They played freaking well, so well that I found myself wondering mid-match why they even bother making a matchmaking system if it's going to be this random. I literally rage-quit after all gens were done in roughly four minutes, and I only got two downs. The good old days where you could play killer and just have fun are over. I won't play killer again in this game, and it totally makes sense why tunneling and camping became widespread strategies. And with the latest changes they have announced it will be even worse.

People may call you a Camper, Tunneler, Gen-rusher, or Toxic player but most of this comes from frustration. Here‚Äôs what‚Äôs really happening in these situations and how both Survivors and Killers can reduce that frustration.

SURVIVORS
We‚Äôve all said it: ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre camping,‚Äù ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre tunneling,‚Äù ‚ÄúOP perks,‚Äù ‚ÄúYou suck.‚Äù These come from feeling powerless or targeted. But instead of blaming, it‚Äôs worth understanding why these things happen and how to counter them.

CAMPING

A killer sitting on a hook for the full 2 minutes feels awful. But camping is actually a huge mistake for the killer.

‚Ä¢ A survivor takes 120 seconds to die on hook.
‚Ä¢ One survivor doing a gen takes ~80 seconds (~100 with Ruin).
‚Ä¢ So if the killer camps, do gens instead of going for risky saves.

If a killer fully camps a first hook, you can finish about 3 gens. If they camp again, that‚Äôs 2 more. A camping killer realistically caps out at about 2 kills max and earns very few points. When you punish camping with gen pressure instead of feeding more hooks, killers eventually learn it doesn‚Äôt work.

TUNNELING

Getting tunneled is miserable, but it's often set up by survivor mistakes that the killer simply capitalizes on.

Killers prioritize:

‚Ä¢ The closest targets
‚Ä¢ Injured survivors
‚Ä¢ Survivors who are already hooked (best value for slowdown and pressure)

If the killer is near the hook when the unhook happens, they will naturally return‚Äîthere are guaranteed survivors there, one of them injured.

To reduce tunneling:

‚Ä¢Don‚Äôt unhook in the killer‚Äôs terror radius unless it‚Äôs absolutely necessary.
‚Ä¢If the killer never leaves the hook, it's camping/proxy camping‚Äîso leave and do gens.
‚Ä¢Communicate with teammates: unsafe unhooks cause tunneling.
‚Ä¢Learn to punish killers through pressure, not insults.

Dead by Daylight continues to stand out as one of the most unique and thrilling multiplayer experiences available. Every match feels intense and unpredictable, thanks to the perfect blend of horror, strategy, and teamwork. The atmosphere is amazing, creepy sound design, detailed maps, and iconic killers that keep you on edge from start to finish.

The game has grown so much over the years, with new characters, balance improvements, and creative crossovers that show how dedicated the developers are to keeping the experience fresh and engaging. Whether playing as a survivor and working together to escape, or as a killer hunting down your prey, the adrenaline rush never gets old.

What truly brings the game to life is the community no two matches are ever the same because every player brings their own playstyle and strategy. Dead by Daylight is a game that keeps evolving, and it‚Äôs clear that a lot of passion goes into every update.

I see a lot of comments saying it isn't beginner friendly and as a new player, I'll be honest. It doesn't FEEL beginner friendly, but in the sense that match making seems a bit off balance. I feel like I'm constantly matched with insane killers who clearly have been playing this game for many years. But in all honesty that doesn't prevent the game from being fun. Sure, it sucks when a killer tunnel visions on you or just goes super hard for no reason, but that's also the nature of these games so I don't really hold that against the game itself. I think skill based match making could be better, but eh.

I will say I went into playing afraid it was going to be pretty toxic but I didn't realize that most people just don't talk? So if you've been afraid to play because you've been afraid to deal with being flamed/dealing with toxic people screaming at you, that's not the case. Just get in a public lobby and play, it's actually pretty chill and in the 10 hours I've played I've yet to really encounter any people raging over it. Most people have seemed either friendly, or chill.

I also went into the game thinking it would be super clunky but surprisingly moving around actually feels really smooth and easy. 

So yeah, while I agree it's not beginner friendly and maybe they could do more to make it more so, the game is fun and worth picking up.

Ten years in and Dead by Daylight is still the only game that can make me scream, laugh, flirt with death, and question my life choices all in the same five minutes. There is simply nothing else like it, and honestly, I don‚Äôt think the world could handle two of these anyway.

One thing I absolutely adore is how wildly inclusive this game is. DBD doesn‚Äôt just welcome every community, it throws the door open, hands you a flashlight, and says ‚Äúget in loser, we‚Äôre looping.‚Äù Horror lovers, queer icons, sweaty tryhards, cozy gamers, lore nerds, chaos gremlins, the eternally doomed, the perpetually carried, everyone fits here. Behaviour keeps adding characters, stories, and cosmetics that make the Fog feel like a place where every kind of player can exist loudly and beautifully.

And the gameplay? Lord help me. It‚Äôs messy, toxic, romantic, terrifying, sexy, hilarious, and deeply embarrassing at times. Every match feels like its own chaotic little relationship. One minute you‚Äôre confidently looping a killer like a goddess, the next you‚Äôre tripping over a rock and dying in the corner like it‚Äôs your first day on a controller. But that‚Äôs the charm. Every round is unpredictable, dramatic, and deliciously tense.

A decade later, this game is still my comfort, my chaos, my adrenaline rush, my therapy session, and my late night ‚Äújust one more match‚Äù addiction. If you want a game that‚Äôs inclusive, creative, constantly evolving, and absolutely unhinged in the best way, Dead by Daylight is the one.

Still here, still screaming, still stunning, still repairing gens like my life depends on it.

Dead by Daylight is an asymmetric 4v1 horror game where one killer hunts four survivors trying to escape. Released in 2016, the game has grown massively with new characters, maps, and collaborations.

Story
The narrative centers around ‚ÄúThe Entity,‚Äù a supernatural force that traps both killers and survivors in endless trials. Each character has a backstory, but the main plot is intentionally fragmented, giving the game a mysterious, haunting atmosphere.

Gameplay
Survivors must repair generators, avoid the killer, rescue teammates, and open exit gates. It‚Äôs all about stealth, teamwork, and decision-making. Killers, on the other hand, must track survivors, use unique powers, and sacrifice them to The Entity. Matches are tense, unpredictable, and often chaotic, which is part of the charm ‚Äî and frustration. The learning curve is steep on both sides, but rewarding once you understand perks, loops, and mindgames.

Graphics
The visuals have been significantly improved over the years. Maps are atmospheric, lighting is solid, and the killer designs are detailed and intimidating. Still, animations can feel stiff, and some textures look dated, especially compared to newer horror titles.

Music & Sound
The soundtrack fits the tone: eerie, minimalistic, and tension-driven. Chase music varies per killer and adds personality to each encounter. Audio cues are crucial ‚Äî footsteps, grunts, and terror radius all shape the gameplay experience.

Conclusion
Dead by Daylight isn‚Äôt perfect: it has balance issues, occasional bugs, and a sometimes harsh matchmaking system. But despite its flaws, it remains one of the most unique and replayable horror multiplayer games available. Its tension, variety, and unpredictability keep players coming back.

Score: 8/10

I received this game for free from a friend. We are no longer friends. Installing this game was the worst decision of my life, worse than when I withdrew my bitcoin stocks in favour of blockbuster stocks in the late 2000s. It is one of my biggest regrets in life. I think playing this game reduced my lifespan by a few decades. The people in this game make me lose braincells, and the stress that both the game and the players induce is sickening. This game should be considered a form of torture with the way it drains my will to live. I wouldn't wish this on my worst enemy.

nonetheless, i like the wide variety of playstyles and builds you can run, despite the fact that this game's mmr system is the equivalent to my second marriage, absolute dogshit.

i recommend this game if you need a new torture method to dissect information out of, similar to my fourth marriage.

I do not like being a negative person.

Vitriol and hatred have been things I feel less and less as of late, more often overtaken by dread, anxiety and depression. I go to therapy to sort these things out and honestly, after the amount of hours I clocked into this game, I figured that I think I need to go some more.

But this game... 

Despite being one of the most popular games in the modern era, a great look at how far horror has come in the nearly 9 or 10 years it's been since this game dropped and how you can see the progression of horror classics and new horror ideas, despite being a very good idea and being able to capitalize on it with great success, despite the hours and hours I've spent on it...

I can't bring myself to compare this game to anything more than a digitally packaged form of self-hatred, abuse, neglect, incompetency, greed and contempt.

This playable version of a Torment Nexus, placed onto unsuspecting players and people who just want to enjoy horror through the powers of incompetent, overpaid fools who would rather spend their time sniffing their own farts, punishing the people who want to play the killer role because of the unforgivable crime of just existing in the playspace, overworking the people who put actual effort into the game and forcing them to work in middling conditions so that they could "potentially" (read; eventually) be swapped out by "generative AI workers" internally, idiotic "directors" in the field of game balance and game design who couldn't comprehensively direct a friggin' blind person, let alone an entire team of people, a completely non-functional anti-cheat system that basically lives up to it's name (Easy Anti-Cheat? Yeah, you can Easily subvert this Anti-Cheat lmao) and just this disgusting air of contempt for the people who play their game. 

And yet, just like an uncomfortable amount of victims of abuse, these players keep coming back.

After being metaphorically beaten bloody, they keep begging the developers, "Ooh please feed me more slop, please listen to me, I'm gonna give you another chance" when they should have had the common sense to realize that the developers of this game will genuinely keep on hurting them, over and over and over, eventually having that same toxic BS pass on from the devs to the players, filling the survivor players with feelings of entitlement and contempt that are ever-justified with how simple yet powerful their perks are whilst pumping the ever-dwindling killer players dry of their faith and joy and replacing it with misery and depression while ALSO nerfing their perks, add-ons AND powers into the ground.

There's this joke in the community going around as of late, around a certain killer in-game known as The Unknown. This killer, due to the intense amount of precision needed, plus the constant "positive" changes that they receive, has gained the reputation of "The Harmless" due to the developers' insistence on making sure that you buckle down, stop playing these killers and start playing other ones.

For example; Blight. You will see this killer, whose power is a simple dash, more often than 90% of all of the killers COMBINED. His simple playstyle but insanely high skill ceiling makes him possibly THE strongest killer in the game as of this moment, especially when in combination with perks such as Lethal Pursuer and Pop Goes The Weasel. Nurse will be seen less than this orange sack of pustulating gross but believe me, she's mostly the same thing.

And yet, due to Behaviour's insistence on looking at ANY OTHER KILLER and gutting their abilities due to their insistence that the spreadsheets and the data never lie, these killers can have certain players go up to winstreaks that have gone as high as 1947 wins. I wish I was making that up. But no, the Skull Merchant apparently deserves to be rendered useless for up to two or three years. 

Laugh out loud, you miserable yucksters.

Another sidenote is the community of this game; one half is genuinely kind people who understand that the game that they're playing is screwed beyond belief because of the incapable developers. The other half is quite possibly one of THE most toxic game communities ever fostered, through bad game design decisions and an "us-versus them mentality", plus waves of entitlement, sociopathy, homophobia, racism, toxic behaviour in-game... 

Oh. Toxic Behaviour. Yeah, that makes sense. This game company really is toxic.

It's very late in the night and my contempt for this game, the company behind it and that one subsection of the community can keep me going for hours. But I'm going to try and cap this off with something positive, which isn't surprising because I can sense that there's actual, genuine love placed into this game from the departments that aren't run by dunderheads who don't understand the positions they're in, only the dollar-signs that come with it.

The music in the game, although sparse, is expertly made by one Michael F. April (who made the music for the Planes video game if you can believe it) and almost all of the original killer designs (special shoutouts to Artist, Dredge, Unknown, Deathslinger, Twins, Singularity, Knight, Trapper, Krasue), plus some of the original survivor designs (Jonah, Jeff, Gabriel, Elodie, Jake, Haddie, Renato, Taurie) are genuinely pretty damn good, alongside their alternate costumes being even better than the main designs in some cases.

Though you usually have to shell out 10$ or more for the licensed outfits or grind an ungodly amount of time in order to buy ONE piece of a costume if it's available through Iridescent Shards because BHVR hates you and wants to squeeze your wallet dry. Oh yeah, some costumes are unavailable to purchase with Iridescent Shards too for seemingly no reason.

Even the licensed survivors and killers also get some pretty fun and unique takes on them when Behaviour is given the ability to stretch and experiment with their designs. Chucky (the good guy) has some fun alternates, so does Dracula (the dark lord), Springtrap (the animatronic), The Xenomorph and Amanda (the pig) whilst on the survivor sides, you also get Nicolas Cage's ridiculous smorgasbord of stuff, same with Yoichi, Ash, Leon and Tapp's slightly less amount of outfits. 

There is good in this game. 
It's just a crying shame that it's clumped in with all of the genuine evil and incompetency. 

Dead By Daylight? Yeah.
Goodnight, Gotham.

---

There's nary a reason to come back to this game unless you want to feel like a piece of sh!t (Survivor) or if you want to feel like sh!t (Killer) and I've just about had enough of that."

Stockholm syndrome is a psychological response where a victim develops a bond with their captor or abuser, characterized by positive feelings toward them and sometimes negative feelings toward those trying to help. It is considered a coping mechanism for survival in abusive or threatening situations, such as hostage scenarios, domestic violence, or child abuse, and can result in the victim defending their abuser or refusing rescue. The term originated from a 1973 bank robbery in Stockholm, Sweden, where hostages bonded with the robbers.

This game is like an abusive relationship, its full of cheating, and isn't fun, but there are these moments which bring you back, and show you what could be, causing you to come back hoping that there will be change, but in the end it always goes back down to the same problems.

Most games play the same, survivors running the same builds made up of meta perks because the killer is probably doing the same, originally it would only be one or two, but now its done by almost everyone because its more likely the other side is doing the same. it stops being fun when everything just becomes repetitive, when you can practically tell what build someone is running purely based on what item they hold.

The game is horribly balanced at best, and a buggy mess at worse. You will be told to kill yourself at least once playing this game. It's not in a healthy state, behaviour act reactively, and half the time don't even understand their own game or the problems with it.

Looking at the concept of the game, it could be amazing, if only communication, respect and understanding would go both ways, like in a proper healthy relationship.
I am going to keep playing this game, I'm in it for the long haul at this point, but in this current state, I'm suggesting what they said in an interview. 

"Go play something else"

I've been playing this game for about 2 years on my ps5 and just now got it on my computer. If anyone is looking for a game that is competitive yet veryyy fun then I'd recommend this game. Almost everyone in this game is nice and it's easy to make friends. Some characters cost money, but majority of the characters are free or cost in-game shards you get from leveling up or using codes. This game is so awesome and it somehow keeps getting better and better. So yes, I recommend this game a lot.

You'll have fun if you're just playing casually, chill, or for fun. 

Otherwise you'll notice 100's of game breaking/ruining issues regarding bugs, players, cheaters, balance, devs, design, and the community (the last listed item being a bit of a 50/50). 

I also see more than enough evidence to suggest that the devs hardly/don't play their own game not seeing the issues with certain changes they propose (ex: recent tunnelling reduction changes), doubling down on bad balance changes (ex: nerfing/killing franklins demise), making changes that make 0 sense or do nothing (ex: insidious "buff" or the streetwise rework), not changing bigger things that should have been changed long ago (ex: nurse), or propose bad changes that we don't even understand how they make it into the PTB in the first place (ex: Xenomorph changes) (they have "player consultants" too by the way). 

Evidence also suggests that they themselves are clueless (ex: not knowing whether The Fallen Refuge is a map, map expansion, tile, a minecraft village, or what have you). They tend to lack new creative powers for new killers (ex: springtrap A.K.A. robohuntress). The game is also not even slightly beginner friendly (with a small exception of things such as using YouTube or having experienced friends lecture you but no big game should be that way). 

Another important item to be noted is that there are lots of important games changing perks for killers and survivors (ex: decisive strike, conviction, vigil, eruption, surge, etc...) that are locked behind a pay wall. The shrine is the suppossed "exception" but realistically with over 100 unique perks on both sides and this only changing weekly. The odds of getting a really good/important perk are extremely low.

If all of that is not enough for you, somehow in my opinion, cheaters are almost the least problematic thing about this game (and mind you they are most certainly a problem that has not been handled very well at all). 

Overall this game has tons of potential given that they have the world in their hands regarding collaborations and licenses, no competition whatsoever, and plenty of talented artistic designers. That said they greatly lack in almost all other departments. For now I recommend you keep the money in you wallet and buy something nicer for yourself. Regarding personal experience with this game: I have total of 6k-7k hours (most from console) on this game.

AND STILL.. a positive experience overall after all these years, this DOES NOT APPLY if you are an advanced player with thousands of hours. But for most people this game maintains its essence (with a little too many micro-transactions and paid only content for my taste) while delivering fresh content every now and then. If you never played this game it's going to be difficult to start because there are a lot more characters and things to learn now so the learning curve is worse in my opinion. But if you've played, you know how to play a killer or you have your survivor build from 2019 then it's still alright, it's not always good, but it's a cozy 2h on a sunday afternoon if thats what you're after. Solo queue is a little inconsistent, the skill difference is a little off quite often. 

Overall It's not a negative review but it's not the same game it used to be so I would give it something like a 6.5/10.

Dead by Daylight is one of those games that makes you constantly ask yourself, ‚ÄúWhy am I still here?‚Äù but somehow you always come crawling back like nothing happened. It‚Äôs not just a horror game. It‚Äôs a full-blown toxic relationship in digital form one that drains your soul, heats your blood, stresses your brain, and then gives you five seconds of dopamine that convinces you to stay. You know it‚Äôs bad for you, but you keep hitting ‚ÄúReady‚Äù anyway. And honestly? That‚Äôs kind of the charm.
Every match feels like stepping into another episode of your own chaotic reality TV show. You enter the fog with hope you didn‚Äôt learn from last night because last night you got left to die on a hook like abandoned furniture. Yet somehow today you think things will be different. Spoiler: they‚Äôre usually not, but that tiny chance is what keeps dragging you back into this mess.
Playing survivor isn‚Äôt just running and fixing generators. It turns you into some combination of a mechanic, track runner, therapist, firefighter, and clown all at the same time. You‚Äôll be a hero in one match and a complete embarrassment in the next. One moment you save your whole team like a legend, and the next you‚Äôre crouching behind a bush hoping the killer doesn‚Äôt notice your giant head sticking out. Dead by Daylight has this unique talent for turning you into both the protagonist and the walking disaster of the story simultaneously.
The teammates you meet‚Ä¶ man. Sometimes you get absolute angels team players who stick with you, rescue you, and heal you in complete silence like some unspoken brotherhood. And other times you get the kind of teammates who watch you get downed and just walk away like they‚Äôre sightseeing. Or the ones who think they‚Äôre superheroes and waste the whole match trying to loop the killer but end up dying every 10 seconds. DBD matchmaking is basically rolling a dice and praying the Entity blesses you instead of laughing at you.
And killers? They‚Äôre a special breed too. Some of them are terrifyingly good relentless, quiet, calculating, the kind that makes you reconsider your life choices. Others are chaotic gremlins who suddenly stop chasing you just to crouch, dance, or try to befriend you in the weirdest ways possible. Playing killer yourself is a whole mental journey. You‚Äôre alone, under pressure, trying to track down four noisy humans who scatter like cockroaches the moment you get close. Sometimes you feel like a powerful hunter, and other times you feel like you‚Äôre just walking around the map while four people bully you. DBD really keeps your ego flexible.
Then there are the perks those little lies we tell ourselves before every match. We set them up like we‚Äôre preparing some magical ritual. Sometimes they clutch and save your life. Sometimes they might as well not exist. And when the enemy‚Äôs perk screws you over at the last second? That‚Äôs when you realize why people say this game tests your emotional stability more than your skill.
The atmosphere is something else too. Every map is dark, dirty, eerie, and way too detailed in all the wrong ways. The sound design alone can give you a heart attack. You can play for hundreds of hours and still jump when a skill check pops unexpectedly. There‚Äôs nothing more horrifying than that ‚Äúping!‚Äù sound betraying your location to the killer because your fingers decided to have stage fright.
And then there‚Äôs the community. The funniest part is how everyone complains about the game, threatens to uninstall, swears they‚Äôre done forever and then shows up the next day playing it again like nothing happened. Nobody leaves this game. Everyone is stuck in the same cycle of suffering and joy. It‚Äôs honestly kind of beautiful in a messed-up way. Dead by Daylight isn‚Äôt perfect. It‚Äôs flawed, it‚Äôs stressful, it‚Äôs buggy, it‚Äôs unfair, it‚Äôs rage-inducing. Some matches make you want to throw your mouse across the room. But then you get one good match just one and suddenly everything feels worth it again. That‚Äôs how this game traps you. And honestly? At this point most of us in the community have accepted it. As a lot of DBD players like to say This game is like a terrible ex you should‚Äôve blocked years ago‚Ä¶but for some reason, you still keep coming back And yeah....it's painfully true.

The Matchmaking Ban for disconnecting from games is ridiculous, the game can literally decide to boot you from a match and then penalize YOU for kicking you from the game due to the "dedicated server not responding"--and if that isn't bad enough, you can now get the penalty for dying, yes you heard me, dying--in the game where you are MEANT TO DIE. If your character ends up tunneled you will get flagged for "suspicious activity". I've spent a lot of money on this game and so have many other dedicated players, and the way the game repays us for their own server issues is to lock us out of playing the game we paid for. It's frankly insulting and unethical for BHVR to continue with this practice, you can't have bad servers that disconnect players and then punish them because you can't keep your game running properly. I don't recommend anyone buy or spend money on this game until they fix this issue.

Here's something for y'all to imagine, Imagine you're playing killer and you're about to get your first hook after a 2 gen chase only for the survivors friends to come save them with Flashlights, flashbangs, sabotage toolboxes, pallet saving, Head On from a locker, body blocking, or things like boil over, flip-flop where it's impossible to hook the guy cause you can't see the closest hook (if it wasn't already sabo'd) or they just get off you instantly which is why killers tunnel, slug, camp, etc. But another reason why we tunnel, slug and camp is because we get t-bagged, insta-blinded (for those who didn't bring Lightborn cause you're better than that), get looped for long periods of time. 
Us killers? Dead by Daylight is the grandfather of the asymmetrical horror X survivors vs X killer game genre. It is unfortunately uncontested as with many other 'DBD killers' like Texas Chainsaw Massacre, Friday the 13th the game, etc shutting down, DBD remains a mainstay for those who enjoy that type of game. There is a reason I said unfortunately.

Dead by Daylight is a horribly balanced game on both ends, with numerous periods of time where the game has been unplayable for either killer or survivor due to Overpowered perks, items, add-ons, etc. The playerbase is extremely polarized with Killer mains and Survivor mains at each others throat, with an 'us vs them' mentality being extremely prevalent in nearly every space you go in the community as the toxic members of each side only ruin the reputation of their own side.

This isn't helped by the fact that the developers seem to be extremely out of touch with their own game, with broken killers like Blight and ESPECIALLY Nurse remaining unchanged, and needing to have OTHER killers perks balanced around them [i] (Nurse has been unchanged despite being the best killer for [b] 8 YEARS [/b] btw) [/i]. And for the survivor side, there were insta blind flashlights that were BEGGED to be removed for years, they were only removed [b] AFTER THE GAME DIRECTOR PLAYED KILLER AGAINST A TEAM WITH 4 INSTA BLIND FLASHLIGHTS AND GOT BULLIED RELENTLESSLY [/b] with the removal coming a month after that match. Needless to say again, but there is a very good reason why the community jokes that the Devs don't even play their own game.

The only people who hate playing Dead by Daylight more than Dead by Daylight fans are the Dead by Daylight Developers. I only find fun when I'm playing with friends and not taking things seriously, because the moment you do, you realize you could be playing literally anything else and be having more fun.

The worst part is that I don't want this game to die, I would love to see the day that the game is well balanced for both sides and the community stops trying to rip each other apart. But the only way I see that happening is if a 'DBD Killer' actually goes on the market, retains its players, and doesn't shut down within 2 years so Dead by Daylight actually has to try.

Dead by Daylight can be a very mixed bag if you come from other competitive multiplayer games. On one hand, the gameplay loop is very easy to understand and the Perks system allows for a lot of self expression. On the other hand, the complexity of the Perks system means that the real difficulty curve is memorizing the hundreds of Perks and how they interact. And with 300 Perks so far, as well as each Killer having their own unique bag of tricks separate from Perks, the bar continues to up for what you are expected to know to succeed in the long term.

The community around DbD has always been very intense. When I first began playing in 2020, my more experienced friends told stories about old tricks and exploits, the famous players and the infamous, their hates and their loves. People care very much about this game, and I find it comforting to know that the developers have taken the very intense criticisms they've received over the years with grace.

DbD content creators have done a fantastic job showcasing the entire spectrum of play, from goofy one-trick builds to super serious shutout builds. Dead by Daylight is also very stream-friendly, and I regularly run into players streaming live during my games. I find DbD to be the most fun with friends, and running into friendly players and having a good laugh is often the highlight of my play sessions.

Dead by Daylight could have crashed and burned years ago if the DbD community and the developers stayed on different pages, but in recent months I've begun to feel that the devs and community are more in sync than ever before. And I very much hope to see Dead by Daylight continue to flourish.

The complete and utter lack of competency by Behaviour is frankly ridiculous, and should be enough to disincentivize anyone from purchasing a game from them. Their inability to make balance changes that makes anyone happy is disgusting, and their refusal to make changes based on anything other than kill rates has made the game not only unenjoyable, but unplayable at times. Not only do they make half-baked efforts to "fix the game's issues", they roll them back like cowards before it even goes live. Their inability to stifle tunneling and slugging is pathetic and shows that they do not have a single solution or vision on how to make the game fair. Not only are their failing to balance the game, they are becoming more and more greedy with their monetization practices. The current rift or "battle pass" is half baked, where most of the cosmetics are recolored versions of already existing skins, and the other ones have you pay for a head that is not only one that's already in the game, but the DEFAULT skin! Moving on to their utter mismanagement of the shop, they forgot to remove a sale of a franchise that was likely going to get a new chapter before they had to delay it, likely scraping the idea entirely. Survivor player numbers are dropping at an alarming rate, and have increased queue times for killer players, who are ignorant to the reason queue times have increased in the first place. Year after year of Behaviour's refusal to look at the state of the game as a survivor has resulted in this mass exodus of that side, and they're not able to do anything about it, either because they get cold feet, or they flat out have no clue how to fix it. Don't buy this game and do not support this developer team. They do not deserve it and you deserve to save your money.

I do love this game a lot. For being one of the few asymmetrical games out there, it does hold its ground.

It's got fun hunt or be hunted chases, lots of perks and customization for both Survivor and Killer, though prices can be expensive by $10 to $15 for the purchasable skins.

You really can't run out of things to do in the game. They have The Tome, which is a web of challenges to give incentive to try new play-styles and builds, there are the new quests that you can track to receive various rewards, and lots of characters to level-up through the blood-web to unlock more perks and customization.

I do have a couple of cons to point out. For one, you will come across quite some rude people when playing, especially when playing Killer. Not the worst thing, but can bump the enjoyment a little bit.
For two, new content at the moment is slow. This year for BHVR's QoL changes has been on and off. The team tends to spend resources on things that get reverted, 

Overall, pretty great game. Highly recommend playing with friends!

[h1] Dead by Daylight is an inconsistent, overpriced mess. [/h1]

For the record, my total playtime across multiple platforms should be around 2000, not the 300 that my profile shows. I played actively from late 2019 to about 2022 or 2023, but have known the game since at least 2017 or 2018. I was a HUGE fan with a lot of passion, but nowadays the game doesn't capture the same magic that it used to. Not saying that dbd was necessarily better back then, of course not! It was a buggy, poorly balanced mess and guess what, it still is today, just less extreme.

To get the elephant in the room out of the way, this game costs you around 20‚Ç¨ upfront, but then has the audacity to charge you up to over 300‚Ç¨ for DLC content. Yes, about half of these can be unlocked in-game, but grinding iridescent shards is tedious. Not as much as it used to be, but it still is. Even then, about half the content is licensed so you'd need to pay around 150‚Ç¨ anyway to get that. On top of that, the game has a battlepass and an in-game store with overpriced cosmetics. This alone is reason enough to stay away from this game honestly.

Now for the actual gameplay though... it's weird.

DbD can surely be fun, but a lot of matches will have you mad at something. This game really knows how to push your buttons. While I am a lot more chill with this game these days, I get why a lot of people get mad at it. Many matches end up extremely one sided, which can be pretty boring and frusttrating. The most lame playstyles are often times the most efficient. So so sooo many perks are also completely useless and not worth running or have a better alternative somewhere else, so you often times see the same loadouts. It used to be much worse, but last time I checked, there's still a lot of stuff that no one really likes to use. Who the hell runs visionary for example???

The Killer roster has also seen better days. Most of the new characters really fail to grab me. Their playstyles are just mixes of multiple abilities that have been executed much better in the past. It's not all that exciting having the 500th character that has a straight forward, mid range, attack. Or having the 500th character that has objects on the map that they can teleport to. It's all been done so many times now that I have little reason to actually play a lot of those Killers, when a more refined and established variant of that character already exists.

Not to mention that half the Killer roster is also not that fun to go against most of the time.

Playing Survivor is most fun with friends usually. But even then, miscommunication can be pretty frustrating, at least it was for me, and unless you play custom games or don't care about what is happening at all, I wouldn't call the game fun even with buddies. Lots of matches just left me with a bad taste in my mouth, be it for boring playstyles or characters, bugs, annoying mechanics or just simply overpowered loadouts on either side.

The FNaF collab, which is probably their biggest release to date also left nothing but apathy within me. They didn't adapt the original games' style or themes properly. They just took FNaF seriously once it got a movie tbh. The modern games are ass, but they could've at least adapted the originals properly. Springtrap is just a lame cartoony villain with the most generic voice lines you've ever heard and the music doesn't sound like it came from the games either. The map is just a withered isle variant with FNaF themed building... lazy. The reason why I mention this is because a big draw of this game for a lot of people are the crossovers. I can assure you that about 50% of them are half-assed and not worth buying.

The tutorial for this game is really bad and barely teaches you anything. If you don't like DbD at the start, you won't like it later and if you love it at first... that will fade. Many players have a sort of love-hate relationship with this game for a reason. Many just continue because they've spent a lot of time and money on this game.

I know I could've explained things better, but I just wanted to write something up to warn newcommers. Don't buy, not worth it. If you do buy it, stay away from the community at all costs. Thanks to Otzdarva for being one of the few folks here that are worth looking up to.

I have played this on and off since 2017 ish and have a love/hate relationship with it. It can be very fun and the premise is cool. But the game isn't thought through very well. I mean the game has been under constant development and constant updates trying to balance the game, but it is still unbalanced. Whether you main killer or survivior, you can have several games in a row where you don't get to do anything. You just waste your time giving points to the opponent(s). And if you don't want to waste more time and leave the match, not only does the opponent get more points, you get a penalty. How about making the game fun so people don't want to leave, huh? Im okay with losing every now and then, but when i don't get to do anything before the match is over, that is a game issue, not a skill issue. Despite having some love for this game, i ultimately can't say i recommend getting into it. It is extremely frustrating and a time waster. They should make an official sequel that is more balanced.

This game has made me so upset a majority of the time, ESPECIALLY lately. It genuinely is not fun AT ALL anymore. I generally take breaks from playing it because it makes me so livid. Then, some time passes and I come back to be tunneled, or sandbagged, or camped on hook. It's so unfortunate that this is the state of this game. You literally can never have a consistently fun time playing it. You get penalized for leaving matches when they are absolutely toxic. I don't want to watch myself slugged or camped on hook and be penalized for disconnecting. I don't want to be forced to watch the mori animation.

People are desperate to win on both sides and end up making the game so unenjoyable. Some friends and I were just talking about how this game has gone down the drain. Does anyone at Behavior even play this game to know that it's miserable??? The sad part is I have purchased so many skins and now I genuinely sickened by the thought of playing DBD. This game needs a revamp. Toxic killers should be punished for tunneling and camping hook. Survivors should not be able to sabotage their own team. None of the measures in the game work to ease any of that. It shouldn't take years for you to implement something. There are so many killers that have been unbalanced for ages. The ghoul?? NO ONE LIKES TO PLAY AGAINST HIM. He gets a free hit and practically eliminates lasting chases from the game. How great is that?

Anyways, all I'm saying is, the state of this game is trash. It's genuinely not worth your time being angry while trying to enjoy a game.  It's not worth the money. The community is generally toxic. The developers do not listen. The killer mains complain about stuff that doesn't get fixed. The survivors complain about stuff that never gets fixed. It's a back and forth that have been going on for years. I have hit my limit waiting for changes to happen and I'm moving on to different games with developers that care and can address things in a more timely manner.

This game has been enjoyable to me for quite awhile now, as you can probably guess by my playtime.
Though it has some glaring issues that need to be address for years now.
What do I mean? The Game has been a buggy mess for years and every single update the devs put out only increases the amount. They can not fix it and probably never will.

What else? Well, they have a thing called "PTB" it stands for "Public Test Build". These are Updates that are made available ahead of time, so players can review the changes. Most of the times it leads to Players discovering multiple bugs and changes to certain game mechanics that most likely won't get changed, at least not before the update comes out for all.

Lastly I want to talk about the game's monetization, I'm sure a lot of you have rolled their eyes now because this has been the topic again and again. Perks or certain content of the game (Killer or new Survivor) have been locked behind DLC, makes sense right? Some or as of today most cost real money for licensing. The bigger issue is the advantage some may get when buying said DLC, because the devs can't and never will properly balance their game.

This isn't a new issue as are all the things I mentioned above. Even in 5 years the game will still be unbalanced, buggy and have a monetization of a Free to Play game. There is no reason to buy this game or spent any amount of money on it. Frankly the people that run DBD don't deserve the Support. Buy something else or support some Indie Dev on his passion project.

This game has more bugs than features, and I mean game-breaking bugs. Examples:

- 1 Generators sometimes count as 2.

- Half the killers are bugged or don‚Äôt work correctly. For example, Vecna doesn‚Äôt show survivors struggling when you carry them, Ghost Face makes random sounds as if you‚Äôre watching him when he‚Äôs nowhere near you, Wraith sometimes crashes your game or the other player‚Äôs game when breaking a pallet, and many other killers are broken too.

- Hitboxes are atrocious in this game be ready for Bluetooth hits.

- Because the developers don‚Äôt know how to program or what server authority is, cheaters run rampant. Be ready to find them 1 out of every 4 matches. And I‚Äôm talking about finishing gens in seconds, getting you stuck in animations, going under the map, rezzing and unhooking people......‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs a shit show.

- The balance team doesn‚Äôt even play the game. If they did, they wouldn‚Äôt make half the changes they do, where they fuck the game and then have to roll it back. "Data-driven changes" my ass.

- Did I talk about the bugs? Because god dammit, there are so many. My favorite was when you could get infinite item charges and the devs said that‚Äôs not game breaking.................‚Ä¶ having an infinite item is not game breaking?........ Fuck off.

- Some killers are so OP it‚Äôs pointless to play anything else. The only counterplay is hoping the player sucks or misplays, because otherwise you‚Äôre dead. So what did the devs do to address this? They nerfed bottom tier killers and left the S-tiers alone. Makes sense, right?

While the concept is fun and has great potential, it‚Äôs completely mismanaged by the devs.

I‚Äôve spent some time with this game and honestly, it surprised me in a way I didn‚Äôt fully expect. I don‚Äôt want to sound dramatic, but there‚Äôs something oddly satisfying about how everything fits together ‚Äî not in some perfect, polished ‚Äúadvertisement‚Äù way, but more like a game that knows exactly what it wants to be and just‚Ä¶ goes for it.

The first thing I noticed is the atmosphere. Every part of the game ‚Äî the visuals, the sound, the pacing ‚Äî kind of blends into this feeling that you‚Äôre actually inside its world, even if you‚Äôre just casually playing. I know that sounds a bit clich√©, but it‚Äôs true. Sometimes it‚Äôs chaotic, sometimes slow, sometimes you‚Äôre just wandering around thinking ‚Äúok, what now?‚Äù but that‚Äôs honestly part of the charm. The game doesn‚Äôt try to rush you unless it actually needs to.

Gameplay-wise, it has this mix of familiar elements and small twists that keep things from feeling stale. Nothing groundbreaking, maybe, but it all works together in a way that feels natural. There were moments when I thought ‚Äúyeah, I‚Äôve seen this in other games,‚Äù but then the game throws in tiny details or unexpected interactions that make it stand out just enough. It‚Äôs the kind of thing you only notice after a few hours, when you start connecting the dots.

Performance has been mostly fine. A little rough spot here and there, but honestly, show me a game these days that doesn‚Äôt have something weird happening once in a while. Nothing game-breaking on my end, at least. You can clearly tell the developers put effort into this, even if a few edges are still a bit sharp. Again ‚Äî part of the charm.

What I really appreciate is that the game gives you space to play the way you want. Some people will rush through every objective, others will take their time exploring or messing around, and both approaches actually feel valid. I like games that don‚Äôt punish you for not following some ‚Äúcorrect‚Äù path.

Overall, I‚Äôd say this is one of those titles that grows on you the longer you play. It doesn‚Äôt try too hard to impress in the first five minutes ‚Äî instead it slowly builds its identity, layer by layer, until you suddenly realize you‚Äôve been playing way longer than you planned. If you‚Äôre looking for something that balances comfort with challenge, familiar mechanics with fresh touches, and a world that‚Äôs just fun to be in, then I genuinely think this one is worth giving a shot.

Would I recommend it?
Yeah, I would ‚Äî maybe not to everyone, because no game is for everyone, but definitely to anyone who likes getting lost in a game for a bit and discovering things at their own pace.

This is a good casual Asymm.  As survivor you'll constantly be fighting to keep your allies alive as they (or you) make dumb choices and misplay as you sneak around trying to power all the gens before the killer murders you all.  As the killer you just go out and kill.

Survivor is much more complicated as it requires you to know and keep track of alot more things, making newbie survivor far less forgiving whereas newbie killer is mostly about getting information perks and then just learning when to swing and to cut people off and how people loop. (survivor needs to learn all that and so much more including 20+ killers).

The overall balance feels slightly killer sided atm.  There are multiple killers that feel pretty unfair or have little counterplay if they play correctly, and iridescent addons (basically consumable perks of massive power you get from beating matches) can make even mediocre killers just not even worth facing.  Slugging and tunneling are also major balance issues that circumvent core game loops or just plain make your life miserable as a survivor even if you could argue is "balanced".

I would NEVER EVER play this seriously.  Between the iri addons, some of the OP killers, and some other killers with an extreme lack of counterplay (like the knight) who you just have to hope are played by someone bad (a good nurse will kill everyone easy, a bad nurse is useless lol) prevent this from ever being something you'd look at competitively.  And slugging/tunneling adds onto that.  Most good killers will actively not tunnel because they dont need to and because it makes survivors have a terrible time.

That being said, if you had 4 survivors who all knew exactly what to do and built complimentary perks they prolly have the advantage vs almost all killers.  It's just never ever going to happen unless you have 3 other friends who are good and you're also good, and all of you have at least 50+ hours in the game MINMUM each to know all the maps and killers and perks and etc.  IE....never gonna happen really.

Dead by Daylight is an exciting and intense multiplayer horror game that delivers a unique experience every match. Playing as either a Survivor or a Killer feels thrilling, and the different characters, perks, and maps keep the game fresh and fun. The atmosphere is always engaging, and escaping the Killer or catching Survivors can be incredibly satisfying. The only major downside is the horrendous queue time, which can make getting into a match frustrating at times. Even with that issue, the gameplay itself is strong enough that it still feels worth playing. When you finally get into a match, the experience easily makes up for the wait.

After probably too many hours more than I would have liked, I have finally broken down and decided to write a review.

First and foremost, I absolutely would never recommend this to anyone to play normal matched of dbd in its current state, the most fun you will ever have in this game is custom matches with friends where nobody is really taking it that seriously or forming certain rivalries between friends, but at the end of it all, you're all friends just having a good time.

There are two things I want to specifically talk about that is the biggest problem for me with dbd in its current state.
The first being the horrendous matchmaking system. Ever since I had a good string of games as killer, every game since then I have went up against multiple thousand hour players and too many p100 players who are way above my skill range. Compared to them, I am pretty much nothing. I don't know even 10% of the game compared to them and every single "good" play I think I have, there will always be one sweaty player making sure that play will go south almost immediately.
Every time I load into a game nowadays I am always met with the sweatiest players that completely ruin the killer experience, and it is extremely demotivating to continue playing killer with several different ways to give a middle finger to killer players.
The overabundance of really strong perks, such as Sprint Burst, Lithe, Vigil, Decisive Strike, Finesse, Deliverance, Unbreakable, Dead Hard, even Saboteur and Background Player can be so infuriating to go against every. single. match.
These perks would be fine if only a certain handful of people were using them, but no you see pretty much the same builds or a certain few perks everywhere and it leads to the same exact matches every single time.
And yes I understand that survivor players want to use the best perks, who wouldn't in any other game, but it compounds with the general gameplay changes as well that just make playing killer near impossible unless you have 1k+ hours.

The second point is just how much leeway the survivor side as a whole has been given in the past few updates, specifically the Pallet Density update.
The point of pallets and dead zones was knowing how many resources you had and how to best use them for you and your team, now with there being 3x as many pallets you really don't need to care about which ones you throw since you can walk 5 feet and see another pallet and loop to fully utilize, killing even more time for the killer that can only really be ignored by the highest tiered killers.

Take, for example, the suggested slugging changes, if the survivors were never letting you hook you would think the best course of action would be to just slug them all and then start hooking, but with this change that wouldn't even work since once you tried that everyone would be able to pick themselves back up and every single play that you try to make that you think can give yourself the upper hand just doesn't work, putting you into a situation where every play you do is a losing situation.

Killers always seem to get the short end of the stick since survivors are able to make mistake after mistake and still be completely fine from their perks and pallets, whereas killers can make one early mistake and the entire game is doomed to fail. This doesn't sit right with me.

For me, 2v8 and Custom games are perfectly fine.
But why exactly.

2v8 is so much more relaxed on both sides, since there are no individual perks for the survivors, only perk sets, and the stress of being the only one making mistakes is alleviated since you have a SECOND killer to help.
With there being no overly powerful perk sets for the survivors, it is much more manageable to deal with as a killer, and with the sheer number of survivors it is also easy enough to do your objectives since you have about 2 people being chased at any given time and about 4-6 people working on generators. This in itself is perfectly fine, and I love playing 2v8 on both sides, if I play killer, I play with a friend and have fun, and when I play survivor, I either play solo or with the same friend since we are playing survivor while we wait for the killer queue, and both are extremely fun no matter if I die or escape.

And custom games, as I said before, are very relaxed where nobody is taking the game all too seriously. Having dbd be a party game is great, a really good way to spend your night with a few friends and just see how it goes.
You can have the new guys, the experiences guys, or anybody in-between still have fun in customs since you are all there wanting to have fun rather than win.

So with all of this said, I am putting the game down and refusing to play the game normally, I will only ever touch the game if 2v8 is back, or my friends decide to play, which really sucks since I really do enjoy the game, but as it stands right now, I just can't enjoy it, I physically cannot enjoy the game in its current state.
If you're playing survivor, get used to dying. If you're playing killer, get used to waiting in the queue

There is a lot that can be said about this game, both negative and positive. Firstly, I do enjoy it very much. As a huge horror fan, this game and all it's collabs is something we might have dreamed about as kids but would have never thought it could be reality. There is no other game where you can play as Freddy Krueger and hunt Resident Evil's Leon Kennedy who is working together with Stranger Thing's Steve Harrington. There is no other game where you can play as Rick Grimes and attempt to escape from the Xenomorph or any other wild mix up you can think of. For that I must commend the developers not only for really making this happen but also for making it a generally pretty fun game and continuing to support and add content to it. 

The gameplay is very easy to learn but hard to master as all games should be. Personally I think playing as the killer role is significantly more difficult and frustrating than the survivor role as most of the game's mechanics seem to be centered around giving the survivors the best chances of escape possible but that is a topic of ongoing debate and contention with the community and I don't really want to dive into it here.

Speaking of the community, I've been playing online competitive games since I was old enough to hold a controller and I have to say, Dead By Daylight might hold the record for having one of the most toxic player bases I've ever come across. And this is coming from someone who has played CoD for most of my life. There is a lot of tea bagging, taunting and just overall BM in both the game itself and in the post game chat. Not a lot of good sportsmanship happening here. Sore losers and sore winners. 

All that being said, if you can ignore the occasional toxicity and not get too hung up on your loses as you learn to improve and adapt to whatever balancing issues there may be on either side, this game can be really fun. It has a large variety of maps, survivors, killers with unique abilities, perks, tools and addons to customize your loadout that make each match unique and keep the game feeling fresh for a long time. It's easy to see why Dead By Daylight has lasted so long in a genre where all of it's competitors usually die off within a couple years. 

Despite it's flaws Dead By Daylight has quickly become my favourite online, competitive title. I mean, a game where you can pick your favorite horror character and try to survive or kill the survivors? How could any horror fan pass that up? It's way too cool of a concept.

üíÄDead by Daylight is a game that I start playing for ‚Äújust a couple of rounds‚Äù and end up leaving three hours later with trembling hands and questions for the developers and life itself. The unique asymmetrical ‚Äú1 vs. 4‚Äù formula remains one of the most tense and unpredictable to this day. Each round is a little story: you're either the hero or a decorative hook.

Pros:

A huge number of killers and survivors, each with their own play style.

Constant updates, events, and new chapters.

Matches are often truly atmospheric and adrenaline-fueled.

High replayability: no two games are the same.

Cons:
‚Äì Balance sometimes goes on vacation.
‚Äì Matchmaking is sometimes strange, especially in solo.
‚Äì Optimization and bugs still happen.
‚Äì Toxicity in the lobby is part of the gameplay.

Bottom line: despite all its rough edges, Dead by Daylight is a game you'll come back to again and again. If you like tense matches, sudden twists, and the opportunity to be either the hunter or the prey, go for it.

Rating: 8/10

2025 has possibly been one of the the worst years I've experienced when it comes to this game. There is so much pathetic garbage that has been prevalent throughout the year. From the disastrous Walking Dead chapter to the "Health" chapter so bad it required a second attempt, this has been the worst excuse I've seen to keep playing this game. 

The game is plainly not fun. I have played it ever since Nemesis was released, initially with my friends. I am the only one that has continued to try and enjoy the game, and while I have my moments with it, it eventually all falls apart thanks to one random patch.

The matchmaking is scarier than anything the game tries to advertise itself as. I have over 1000 hours and have seen survivors with less than 50. While initially it might sound like I am awful at the game, the issue is the way the matchmaking actually takes survivors "skill" into account. The game, as of now, seems to only count escapes as whether or not you are performing well as a survivor. You could legitimately do half a generator and hide the entire game, but if you escape, you performed better than your teammate that distracted the killer for 5 minutes and ended up dying.

Both sides are suffering, but the community is so horrible that the mentality of "us versus them" has completely taken over, leading to people being despicably hateful towards the other side, or even their own teammates. The development team is so tone deaf that they can't understand either side, from issues with tunneling, to issues with the extreme pallet density, it's just something new every month. There are so, so many killers that have had a horrendous amount of game breaking bugs this year that take literal months to get patched out. Deathslinger had, and possibly still has, a bug where you can't even see him aiming to use his power, and it was in the game for a minimum of 8 months. The way they invited THE Chandler Riggs to a livestream with top creators, just to embarrass themselves even more than they already had with the Walking Dead chapter was simply put, depressing.

Despite the team landing the massive license of FNAF and even adapting it very well, this year overall has been too dogshit to excuse.

For the last rant, the game isn't beginner friendly in the slightest. MintSkull made a very in depth video on the topic of "pay to win" and FOMO, and how a very real case could be made for both those things being prevalent in this game. I have had friends try to figure out how to play the game only to get confused because of the sheer number of perks and systems in place that constantly change.

If you are wondering if you should play this game, don't. Do not waste your time, money, or soul in this spaghetti code, pile of rotten shit.

Look.. I love this game, I really do, but when it gets to a point where there's only one way to play to have fun (and most of the time it's really easy and boring anyway) I can't recommend this game to anyone. Seriously, if you think it's a good game please reconsider. I was a survivor main when I started but once I got around 300 hours on the game I began to play 50/50 and have been ever since. (To note; I have 500 hours on epic games + the hours I have on here so take that into consideration as well). 
To put it simply, this game is not fun for 70% of the time you play it, and when it is fun it's only when you're a survivor bullying the killer. Playing survivor most of the time is holding w and running around an obstacle 17 times until you get hit - then repeat the process until you die or you escape. Playing killer actually feels like a social experiment to test how stressed a human being can get before throwing a chair at their window. 
Survivors get handheld because the devs want the game to be "beginner friendly" which is a bunch of bs since it means they just buff and buff and buff survivor until it's literally impossible to play against them. They've far since left killers in the dirt to just fester in the sorry state that they're in, and I don't see any kind of improvement to the current state of the game anytime soon. 
The devs also just don't give a toss about the community or quality of life for their players. They just push to release popular licences as a buggy mess of an update to bring in more players, and they make "balance changes" always in favour of survivor to "help" those new players settle into the game. The tutorial is years old at this point and teaches the player to do gens, pallet save, and leave. There's nothing about perks or other niche mechanics in the game that are useful for beginners to know, and it essentially teaches the players to bot gens and leave. 
Anyone reading this MUST know about "survivor entitlement" and honestly it's bad. It's so bad actually that you'll have survivors threaten you personally just because the game didn't go their way. The wider community for the most part is fine but in-game it's atrocious. 

To TLDR this review; Survivor is easy and boring, Killer is rage inducing and absolutely not worth your time if you haven't spent money on the game, The devs don't care about anything the community says to help make improvements and instead they push buffing survivor, The community in-game is ass.
Oh yeah and one more thing... THE BUGS. This game doesn't go a single update without some colossal game breaking bug. 

DO NOT BUY THIS GAME. It's a WASTE of your TIME and MONEY. Please!

This is a love letter to the DEVS over at BHVR.
I first played DBD about a year after launch, I loved playing both sides, nothing felt unfun aside from the connection issues at times. I've played since then on and off, as a casual person that had school and then a job. I loved the feel for the game, but things changed over time, people wanted maps to be brighter, the horror was lost a lot, I get it. But in the last 2-3 years? Nothing has been fun on either side, and most recently, it's just not engaging to play as a survivor and it's not pleasant to play as a killer.

There are issues with the current climate of the game that has made it unfun in public matches.

I get it, you want everyone to have a good time. But when was the last time you tested the game, YOURSELVES, in a public match against some of the sweatiest streamer SWIFs? The perks you add just end up piled together that make it so easy to counter the killer, to basically not even play the game. It doesn't feel engaging at times if I win cause of players using these newer and less balanced perks. But there's a key here that I have noticed. A lot of survivors are streamers, I could go on about streamers ruining gaming as a whole but that's not for here. They dedicate their lives to playing the game and abusing it. But they're also the loudest, and most easily heard voice for you. So everytime I see a survivor buff or something to make their experience "better" I get it. But the fact that they can abandon so easily now in your game were the only gamemode is focused soully of ranks? It's kind of crazy that a killer can't do the same and get replaced by a bot. Cause some of those survivor players overtune their loadouts just so they can get killers to DC over and over and they're happy about it, which should really tell you the type of person you're catering your game to. And that doesn't even feed into the fact that you leave killers bugged, broken, and unable to fight these new perks, especially cause of the power creep those killers have gotten out of hand.

So, to you, who is debating buying this game. Don't give BHVR your money, go buy some other older games, or get TCM, sure it's dead but it's balanced.

And to the DEVS! IF ANY of you read this, please. Take a step back, play public lobbies as killers in the higher ranks, or even just the mid ranks-

Dead by Daylight is one of those rare games that just never stops being pure peak gaming, no matter how many hours you sink into it, and part of what makes it so good is the perfect blend of tension, strategy, unpredictability, and hilariously chaotic moments that keep every match feeling fresh. The atmosphere alone is unmatched‚Äîevery chase, every mind-game, every palette standoff feels like a mini psychological battle, and the rush you get when you win that interaction is exactly why the game stays addictive. What really makes it ‚Äúpeak,‚Äù though, is the variety of playstyles and personalities the killers bring to the fog, and that‚Äôs why maining Springtrap and Bubba feels so incredibly satisfying. Springtrap has that perfect mix of intimidation and raw pressure; the way he controls space and forces survivors into panic never stops being entertaining, and landing those jumpscares or shutting down loops feels like pure power. Bubba, on the other hand, is just the definition of fun‚Äînothing beats revving up the chainsaw, barreling into a loop, and securing a clean sweep or a spicy multi-down; it‚Äôs chaotic, it‚Äôs loud, it‚Äôs dramatic, and it never gets old. Both killers scratch different itches: Springtrap gives that cold, calculated, lore-heavy menace, while Bubba delivers the goofy, high-octane, zero-nonsense energy that turns even a standard match into a highlight reel. Together, they make logging into DBD feel exciting every time, because you know you‚Äôre either going to terrify survivors, make them panic, or send them spiraling into confusion as they try‚Äîand fail‚Äîto outplay you. Dead by Daylight stays peak because of killers like these, because of mains like us who pour love into our characters, and because no matter how many times we queue up, the fog always finds a new way to make the experience unforgettable. (credit to the big gtp for this goonable paragraph)

When I first stumbled upon Dead by Daylight‚Äîthe survival-horror game where one player assumes the role of an unstoppable killer and the rest play as survivors trying to escape‚ÄîI never could‚Äôve predicted the profound impact it would have on my life. At first glance, it seemed like a game made to thrill and terrify, but as I delved deeper into its nightmarish world, I realized it was more than just a horror game. It became a source of connection, a stress reliever, and even a way to build self-confidence. Here‚Äôs my story of how Dead by Daylight helped me become a better, stronger, and more self-aware person. When I first started playing, it was just for fun. A few friends introduced me to it, and I thought it‚Äôd be a good way to kill time. But I quickly realized that Dead by Daylight was more than just running from a killer or trying to outwit opponents‚Äîit was about connection. The game requires you to work with others in ways that foster cooperation, communication, and trust. Whether you‚Äôre in a match with strangers or friends, you‚Äôre always learning how to coordinate, plan, and support one another.

In a world where life can feel isolating, Dead by Daylight offered a place where I could find like-minded people. I joined communities, both in-game and online, where I could share experiences, strategies, and tips. This sense of camaraderie and belonging was life-changing. I started meeting people from all over the world who shared my love for horror games. We‚Äôd talk about tactics, but we also talked about life‚Äîpersonal challenges, triumphs, and even things unrelated to gaming. It felt good to be a part of something, to have a space where I was understood and could let my guard down. Before I started playing Dead by Daylight, I often struggled with stress and anxiety. Everyday worries seemed to get the better of me, and I found it difficult to relax. The high-stakes, fast-paced nature of the game actually became a form of escapism for me. There‚Äôs something oddly therapeutic about the pressure of being chased by a relentless killer. It takes you out of your head and forces you to focus entirely on the present moment. Every step, every choice, every heartbeat matters in those crucial seconds as you try to evade the killer or help your teammates.
Rather than leaving me more anxious, the game helped me channel my energy into something more productive. The tension in each match is so consuming that it becomes impossible to think about anything else. Once the game is over, I feel drained‚Äîbut in a good way. It's a release. The experience of facing fear and uncertainty, and then coming out on top (or sometimes failing gloriously), became a mental workout that improved my emotional resilience in real life. The complexity of Dead by Daylight also made me better at handling challenges. Each match is different. Sometimes the odds are in your favor, and other times, the killer seems unstoppable. The game doesn‚Äôt reward you for playing recklessly‚Äîit rewards you for thinking strategically. I learned to adapt quickly, figure out the best ways to outsmart my opponents, and stay calm under pressure. This translates to real-life situations, where I now approach challenges with a clearer mind and a more methodical approach. It taught me how to look at problems from multiple angles and take calculated risks.In the game, there are moments where patience is key‚Äîwhether you‚Äôre waiting for the perfect moment to escape, healing a teammate, or fixing a generator. You can‚Äôt rush the process, and sometimes, your efforts don‚Äôt pay off immediately. In the past, I struggled with impatience, but Dead by Daylight slowly taught me that things take time, and sometimes, you just have to trust the process. One of the most profound ways Dead by Daylight changed me was by shifting my perspective on fear. In the game, you spend most of your time running from a killer, hearing their heavy breathing and the sounds of their chase as they draw closer. It‚Äôs terrifying. But what‚Äôs truly empowering is when you face that fear head-on. There‚Äôs a rush that comes from evading the killer, hiding in a locker at the last moment, or escaping the trial when all seems lost. I began to realize that I didn‚Äôt have to avoid fear‚ÄîI could face it, learn from it, and even come out stronger on the other side.
In real life, this mentality carried over. Whenever a challenge felt overwhelming or intimidating, I reminded myself that I could handle it‚Äîjust like I handled that terrifying chase in the game. It wasn‚Äôt about avoiding fear but understanding it, and realizing I could still make progress even when it felt impossible. This has given me a new level of self-confidence, both in my personal and professional life.Dead by Daylight is more than just an action-packed horror game; it‚Äôs a psychological battle of wits. As a survivor, I learned how to plan every move with precision‚Äîwhether it was strategically looping the killer or making split-second decisions to save a teammate. As a killer, I‚Äôve learned how to read the environment, anticipate survivor moves, and use my unique abilities to outsmart my prey.
This kind of creative thinking has translated into my everyday life. I now approach tasks with a strategic mindset, whether I‚Äôm organizing my day or working through complex projects. The skills I‚Äôve developed in-game‚Äîmultitasking, analyzing risk, and using limited resources wisely‚Äîhave directly impacted my problem-solving ability outside the game.When I look back at my journey with Dead by Daylight, I realize it wasn‚Äôt just a game that provided entertainment. It became a tool for growth‚Äîa source of confidence, self-awareness, and connection. The lessons I‚Äôve learned in the game have shaped the way I approach fear, work with others, and deal with challenges in my daily life.

Sure, there are frustrating moments when you get caught in the game, or when a match doesn‚Äôt go your way, but that‚Äôs just part of the experience. It‚Äôs all about learning and improving, which mirrors life itself. And for all its horror, Dead by Daylight has taught me how to face my own fears, step into the unknown, and come out on the other side a stronger person.
So, if you‚Äôre wondering whether a video game could really change your life‚ÄîI can say without a doubt that Dead by Daylight did for me. It wasn‚Äôt just a game; it was a path to growth, self-discovery, and a renewed sense of purpose.

This game used to be fun bun not anymore.. Devs pander to the loud survivors and turned the game into something very frustrating if you want to play killer.  It is a 1 killer vs 4 survivors and the most effective strategy as a killer is to take one of the survivors out of the game as soon as possible so it becomes a 1v3 . But hooking the same survivor 3 times in a row is called ''tunneling'' and if you do what's best for you as a killer you will get insulted in the end game chat lobby. But if they all escape you also get laughed at, called ''baby killer'' and survivors always have something negative to say at the end of the match. In my opinion the most outrageous is the survivor perk ''Windows of Opportunity'' which lets them see all the pallets and windows around them and makes them plan the loops way easier so it's like having a hack. Not to mention that recently they ''balanced'' the pallets density by adding even more on the maps and leaving no ''dead zones''. The game is also infested with LGBT flags because the devs had the brilliant idea to break the immersion of the game by letting survivors hang flags from their belt and killers hang flags from the hooks. I would not buy the game in the state that is right now.
