I have never seen a game where the Killer needs to repeatedly hook the same Survivor to eliminate them, yet the Killer's chasing ability is so weak. Not only is the chasing ability weak, but the Killer's perks are also monotonous and repetitive‚Äîthe strongest skill turns out to be a simple dash. What's more, despite such an obvious imbalance favoring Survivors, the developers still haven't realized it. As game developers, they have failed to see the core issue‚Äîthey only notice Killers targeting specific Survivors without understanding why. If chasing other Survivors offered a better payoff than focusing on one, who would persistently tunnel a single player and relentlessly limit their game experience? Survivors want to win, but don't Killer players want to win too? Step by step, the game space for Killer players is being constrained. I can only say that the future of this game looks bleak. If Dead by Daylight continues to refuse to face reality, indulging in the idea that profiting from four players is better than profiting from one, thereby sacrificing the Killer player experience, this game will soon fade into obscurity, drowned in players' disappointment.

This genuinely might be one of the worst "popular" games that I have ever played. I'm not even playing into the DBD hate hype train. I am absolutely shocked that it is not dead yet - Perhaps because there aren't other asymmetrical games like it, and the licenses keep player count high. 

This does not feel like a live service game. Year after year we have asked for specific things, and BHVR responds with "yeah that's cool, also look at this new license! But no, you're right, Game Health is important... so in honour of that, let's worsen the cosmetics UI for no reason". Also, there is a long-standing bug list for a bunch of killers that the devs haven't even sniffed, and I don't think they're ever going to get fixed. 

Speaking of killers, the balance team at BHVR definitely like to troll. The Krasue release was absolutely awful - and this was only exacerbated by the recoil from the terrible Walking Dead livestream situation prior. I literally stopped playing for weeks until she got nerfed. 

How many times have game-breaking things like this happened which make the game unplayable for an extended period of time? BHVR somehow manage to maintain a completely ignorant approach to all the things that they do. Like dude, if this was any other game, you would legit think the company hates their fans or are intentionally trolling, but when it comes to this game, you just say "Good Ol BHVR!". This company's name and reputation has become synonymous with "dogshit" for crying out loud. I will say that is not true in regards to the support team at least. The support team actually try to stay on top of tickets, unless they get inundated like all of the employees at BHVR do, which is why there are so many quick fixes. 

The game itself is so monotonous and boring, and the seasonal events and 2v8 do little to actually make the base game anymore entertaining. Imagine your soloQ team is trolling, so you have to sit on gens the whole game... 5 games in a row. Not fun, right? That's often the reality. And dude, fucking Among Us makes doing survivor tasks more enjoyable than a 10 year old, live-service horror game. Where is the courage to go out of their comfort zone and bring engaging gen completion ideas to the PTB. BHVR are terrified to take risks. This is another reason why DBD does not feel like a live service game. Rather, it feels like they are just keeping the servers running. 

If it wasn't for comp or JRM-style trolling, people with over 2000 hours would've left for another game like a mass exodus (and BHVR only recently started doing things like "supporting" creators or DBDLeague. For so long, there was such little community involvement in ANYTHING. I have rarely seen other western companies do the same with their popular games). 

I came back to Dead By Daylight from a month of not playing (during which I played CS2, Runescape, Metro 2033 series and Minecraft) to this game and was absolutely shocked at how truly unenjoyable everything was. Like I said, if it wasn't for comp or JRM-ing killers, the only way DBD would keep its numbers up would be with a constant influx of new players, as older players would be getting tf out ASAP. I have not played a game less rewarding to invest time into. 

Queue up in SoloQ against a good killer? That's always game over, because BHVR's "mmr-based" matchmaking will consistently give you bad survivors who should not be put in your lobby, so it's not even a fun challenge. Queue up in SoloQ against a bad killer? That's always ggez, because you stomp this poor baby killer who doesn't even know what a CJ tech is, again because the matchmaking is not coded with any common sense in regards to mmr, but done in a way to reduce queue times. 

Also they 100% lie slightly about the ping in public games. Whatever your ping is, add 30 onto it. 

I actually was working towards becoming a major content creator for DBD, but HensDaMonsta can take the spotlight, because whilst this game still has potential, the way BHVR manages it does not, and so I have lost faith in Dead By Daylight. What a letdown.

This is the most dangerous game of hide-and-seek you may ever play. It is fun but difficult as it is almost exclusively other players in the match.

In regular play, there are 4 survivors vs 1 killer, and all players can choose from a small list of default characters, or purchase one of *many* DLC packs to unlock additional characters, many of which are licensed from other horror movies or games. It is a lot of DLC if you really wanted to unlock and try everything in a short, reasonable amount of time. That may put off a lot of players, but licensing is expensive so it is an understandable move by the devs, and also supports a lot of great horror franchises. The number of characters available also creates a ton of diversity in match-ups that you may encounter on either side, too, even if you haven't purchased a specific DLC yourself.

Every survivor has a few semi-unique perks to make them feel different besides their cosmetic look, and each killer has a (sometimes VERY) different set of perks and secondary skill to help them catch the survivors before they can repair generators and escape through the gate to safety.

Each match is fun and tense, but you must be okay with losing and sometimes that may feel unfair to you. If you are not okay with losing often, then this is not the game for you and it may only frustrate you. That is okay, it just means you need to find a different game that suits you better. This game is awesome if you enjoy tense PvP matches, though!

Okay so slightly different than surrounding reviews, but I feel like this game suffers from a player base which have herd behavior (in terms of the toxicity aspect), when I came to try this game after hearing all about it from the player base, popular streamers and friends. I thought I was going to play the most annoying game which was unbalanced and stuff of the sorts but when I played it I didnt feel much of that, now I understand how this game could be toxic but over my 65 hours playing as both killer/survivor these cases were kinda widespread not saying it doesn't exist but what pvp game doesn't have a somewhat toxic players, I know I haven't exactly spent 1000 hrs in game I haven't met them all but I feel like the amount of toxicity in this game is overplayed by the player base, either through popular content creators or player who only play killer or survivor so they tend to assume that the other side is stronger alot of people say that the game is killer sided or survivor sided but I mean each side has their own strengths and weaknesses, now if you were to ask me if you should buy the game I would say yes most killers are unique (apart from some which have similar abilities) but most are fun to play survivors admittedly is kinda RNG on whether or not you're gonna synergize well with team but still fun. not saying the devs are the best of the best but well who is.
TLDR, In my opinion the game is a nice game but people keep overplaying the amount of toxicity that occurs in the game

I just can't help but come back to it over and over. That said, the community itself ruins everything. I don't care much about the whole "camping this" and "tunnelling that" business, but what I do care about is the fact that the community will complain about EVERYTHING. Less fun map? Complain. Dont know how to loop? Complain. Ever so slightly outperform someone? Complain. New killer came out? Complain SO HARD that behaviour has to nerf them INTO THE GROUND so that everyone stops being angry. And don't even get me started on the Tokyo Ghoul controversy either. Not to mention the amount of TTV players that think that being toxic and downright hurtful is good content... it's honestly painful and genuinely sad. My friends on console aren't even safe from chat either because players will actively reach out to talk trash and insult you in DMs. 

All in all, if you can get past the near-LoL level toxicity of the community or manage to find a group of friends you want to run custom games with, I super-duper recommend the game. Otherwise, maybe give this game a bit of space.

Game does not respect players

Ive played this game on and off since its release, ive had 3 different accounts and have played against every type of player there is. I say all of this to sadly just have the realization that this game just is not cared about anymore by the devs. Time and time again they blatantly ignore feedback, delay features we have begged for year after year, and refuse to fix any other issues that have been plaguing this game for the longest time.
The countless untouched bugs for both killer and survivor, the constant release of 50/50 sided maps that dont feel balanced or fair. The GOD AWFUL matchmaking, and the insane levels of powercreep from churning out DLC after DLC with new perks that just push the game further and further into the grave.
It used to be I could queue survivor or killer and just play whatever I wanted. I could run fun meme builds, maybe trying out different playstyles on each side to see what would be fun. 
Now I am forced to run meta every single game, because if I dont, I lose. If I dont run meta perks on survivor, weather it be fast gen rushing or meta chase perks, we lose.
If im playing killer and im not running ANYTHING other than gen slowdown, by the time I get the first few hooks, the gates are already open, and this is coming from a person who has seen every meta this game has ever had. This is by far the WORST state ive ever seen the game in, the insane amounts of pallets on every map pretty much killed this game on both sides for me. As a killer, unless im running the best killers in the game, or Lord help me im running an m1 killer, im gonna have to go through at least 5-6 loops in one chase, SOMETIMES MORE depending on the map and tile set I get. I have to mindgame every 10 seconds meanwhile gens FLY by because everyone is just running gen rush. Its not fun for survivor either, it used to be I actually had to THINK every time I threw down a pallet, seeing as how thats potentially a resource im wasting, but now theres so many that there is literally ZERO risk in just pre dropping practically everything, by the time the killer breaks it, even with a kick speed build, im already at ANOTHER pallet. By the time I go down usually we get 3-4 gens done. The art of looping has been turned into a fucking clownfest.
The devs actively refuse to fix this, they dont test their games before patches as was demonstrated with the ABYSMAL launch of the walking dead chapter, they regularly dont test skins as we have seen with SEVERAL killer skins that actively make you LOSE due to either bugs or visual clarity (im looking at you blight deathslinger on launch) and they just dont care. They have decided that they are gonna cater to survivors, and it cant even be hidden anymore. They are gonna milk this game for however much they can squeeze left and abandon it, because the levels of neglect and lack of polish is just astonishing.

I loved this game, I really did. It had a special place in my heart, but the devs lack of foresight or care, along with the terrible balancing, matchmaking, and dont even get me STARTED on this shitty, toxic community, legit one of the worst ive ever witnessed. Ive seen 2013 COD lobbies with more sane and rational individuals. I just cant look at the shell of what its turned into. Its broken, its ugly, its unbalanced, and the level of negligence that is plain to see just saddens me. Dont play this game, save yourself the time and the sanity.

Oh and FUCK your over ONE HUNDRED DOLLARS worth of DLC if I wanna be able to get everything BHVR.

Kinda fun at its base but the developers are just straight-up clueless. in a game where its supposed to be 1 strong killer vs 4 survivors, they seem to think that only the survivors experience matters. they also clearly don't play their own game, and make all balancing decisions by spreadsheet. theyve left S+++ tier killers untouched for years and years because the data shows they have a low kill rate (because they have a lot of skill required to use) and have repeatedly nerfed people who kinda just suck already, because noobs dont know how to deal with them. theyve tried implementing severe penalties for killers just... doing their job in a way the devs dont like, penalties you can easily trigger on accident, while survivors doing THEIR job in the most toxic, frustrating and poor-sportsmanship ways is met with an "alls fair in love and war" sort of attitude. will not be playing again until the people behind it suddenly get a WHOLE LOT smarter, and i'm not holding my breath on that particular possibility.

Used to be balanced, It is the most survivor sided it's ever been. Was pallet density needed for some maps? 100% instead of just haddonfield however, they buffed EVERY SINGLE maps pallet density the saw map is genuinely impossible to win on with new pallets everywhere, Survivors don't even have to loop anymore they can just chain to the next pallet insta drop it and then continue on. The stupidest thing is how this barely even effects the actually overpowered killers (Nurse, Ghoul, Blight,) it just makes bad killers even worse who don't have super good mobility or chase powers, And then to top it off in the latest PTB they're giving survivors multiple perks as basekit along with multiple of those perks being old meta perks. The new add-ons remodel makes you able to use exhaustion perks twice in a row in seconds, you can sprint burst, sprint burst and just zoom across half the map. They also have overtuned anti tunnel buffs, anti face camp, anti slug, and the face camp is literally when your within that entire side of the map basically. And guess what killers got, a measly 200 blood point bonus for hooks or some stupid stuff. Absolutely horrendous balancing team, Otzvarda is the only reason this game is still alive and every DBD YouTuber is also critiquing this catastrophy of changes.

Dead By Daylight is a game that is only playable during infrequent 2 week periods. The game, in its normal 1v4 mode, is plagued by feature creep and an insufferable playerbase. During its 2v8 events, not only are these problems largely mitigated, but the game becomes more fun at a fundamental, structural level. I wish I could give this game a positive review, but that review would only apply to the brief periods of time that I actually enjoy playing it. 

If Behaviour wants to make their game permanently fun, they would make 2v8 permanently enabled. While this would effectively kill 1v4, in the words of Reggie, "If it's not fun, whats the point?"

this game feels like a psyop with how scripted matches feel sometimes. its either a killer appearing out of nowhere to plug my hole with ravenous claws or a perk not working the way its supposed to only when it matters in chase. im actively going insane with how appalling this game manages to be at every single second. one game i get teammates who dont know how to do a single gen combined with a killer who has an eons worth of hours in the game at ash 4, then the next its a 3 stack of comp survivors who make the killer leave immediately. the bugs in the game outweigh the actual working features by 10-fold to the point where an intentional mechanic feels like a godsend when it works. the only things that save this game is the fact that this shit only happens to me and atleast the basic gameplay loop feels engaging. i swear no other game has made me cut more than this one, but literally what else is there to do? no other game works like this and has the opportunity to be fun (if ur willng to play 100 games just to get one decent one) like this. i find it fucking crazy that people dont take tunneling serious enough. complaining about how hard these changes are on killers when i could already shit on most teams with my eyes closed in the current state. have u not experienced getting tunneled every single game for HOURS of gameplay? its a horrible experience that just forces u to run a meta build to someone counteract that. even then, right after changing builds i will always be put against the specific killer with specific perks that make mine useless. so then i go to change them again and look! same fucking thing. the only perk that can be used every game is resilience. a perk that at this point should be build into the survivor kit with how fucking required it is to loop at all. even with perfect looping skills and knowledge of a map, without resilience its impossible to vault anything without getting hit from across the universe. literally how is it possible that a killer is always twice my speed whenever its clearly states that their only 10-15% faster?? i swear that so many killers are sliding on the floor without the necessary perks to do so that u would think its a fucking ice rink. maybe im just slower than everyone else and thats why the killer can catch up in 2 seconds flat without bloodlust. who knows.

Pros:
- Really cool game concept
- Fun casual/party game, especially with friends! 

Cons:
- Horrible and toxic community
- Extremely incompetent and tone-deaf developers who make the most baffling of decisions on an extremely regular basis and refuse to listen to feedback
- Bugs and glitches out the wazoo (there's a new problem every patch)
- Horrible balancing and blatant favoritism (from the devs) for casual players who will DC at the first sign of the slightest inconvenience
- Extremely poor tutorials and one of the worst beginner experiences imaginable (the game will not teach you anything about how to play and increase your skill level - you have youtubers for that)

Final Verdict:

Dead by Daylight - a name-based breakdown

[b]Dead[/b]
You play in one of two teams (yes, a solo team is still a team), either trying to do the dead to someone or avoiding becoming the dead.
As the killer, it is your job to find people, run in circles of varying radii while dodging pallets thrown at you for at least 10 minutes, attack survivors with often questionable hit registration, and scramble to find a hook in proximity. Rinse and repeat thrice per survivor.
You also get a large cast of characters with increasingly broken and more abundant abilities and perks (scaling with in-game and IRL money cost, of course).
As a survivor, your job is one of: Holding Mouse Button 1 for an eternity and occasionally tapping space, running in circles of varying radii while dodging the killer, dropping pallets and jumping through windows, and enjoying the scenery while [i]hanging around[/i].

[b]by[/b]
By choosing to play this of your own free will, you prove that you are masochistic.
As the killer, the survivors always find some random junk scattered by a tornado to hide behind, and as a survivor, the killer is always slightly* faster than you.
If you are planning to play a killer with projectile or ranged attacks, dont't. Hitboxes in this game have been proven to protrude into the 7th dimension, especially those that don't look that way.
Conversely, survivors have been known to have been hit by attacks through solid objects.
Really shows how our understanding of physics breaks down beyond the third spatial dimension.
Also remember to pray to RNGsus before running through shrubbery, as it might be of the 'solid' genus despite sharing the phenotype of their 'transparent' siblings.
It's also funny how there are never any windows or pallets while you are being chased. Well, back to admiring the level geometry.

The performance is also abysmal. Lowering the graphics settings barely makes a difference, as the game is consistently gobbling up 80-100% of my CPU even while not much or even nothing is happening (e.g. game lobby, transition screens).
Depending on the map, it turns into a PowerPoint presentation as soon as at least one other player is on screen for no discernable reason.
On a positive note, I no longer have to change settings every time I boot up the game, so a big round of applause.

[b]Daylight[/b]
This game is anti-fun regardless of which team you play on, regardless of you win or lose. Good games where neither team is completely steamrolled are few and far between.
It seems like you are placed in the timeout box after dominating too many matches in a row and are free to return after serving your sentence. If that's your thing, good for you, but that ain't it, chief.

Specifically for 2V8 (the only theoretically redeemable mode**) the killer queues are a joke. You usually wait 30+ minutes for a match, and too often just so that the survivors can complete the 'DBD All 8 Generators' 100% glitchless speedrun in 2m 57s.
How is this possible when there is a 5-digit player count at all times? The introduction of 'Survive While You Wait' has done precisely nothing and the priority queue got ditched after one iteration of this game mode for reasons I don't care enough to look up.
At least you may partake in fun activities such as: Holding Mouse Button 1 (but more often because no one else is doing it), getting nothing done while being permanently cornered by 2 killers, and getting ignored by up to 7 players while in a cage collecting hook states (what do you mean that's not the objective???).

I'm being held here against my will by a so called 'friend' who's only into these kinds of games. Please help.

* Top speeds of Mach 3 have been registered.
** Objective fact.

Hate it, Behaviour never listens and keeps making absurd changes to try and kill their own game.

You‚Äôll spend 30 minutes matchmaking, 5 minutes hiding in a bush, and 2 seconds realizing the killer saw you anyway. Then you‚Äôll scream, die, and immediately queue again because apparently, we all love trauma.

Playing killer feels powerful until you chase someone around the same pallet for three business days. Playing survivor feels empowering until you realize no one else brought a med-kit and everyone‚Äôs crouching behind the same rock.

The community is 50% wholesome teamwork, 50% salt mine, and 100% people teabagging at the exit gate like they‚Äôve achieved enlightenment.

Overall, it‚Äôs a fantastic horror party simulator where trust issues flourish, heart rates spike, and friendship ends‚Äîjust like Monopoly, but with more blood.

Dead by Daylight is a fun but flawed experience. The tension of being chased, the sound design, and the thrill of last-second escapes make for genuinely memorable moments ‚Äî especially if you play with friends. The variety of killers and survivors keeps matches interesting, and Behaviour still supports the game with frequent updates and collaborations.

That said, the game has real issues. Matchmaking is inconsistent, balance constantly swings between killer- and survivor-favored, and the community can be frustrating ‚Äî from camping killers to teammates who quit early. Performance and bugs also pop up more often than they should for a game this old.

When it works, it‚Äôs amazing. When it doesn‚Äôt, it‚Äôs exhausting.

Verdict: If you enjoy horror and chaotic multiplayer moments, give it a try ‚Äî but be ready for some rough matches and tilted games along the way.

I usually keep my opinions to myself when it comes to feedback.

But since Dead by Daylight is my main game, with over 2000 hours of playtime. feel compelled to speak up, even if it won't make much of a difference.

We're all familiar with the problems that plague this game, 
but I experienced them again in the 2v8 mode.
A mode that should be fun has turned into a disaster.

Once again, I'm dealing with bots, players who rage quit, and killers who act out their perverse thoughts and engage in slugging.
It's just exhausting. The fun is completely gone.

Where are the people with a sense of personal connection?

Video games are meant to be an escape from reality, aren't they?

I'm speechless.

I wish it weren't like this, but unfortunately, it is, and I can't look away anymore.

I hope the future will bring some light back into this darkness, because I won't be putting up with this much longer.

Killer Role is actively sabotaged by the developers. Exhibit A example of Reddit incarnate balancing a PVP videogame. Real world ethics, politics and morality don't have any place in how you balance a horror PVP game about surviving against iconic figures either inspires by or actual licensed horror films. Total letdown. This game's state is a small symptom of a larger issue growing in the video game community/industry. Good sportsmanship and healthy competition is under attack by toxic positivity-spewing sensitives who cannot handle losing. Instead of learning game mechanics/expanding their knowledge motivated by interest in the game itself, they will complain and moral grandstand towards the community and developers to make the game easier for themselves. PVP as a whole is under attack by people who have no business interacting with game franchises built around PVP; this includes people hired to work on them, not just players. Developers with shaky/questionable convictions are complying with players uninterested in games to double-team fun games. Stop ruining niche games/genres.

Devs don't understand how to balance their own game and constantly make changes to the game which overcomplicate it to the point that even with 300 hours, you will have matches that end with "I literally don't know what the counterplay for this power/perk is".

Some survive with friends groups play the game to bully killers rather than the actual game objective, which leads to killers playing toxic in response, which leads to more toxic survivors countering the toxic killers. It's a problem caused by the game's own design and is currently in a huge feedback loop, especially as all recent attempts by the devs to "fix" these issues are tone deaf on community concerns or issues raised.

If ever a game needed a competitor to blow it out of the water, it's this one - sadly there's basically no other game on the market that offers this gameplay, and yet what is presented here right now is simply not fun in public matches... and I cannot recommend a game based on "if you have 4 other friends and an hour to make up a ruleset to make it friendly for newer players to know what's happening, it's good fun".

I love this game, I always come back to it. I would be lying if I said it didn't have its frustrations. However there are no other games quite like this. I used to play Friday The 13th up until its legal troubles and this game filled that void. I especially like how competitive this game is and what it has to offer, other horror games generally are a pick up a few times for me, but DBD gives meaning and purpose to wanting to improve at it. DBD also isn't limited to one specific horror character when other games typically focus on one. You could argue the gameplay can get repetitive, but I find myself enjoying the different killers approaches in changing the gameplay dynamics. As a horror fan, I approve. 

Tip: Get the perk from the chainsaw killer that makes you immune to flashlights, you can apply it to different killers. Have fun!

Having sunk 222 hours into Dead by Daylight, the game continues to hook me with its incredible depth and iconic roster. As a Killer main, I get an unmatched adrenaline rush playing as Albert Wesker, launching myself across the map, and slamming survivors into walls or throwing them towards one is satisfying. It's weskin' time. The tactical mind-games of The Glitchtrap from FNAF is also pretty fun. When I switch to survivor, I always come back to Sable Ward or Ada Wong with Michonne from the Walking Dead's perks. 

The social aspect is a huge part of the fun; teaming up with friends for a late-night survival session is a weekly ritual. It's chaotic and fun. But there's also a unique, solitary tension to playing Killer in the quiet of the afternoon. The constant updates and crossovers with legendary horror franchises keep the meta fresh and exciting. It's a game that truly rewards your time and passion. But I would say the new update is quite survivor sided and makes killers harder to play, so hopefully the devs can balance things out soon.

2371, to some that is a crazy amount of hours, to others it is not even half of theirs. Would i recommend this game? Yes but No, it's not a hard No but i wouldn't recommend to a new player for the sole reason you need to sink a silly amount of numbers into the game to learn the basics but also to actually enjoy the amount of perks you need to buy nearly every character just to be in for a chance of competing against good players. Now the review, this is a killer mains perspective so you survivor mains move along you will just disagree with everything boohoo killer main yes yes.

So I've played, streamed and put so much time into this game that it was the sole game i played for years now, patch after patch, perk addition after perk addition, toxic message after toxic message later I've learned what a pile of poop this game really is, beneath all the bugs, imbalances and overall mess of a game this is, is the most toxic community only second to League of Legends I've ever come across!! Had a decent game with 8 hooks, 2 hooks on 3 people and 1 dead, nah trash should get good while watching 3 lots of tea bags at the exit gate because you played "fair", so you change it up, get 2 survivors out earlier and avoiding the good looper BANG!!! TUNNELLER, UNFAIR, REPORTED, CAMPER, PLAYING LIKE A TOXIC PERSON!!!, You can't win.

Now let's move onto the devs. I am sick and tired of seeing the immense hand holding to one side it's unreal, look at patch 9.3.0 that is soon to come out (PTB.... we will see), it's honestly a disgrace that survivors are getting countless base kit additions, x-ray, shield, speed, stealth etc.... oh but don't worry the killer gets some extra speed after hooking, but he will lose it as soon as they see a survivor... but don't worry we will throw in an extra 200bp for each hook!!! Talk about the 2nd child treatment oh my gosh. The fact they don't even play test their own game (Jim Beam is an obvious fact that they don't) is laughable. This game is digging it's own grave and i'm tired of thinking team killer will have an easy time. The last survey i closed, i didn't even finish because it's insulting that the options for why you uninstalling or not enjoying the game features 2 anti fun killer options basically asking Survivor mains why they are not enjoying... what about why i'm not enjoying? Why is there no "Gens are too fast" "Too many Endurance perks" "Base kit is too oppressive" "Why can i only kick a gen 8 times but Survs can heal infinite times and reset" or any other killers are not having fun options but nope they only care about the favourite child. 

Before anyone wonders... yes i play Survivor, i have around 1K of my play time survivor as well and boy can you feel the game is designed around them just by the game play. So, to most i would never recommend this game but apart of me still holds stupid hope that they will think about both sides and reward the killer for playing how "They are supposed too" you know killers are meant to play a certain way to make sure the survivors are having fun too. The more i type all this out the more i realise i am just no longer enjoying the game and for the first time in years i actually am close to calling it daylight.

Hope this didn't feel too much like a crying rant as yes it does look like it but i guess it's just come this far and that is how i am viewing the game! The game at its core is fantastic but has too many issues. Until the devs actually decide to think about the other team I'm going to give it a rest for a while. Surv queues are going to sky rocket with how many killer mains will end up leaving.

I really wanna enjoy this game, i really do. But at this point i genuinely feel like i got scammed. When i first got the game back in June, it was a blast. Sure i did get killed a bunch of times and sometimes don't get a full 4k. And maybe get called a few slurs on the side (Although i enjoy the cope.) But the game was still absolutely fun to play both as killer and survivor.

But nowadays, especially with what's being going on right now. Things are definitely different, and not in a good way. Every time i boot up the game, i don't feel like i'm trying to fight for my life or purge any living thing by dawn. but instead trying to endure the daily punishment set out by the Laughing Joking Numbnuts over at BHVR. We all know that the devs love to glaze and hand hold survivors, BUT DEAR GOD! This is just full on Helicopter Parenting for survivors at this point, while killers get left to shiver in the doghouse in the pouring rain like an unloved family pet. Pallet Density, Survivors getting more OP buffs than killers, while bugs that affected killers for a while never getting fixed. And of course the latest PTB, (or as i like to call, anti killer update) being their magnum opus. The fact that they brought this back, despite the massive backlash they got when it was first announced. Shows that they are really incompetent, tone deaf, and overall don't care about killers. And are fully determined to make the role less fun for new players and pros alike and get them to uninstall and get refunds.

They don't understand that there are times that killers need to do these to win matches and get blood points, so taking away those simple things and nerfing them, just makes them less of an imposing threat, and more of a worn out punching bag for survivors to wail on every match. And i'm not being biased, cause i also main survivor as well. And i've definitely seen killers struggling to get a single kill. While other survivors just pick on them with flashlights, vial bombs and other stuff. Sometimes i even offer myself to get killed cause i feel bad for them, Genuinely tragic. And survivors just rag on them and be super toxic towards them after every match. Yet those same players are the type that don't want to learn how to actually get good and learn how to use builds and strats such as looping, but instead bitch, whine and complain to BHVR that they need buffs, and that killers are doing this and that, and overall being crybabies and ruining the fun for everyone. And whats's worse is that these are the people BHVR are kowtowing and submitting to the most, for reasons i don't know why. But it's just Grade A Textbook favoritism towards survivors and don't even dare to touch upon things like gen rushes, bully squads and other unfair things that they do, and they have the nerve to say killers are being handheld? What a sick joke!

It's genuinely sad to see this game go down like this, cause this definitely had and still has the potential to be a great game, especially for horror fans like myself. But the biggest problems are the game killing clowns from BHVR. They clearly show that they do not even play their own damn game, let alone know what they're doing, and instead pander and rely on the whiniest part of the fanbase to help make decisions. They lack integrity and do a very piss poor job at balancing and maintaining their game. Dead by Daylight: where I finally discovered my true talent‚Äîbeing the ultimate escape artist... from my own dignity. Nothing quite beats the thrill of being chased by a lumbering killer only to trip over my own shoelaces and become the next victim. The game‚Äôs balance is so perfect that it‚Äôs almost impressive‚Äîif by 'impressive' you mean relentless frustration in a cute, indie horror package. It‚Äôs like hide-and-seek, but with more screaming and less hiding. Five stars for making me question all my life choices‚Äîespecially why I keep ignoring those warning signs about my gaming addiction!

I haven‚Äôt actively played the game since 2023, and this isn‚Äôt my main account but I still wanted to leave a review here.

Unfortunately, in recent years the game just stopped feeling the same for me. The atmosphere has changed a lot, and with all the balance updates, the killer side has been heavily nerfed.
To be fair, I was never the type to complain about balance as someone who mostly played killer at a decent level, these changes didn‚Äôt affect me much personally.
But I can definitely see how mid-level killer players might find the current state frustrating.

Still, out of respect for the great times I had in the past and the fact that this game is still alive today, I wanted to leave a positive review.
It‚Äôs worth its price, because unlike many other games in this genre, it won‚Äôt shut down in a year or two and that alone makes it stand out.

I love this game, but I cannot in good conscious give this game a good rating, as it stands. The developers are so willfully blind, almost to the point of it being malicious, that they're willing to alienate an entire chunk of their playerbase. Never in all of this game's history have I seen such blatant handholding. The devs are going far out, above and beyond, to ensure that the poor and helpless survivors don't feel "bullied" or are "having a bad time". They have an entire exit/uninstall survey, that specifically asks why SURVIVORS have left the game, there isn't a single option to select that accounts for a point of frustration for killers. It is blatantly obvious and clear for all to see, that Behavior CLEARLY values one side over the other. It isn't refutable at this point, there is no denying it in any way, shape, or form. Punish the killers for playing. It's genuinely sad to see, all because Behavior makes money off of shit like Sable bikini goon skin, so they must cater to that demographic at the expense of everyone else. The casualization of this game will be the death of it, starting with patch 9.3.0. My review will change when and if they come to their senses, and stop this foolishness.

BHVR. I'm writing this as someone who started playing the game in the newest anniversary update. Stop trying to pass the Slugging, Tunneling, and Camping update if you want to keep making money. You are actively making Killer a worse role to play while making survivors all the better. Why? You, as a team, do not understand Killer game play, nor do you understand that Killer is supposed to be unfair. Your team seemingly only ever cares about how it feels to play survivor, to the point of over-tuning it. Why are you gutting one of the most fun perks for killer and replacing it with an ability that doesn't work for more than HALF YOUR ROSTER OF KILLERS? Why are you making it that if a killer dares to hook a survivor in the basement, they get 30 seconds of haste, endurance, and get FULLY HEALED? You are punishing Killers for doing what they're supposed to do. Your making the Survivor role less about "surviving" and more about farming clips for Tiktok and playing this weird power fantasy. Slugging, facecamping, and tunneling are NOT real problems. Why? Because games last a few minutes, then you move on to the next one. Killers do NOT quit a game after chase that ends badly for them, some Survivors, however, quit as soon as they lose one chase and get hooked. Those survivors are the people you are capitulating to. Making this game more casual for the new people coming in is the stupidest choice as a company you can make. This game is almost ten years old. People having been playing this game for that long. You have a good thing going here, DBD is the most fun when both sides have options to win, not when Killers HAVE to play with one play style the entire time or risk getting punished for nothing. Do NOT release the new ptb. Play Killer for two months straight, THEN decide what to do. It's obvious no one mainly plays killer over there. If you want to keep making money, stop making the dumbest decisions possible.

Christ, what a mess. This game is a lot. Both sides of the coin, killer and survivor will always tell you that the other side is handheld by the developer, the other side is too easy, it's too broken, blah, blah blah. Let me ask you, then. Which side are new players AFRAID to play? Is it the half of the game where they are hunted down like prey, slaughtered while they run and complete objectives? Or is it the one doing the slaughtering, the one holding those lives in the palm of their hands? It's killer. It's always been killer. Because killer has always been the centerpiece of any match of DBD, killer NEEDS to feel good. Killer needs to feel powerful. Killer needs to feel... fun. And recently, it feels like BHVR has been trying their hardest to prevent that from being possible.

 I try my best to leave survivors alone when they get unhooked, unless there's a damn good reason to do otherwise. I've never slugged someone out in my life. And yet, I'm being punished by the devs for the actions of bad actors by having survivors be granted 30 seconds of fucking god mode on unhook. Wicked and Resurgence are going to allow survivors to go down, get hooked in basement, self unhook in front of my face at FULL HEALTH, get hit, run away for 29 seconds, get hit again because they still have endurance, and then make a break for it. The pallet density is still off the charts. And what do killers get for these survivor buffs? One tier of bloodlust. .2 meters per second of movement speed. Most killer's base movement speed is 4.6 meters per second. That is a microscopic increase. And not only is the increase microscopic, it is very fragile. If I'm playing a mid-tier killer, one that is supposed to benefit from this move speed increase instead of making the top tiers stronger, what do you suppose the first thing I'll want to do after hooking a survivor is? Looking for another survivor. How does The Knight do that? Well, it's easy! I'll just send out my guard, check this generator, and... my movement speed bonus is gone. All because I tried to play the game.  How does The Doctor do that? Let me just charge up my static blast, and... the movement speed is gone. Any teleport killer? Gone. Any information? Bye-bye. Stealth? Nope. This is the kind of ass-backwards design that BHVR comes up with to keep the playing field "fair". It's nonsense. 

Let it be known. I'm no fool. BHVR is no stranger to swinging the pendulum the other way. I remember Call of Brine Eruption. I was there for original Hex: Ruin (which was only so universal because survivors were given more tools than killers had at the time, but I digress). Killer has been miserable for survivors to play against too. But that's the problem. This is a fucking video game. Why should we be miserable? Why should we sink another 500 hours and 2000 auric cells into this game when we could do literally anything else? Learn a skill. Read a book. BHVR doesn't respect your time. Please respect your own.

Bums just want hand outs rather then use their tiny peanut brains. Just get better & stop expecting handouts because your tiny brains can't multitask. LMAOOOOOO

But lately BHVR just keeps giving survivors more buffs because they cant handle losing and are a majority over killers in this 4v1 asymetric game, meanwhile killers keep getting bullied at this point the game is more of a 4 bullies vs 1 innocent instead of 1 killer vs 4 survivors. Like who's the power role here now...

The latest announcement for PTB is what made me decide to leave this review, it seems like they dont want to listen and dont wanna do anything about the over abundance of pallets that they flooded the game with recently. Because, as long as survivors are happy who cares right? Even if the game ends up having 2 hour queues because no one wants to play killer, which will eventually cause it to die- well probably not coz it's DBD, but this is the reason other asyms have died.

So with all that I cannot in good conscience recommend this game in it's current state

Now as much as I enjoy this game, I feel I need first address the popular notion that it is hard to get into, that many killers (The players who chose to play as the monster.) try very hard to win and seem to have no concept of mercy, and many survivors have no idea what they are doing. These are all true... Kind of... Keep reading please.

For the first, it simply is. The game's rules are fairly simple on paper but internalizing them does take time and the ingame tutorial, while not garbage, isn't very well made.

For the second... Ya, some people do try very hard at the game. I am one such person... Most of us do, as you may think based on what happens, have +200 hours of having played which will make you feel like you will never catch up, and a few autistic wonderkins who seem to master the game with 20 hours and make you queston what you are even doing.

For the third, ya... You will at some point be pared up with someone who is playing for the first time, and they will you know... Not do so well at a new activity.

This is not to say the game is bad, as you can see I do recommend it, just that if those are things that get to you. That if you get frustrated when games tell you that you have failed, or you don't feel you have 10+ hours to spend learning what is going on, that I wouldn't recommend this game to you unless you view those aspects of yourself as personality flaws and plan to correct them though exposure therapy, in which case this game is to be filed in the medical expenses category of your budget... I know that sounds funny, but if you are that kind of person, feel that is a bad thing, and want to work on it, you could do a lot worse for $19.99(USD).

Anyway, for those not scared off by the prospect of the game's entry skill curve resembling a wall, let me assure you, while it is a wall, it's not like a full on city sky scraper. It's more like a fairly short one story house. You can't reach the top by just standing, but if you jump up real high, or get a friend to give you a boost you should be able to get your hands on the ledge and pull yourself up without too much dificulty, and the view from up on this wall of ours is... Well it's something. Not for everyone, but we like it.

As for what you do in the game?... You can see the trailer right? The description on the page? If that sounds fun to you then go ahead. Steam gives refunds if you have less than 2 hours of playtime and the tutorial only takes about 20 minutes. That should be enough time to play at least 3 or 4 matches, I suggest trying at least one each as survivor and killer, you may find you didn't like the side you thought you would... It's way more common than you would think.

... You want a turorial from me? You are free to DM me if you want, but this isn't the right place to post that I think... Check the community guides if you like. I may post one there later... You know... If you want.

This is a good example of a game that started out really good with a great concept and a challenging game mode for both killers and survivors. It used to require coordination, skill, critical thinking during a chase, and strategy with teammates to win. That is all past tense, now it's become a mode of overpowered and unbalanced perks that spoon feed survivors super human abilities that encourage toxic game play (from both killers and survivors) and takes all challenge and fun out of the game. Survivors spam stuns, hit negates, gen rushes, and near instant heals to troll killers and some of them even use speed hacks on top of it since so many other perks allow them to get away with it. Killers have to use scummy tactics like tunneling, three gen camping, and slugging just to have a chance to balance the playing field. It's gone from a creative survival hunt to an overpowered perk slug fest. Last few releases/updates have gutted this game beyond repair short of straight up removing those changes.

Dead by Daylight is not an easy or beginner-friendly game by any means. The biggest flaw? It desperately needs an updated tutorial and practice mode. New players have no way to rehearse basic skills like flashlight saves, flash bangs, loops, or facing specific killers. In custom matches, you can only fight bot survivors as killer‚Äînever the other way around.

I‚Äôve introduced this game to several friends; 90% quit within their first week. The learning curve is brutal and full of odd mechanics (like having to line up exactly 90¬∞ for a fast vault). After nearly a decade, the same issues remain‚Äîtunneling and slugging still dominate matches, making the solo experience miserable. Solo queue players are punished by design, since survivors can‚Äôt communicate beyond basic gestures (‚Äúcome here‚Äù or ‚Äúfollow me‚Äù).

The developers seem to prioritize new content over stability, balance, or beginner accessibility. The business cycle feels predictable: announce a new killer, generate hype, attract new buyers, they realize how unforgiving the game is‚Äîand then they leave.

A notable example I would like to point out is Dead by Daylight hasn‚Äôt been forced to evolve for nearly 10 years due to lack of major sustainable competition. Until Behaviour Interactive adds quality-of-life features that support new and solo players, I can‚Äôt recommend this game to anyone starting fresh.

Verdict: Great concept, deeply flawed execution. 6/10 for veterans, 2/10 for newcomers 

 [Overall]: Not recommended

at time of writing I cannot in good faith recommend Dead by Daylight (DbD) to anyone. 
this easily was one of my favorite games of all time, I loved the competitive players and the casual players, I loved the gameplay loop and the artistic direction, every thing about this game seemed amazing.
however after sinking a thousand plus hours into the game something is made very clear, this game is designed to get money out of the player base with very little care for the quality of the experience. If you ask any DbD player you will get many stories of how under cooked the game is, about how alienated the devs seem from the community, about how the game is so frustrating that even some devs are recommending not playing it. This all the while new chapters that players who have already paid for the game come out every 3 months, that massively throw off the balance to the point where not owning some of these chapters is outright harmful to your game experience. this as well as many other outstanding issues is why I have left the game, and why I cannot recommend it.

I will try to update this review if I feel that the game has entered a truly more healthy state. I loved Dead by Daylight, I hope I can again someday.

Don't play this if you want to play it for Survivor.  You aren't allowed to do anything skillful that might be inconvenient for the killer.  It's just Generator simulator and run the killer for more than 10 seconds.  You are also expected to act like a team but you can't be too coordinated because of course inconvenience is frowned upon.  The game balance is in a constant struggle of balance around premade groups against the killer...which is typically 10% of the playerbase.  The game just doesn't want you to be successful.  It just leads to more nerfs.

Game balance is just constant Survivor nerfs without much to look forward to because any buffs get reverted.  It's all about the Killer experience.

Every update killers are getting buffed while survivors face nerfs.  Even if survivor gets a buff it doesn't last long.  The newest thing for survivor got nerfed into useless within 2 weeks of release.

Survivor progression is terrible.  Everything is nerfed down hard.  You spend your points on useless stuff.   There isn't much incentive to strive for the highest grade every month.  Killers have certain addons to desire for their build but with survivor it's all trash.

Events are terrible--balanced to be typically killer having the advantage.  They aren't really eventful.  No one really participates in the event stuff.  And they are recycled year after year without any changes except balance.  It's an event mode but no one is really having fun.

If you are a survivor and go to the Forums to provide feedback/opinions you are going to get flamed.  It's like survivors can't have an opinion.  Someone is going to argue with you.  It's best to just post your opinion and don't even interact after that.  It's very likely nothing will be done with your feedback because it's coming from a survivor.  There seems to be more action that is beneficial to a killer.

TLDR: Just don't get this to play the Survivor role.

This game used to be fun. Or, rather, it used to be more fun than it currently is. 

My main issue is that the new killers developed are basically geared towards button masher players. Sure, you can play and get a ton of kills but there's no finesse, no skill involved. And the developers basically want it that way and have decided that instead of a game of skill and stealth in which both killers and survivors hone their abilities, it's now a game of chase. There's no impetus for killers to improve because they're already meeting their "goals" of killing. It's become increasingly frustrating for survivors because the pay out is less and less. 

Literally the only reason I play is because I have friends to play and commiserate with. Thank goodness they have 2v8 as a play style to shake things up a bit because now even the seasonal events are filled with try hard killers who only want a lower queue time and are completely unaware of the goals associated with said event and the developers seem to be phoning that in as well. 

With apologies to Mad Men, this is a game for sadists and masochists, and you know which one you are.

[h1]üî™ Dead by Daylight ‚Äì The Art of Fear and Survival[/h1]

Overall Rating: ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÜ

[h2]A Horror Playground That Never Sleeps[/h2]
Dead by Daylight, from Behaviour Interactive, has evolved far beyond its 2016 origins. What began as a modest asymmetrical horror game has become a vast ecosystem of killers, survivors, and licenses spanning the entire horror pantheon. It‚Äôs messy, unpredictable, and endlessly replayable‚Äîa digital haunted house that reinvents itself with every update.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Gameplay & Core Mechanics: ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÜ[/h2]
The 4v1 format remains brilliantly tense. Survivors repair generators while a lone killer stalks them, each side using unique perks and abilities to outthink the other. The learning curve can be brutal for newcomers, but once mastered, matches become thrilling mind games of bluffing, anticipation, and timing.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Atmosphere & Audio Design: ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ[/h2]
Dead by Daylight thrives on atmosphere. Each map tells its own story‚Äîfog-shrouded forests, derelict hospitals, and cursed swamps brought to life with chilling soundscapes. The heartbeat mechanic, signaling the killer‚Äôs proximity, remains one of the most effective audio cues in gaming‚Äîsimple, terrifying, and iconic.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Progression & Balance: ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÜ‚òÜ[/h2]
While the perk system and bloodweb progression keep players engaged, balance is a perpetual struggle. Some killers feel oppressive while others lag behind, and new survivors can feel underpowered without the right builds. Frequent patches and reworks show the devs‚Äô commitment, but equilibrium is always fleeting.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Visuals & Performance: ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÜ[/h2]
Graphical updates through the ‚ÄúRealm Beyond‚Äù project have revitalized older maps and characters with impressive detail and lighting. Performance is stable, though occasional frame drops and matchmaking bugs persist. Still, the visual fidelity now matches the game‚Äôs ambition.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Final Verdict[/h2]
[b]Dead by Daylight[/b] endures because it understands one thing: fear is more thrilling when it‚Äôs unpredictable. Despite occasional balancing woes, its constant evolution, crossovers, and passionate community make it a living horror anthology. Few games sustain this level of tension and creativity years after release.

[b]In short:[/b] a unique blend of strategy, suspense, and horror storytelling that rewards cunning over brute strength. Whether you prefer to hunt or to hide, Dead by Daylight offers endless nights of adrenaline and dread.

tl;dr Game's good, but too broken to play.
There's a lot to chastise this game for. The ever encroaching oversimplification of once robust systems. The community in a constant uproar and argument over fair and unfair tactics and powers. The select few sludge pits that still only communicate through slurs. The devs that have no idea what does well and what does bad in their game, because they simply do not play it. The grinding. The microtransactions. The lacks of polish.

But I can excuse it all. I can move past all that. If it weren't for the crashes and disconnects. I have not had a play session in MONTHS that didn't end with the game still running. Unreal will break. Servers will break. UAC will break. And kick you out of whatever you're doing and you have nothing to show for it.

I absolutely love this game. I've always been a fan of hide and seek games like Prop Hunt, and this scratches that itch. I've always loved horror as a genre and have been a big fan of the walking nightmares that can't be stopped, and this game lets you feel it. I love big crossovers: even when they get kinda outta control like Fortnite or Magic: The Gathering. I love the gameplay loop, I love experimenting with powers and perks, I love being a goofball with the survivors, I love playing a little guitar for the killers. It's so much fun.

When I actually get to play it.

"Would you recommend this game to other players?"

The real answer is "Sort of, I don't know, maybe."

[h1] The Good Things [/h1]
- The actual gameplay loop can be fun enough, but it really depends on whether you queue up with other people who want to have fun.
- Active support and events from the development team means you usually have a reason to hop back online.
- Many of the perks lend to player-tailored experiences. Whatever your playstyle is, you can build something at least somewhat enjoyable.

[h1] The Bad Things [/h1]
- The monetization practices in this game are insane. While the initial cost to play is low, it is easy to spend hundreds of dollars on new characters and cosmetics. There are costumes that cost more than the characters who wear them.
- The gameplay is incredibly difficult to balance, and as a result there are often long stretches where it isn't fun to boot up. You have to just sort of wait until the next patch comes out.
- There's a high amount of tired, real-world propaganda in this game. If you know you know. 

[h1] The In-The-Middle Things [/h1]
- There is a lot of lore for the characters in-game, but it is buried in text that even after 1,500 hours I haven't been bothered to read.
- There are plenty of achievements to hunt, but you'll never really 100% the game because the devs keep adding new achievements with every new expansion.
- Many players are frustrating or exploitative. There's an in-game reporting system that works alright, but it doesn't fully deter bad actors.


[h1] General Thoughts [/h1]

It can be fun with friends. You can have good or bad days here, and you have to be mindful of your wallet. It's a great collection of horror icons. Worth trying out, but Dead By Daylight has its reputation for a reason.
good

An unbalanced game that keeps getting worse. The devs really only care about the survivor experience. If you got this game because you wanted to play as your favorite horror characters, then good luck doing that while you try to micromanage four survivors on comms who could have any combination of over 150 perks, some of which completely disrupt regular gameplay. 

Recent dev action shows more and more bias, poor decision making, and the inability to look at core causes for problems. 

Seriously, this game isn't in a great state and continues to go down a poor path. Unless the devs figure out what they are doing, do not waste your money on this game, even on sale.

Its hard to put into words why exactly I like playing DBD. I have as many frustrations with this game as the vast and colourful community does; ranging from Behaviour's decision making, the balance issues, and the technical problems that still plague the game on a regular basis. The game is still, like many people like to point out, like an abusive relationship. It hurts, but I cannot stop being around it.

 However, I cannot bring myself to stop playing DBD, and its for one core aspect that I don't think gets highlighted often enough: the singular universe crossover of all these fantastic horror (and semi-horror) IPs and different avenues of horror from Behaviour's own creative lens. If I told any DBD fan back in 2016 when the game first came out that nine years later you'd be playing as Leon Kennedy from Resident Evil being chased by Michael Myers, one of the most iconic slashers of all time, in the Gideon Meat Plant from Saw, I'd think they'd have me institutionalized. Its moments like these where I can just admire the beauty behind the bugs, that I can forget getting tunneled or four outed and just appreciate what is in front of me. Now this goes without saying, but I'd still like the game to be fixed and properly balanced (Behaviour plz).

If you are reading this review wanting to know if DBD is a game for you, I'd say yes, provided that you don't mind getting your butt smacked around often, because the game, as it stands nearly a decade later, I'd argue, is a must play for any fan or enjoyer of horror media.

I got this game in the spirit of the spooky season and Halloween, I loved the concept. It seemed like Super Mario Smash Brothers with horror characters, or a deranged version of Hide and Seek with Survivors vs. Killers- either way, I was curious and I was into it. Because I personally don't like jump scares, I was eager to be a Killer.

Now, not so much. This game has a learning curve and for me it's a little steep. I lost an hour on the Survivor tutorial simply because the instructions weren't clear. The Killer's tutorial was fine. Great, I jumped into live gameplay.

As a Killer, I hate the first-person POV Killers are limited to. I can only see so much, and when chasing after Survivors it's so easy to lose sight/track of them. Maybe there's certain powers/perks to help with that?? I don't know. There's so much to try to understand and learn in this game. Survivors can duck and crouch in order to hide, but Killers can't crouch low and do sneak attacks. So as a Killer I'm basically standing out in the open, trying to go after 4 other players- and, 4 against 1? Really?? I'm new, so, OOooOkay..... I try my best and I honestly feel like a lost, wandering villain trying to catch tadpoles. And if, IF I am able to catch a Survivor, they don't die right away (lol I know that sounds bad)- but what I mean is, they have to be hooked multiple times to get sacrificed. And that's another thing that adds complexity to the game- the multi-steps. There are multiple steps to kill a Survivor, to fix a generator (when playing as Survivor), the gates seemingly take forever to open at the end of the game. Just...lol, come on.

I have no idea how a Killer's "power move" actually works because it's not in the Tutorial, nor any other abilities- and my frustration for lack of information is definitely aimed at the developers. On top of that, I haven't found a way to practice as any character of my choosing. In the Tutorials you play as the same character. Sigh. Which means I have to watch YouTube videos and study on gameplay mechanics, learn more about Killers, try to learn learn learn.

And for what??? When I get back in the game, it's still a challenge and not really fun. I'm not against learning new things, but I do care about the ROI (return of investment) on my time- and for this game, considering the amount of time I try to learn how to play it vs the experience in playing it, for me it's not worth it.

I have read comments and reviews about negative interactions in the community and I haven't experienced that. But then again, I'm a Killer who hasn't caught or killed anyone yet, so what would Survivors in those games have to complain about?

The concept of the game is fun, but the actual gameplay is a little too challenging (and tedious) for me right now to truly enjoy it. I don't recommend it as a new player, but I'm sure other people may like it.

Unfortunately over the past year or so, the bias of the developers has been on full view. 

They've been nerfing killer options over and over. Limiting the amount of times killers can kick generators, nerfing kicking and regression perks, nerfing killers ONLY anti-item option and not giving any real meaningful replacements.

Then on top of changes like that buffing healing perks that nerfed before for being unhealthy, but this time sticking it around. From what I've picked up, the current healing meta is stronger than circle of healing and its possible to heal under hook in under 2.5 seconds, making health states meaningless and offering no pressure for the killer.

Then considering a huge buff like adding a significant portion more pallets simply a "quality of life update," while also planning to make big changes that continue to buff survivors and offering almost nothing to killers with the suggested upcoming changes in the current PTB. This company has no idea what balance for their game looks like and asks only survivor sided questions in surveys and then act like killers have no complaints. Its insane. One of the singular most incompetent and disconnected dev teams I've seen in my life, even during their own live stream they don't know why killers slug so much in a match, they're confused. The ENTIRE twitch chat screamed pallets at them and their response was "I'm glad they like the new pallets," instead of understanding they were the problem.

Spend your time with a game where the devs might actually understand the game. I don't have much faith in the future of Dead by Daylight's balancing.

Hello Human, here are some notes to help you on your journey of the DEAD BY DAYLIGHT experience:

- Lots of crossovers, allowing you to play as cool characters from many horror universes

- Game naturally creates chaotic scenarios with all the combinations of perks and addons in play (sometimes for good, sometimes for ill)

- Heavy DLC policy, requiring you to purchase characters. Not as important on the survivor side (since the survivors are essentially cosmetic changes), but on the killer side you are much more limited since they have unique powers you are missing out on. Not as expensive as other games with this same model but still not great practice

- Very poor progression, takes a long time to unlock people. Bloodpoints and Bloodweb system is basically just a waste of time that pulls you out of just playing the game (different currency then the one you use to get characters). Get stuck in scenarios where you want to play a character for their abilities/looks but also want to get other characters just for their associated perks. Further made worse by shrine of secrets being very unforgiving (can't just buy perks, need to get them for a high price from a random weekly rotation of 4/200+ perks) and uses the same currency (Iridescent shards) to buy characters, further complicating the process.

- Game controls are not bad but are strange sometimes (they try to keep it only 2 buttons no matter the cost, even if it means creating these weird cycle mode abilities rather then just have it be 3 separate buttons) (seems to be done to simplify controller, at the expense of keyboard). Not a terribly degrading thing just a bit weird to get used to.

- Quite buggy, some characters are in weird broken states for extended periods of time. For instance, one character named the houndmaster has a dog that follows them. There is about a 10%? chance that using your ability to send the dog out just does nothing, this bug has existed for a very long time considering how impactful it is.

- Design wise is in this weird limbo state where it isn't optimal for either causal nor competitive ways of playing. A good example of this is with map design. Many maps are slightly unoptimal to play more competitively since the RNG makes them not always spawn the same, preventing 100% optimization for cool map-knowledge plays. On the other hand, the way that the RNG is implemented is not very interesting (mostly a reshuffling of generic tiles) so casually it feels essentially like the same map. This basically causes a local minima where neither side is completely satisfied. This philosophy extends onto character design, perk design, and base kit design with particular playstyles.

- Adding onto design philosophy, it is also counter-intuitive and punishing in strange ways. On survivor, you have no ability to see your teammates, see your teammates' perks, or communicate to them via text or voice chat in game. This creates a very large disparity between coordinated teams using discord versus uncoordinated teams, further exacerbated by the difference between coordinated perk and add-on usage versus uncoordinated. The game is obscuring information preventing you from working with your team in the team-based game. On killer, the most logical way to win a 1v4 scenario is to remove one person from the equation as fast as possible (known as tunneling) so that it simplifies the game-state in your favor. It makes then the most sense that on survivor that you need to spread out damage across your team so that no one dies too early. The way that it is currently implemented is in such a manner where tunneling isn't really fun to do or go against, but is also in a state where the game is sort of balanced around it. You are punished for killing in the killing game as a killer. It's not impossible for the game to be fun on both sides while balancing around tunneling being the norm (Identity V does this quite well), and I don't believe that it is impossible to have a scenario where tunneling is one of multiple strategies that exist, but the way DBD handles it again puts it in a local minima where neither side really has as much fun doing it as alternative playstyles (if they win in a scenario where they spread out hooks, it doesn't offer them any unique advantage and is not as decisive of a victory as if they just tunneled), but there is some game scenarios where there isn't really an alternative other than just lose immediately. TLDR, there exists aspects of the game that are punishing and not clear, some of which create a circumstance where the path to victory is not congruent with the most fun way of playing.

- Development time on these aforementioned problems as well as just balance changes in general is very slow. Some changes that one would think would be a easy net positive QOL can take years to implement for not very clear reasons. 

Overall, this game has very good potential, but is stunted from questionable design decisions and progression. It is enjoyable on occasion, but you basically need to completely dissassociate from 1. Winning/Losing  2.  Progression and 3. Bugs (just laugh at them),  in order to have consistent fun. As you can see I have followed this game for a while, so I had a lot to say about it (I have about +100 hours not on this account), and can say that my Disassociation Techinque is one of the most effective techniques in all of gaming, perfectly employable in this specific scenario to be used to the upmost advantage. Good luck out their in the fog soldier, or just play Identity V which is free and is advantaged in almost all areas except graphics and horror icon crossovers.

I used to reccomend this game but its just not fun anymore. As a killer player i feel that the devs are just against me.

I have 223 hours on steam, i have around 450 on other platforms.

So given I have so many hours how can i not reccomend this game? well its because the game keeps changing to be less and less fun. Less and less of what it use to be, its no longer 1 killer trying to kill 4 survivors its just 4 survivors bullying the killer, the only way to get around this is to play 'meta' killers but after 250 hours of nurse i needed some variety so i tried others and boy is the game shit when you aren't meta.  The rest of this is just a rand on the amount of BS the devs added to create this problem.
 
If as killer you pick up a survivor other survivors have 5 or 6 different ways to make you drop them. The survivor them self has 4 ways to make you drop them. 
If you hook someone and they get off the hook they block for a teammate because they have off the record for around a minute of endurance, you get past that and now they have decisive strike, you get past that and its rolling to see if they can get one of the 7 ways to get saved again. The devs said this was all to stop anti tunnelling. The devs solution for the killers using one of the primary win cons of the game was to give the survivors tools to punish the killer for playing the damn game. As the killer the solution then became to just leave people on the ground, you cant pick up so you have to leave them bleed out and apply pressure to the rest of the survivor team.
Then the devs added a ton of anti slugging perks, so if a survivor is left on the ground they can pick themselves up an infinite amount of times, they have insane bleed out timers now, and the devs tried to make this base kit but there was backlash because its stupid, so they made it all part of perks instead. Some of these perks have conditions that pretty much only mean they take effect if the survivors are 4 qued or if they are against a weaker killer who has to use totems.
So the solution was to wait out the perks that puinish picking up but picking them up before they can pick themselves up, so the devs made perks that make it where they make it where if you pick them up after leaving them for a bit they can knock themselves off your shoulder quicker and other BS.
So as a killer you are punished for picking up immediately, punished for leaving them on the ground and punished for waiting and then picking them up, at this point i feel like im getting punished just for trying to play this stupid game yet alone trying to enjoy it.
Gens have been made quicker, the 80s slasher film aesthetic was removed ages ago, There is builds that make the survivors faster than the killer because they added in haste stacking.
That wasnt enough though the survivors needed more so they upped the pallet count on every map to around 20 and then they made all of the pallets stronger, theres far less "unsafe filler pallets" they are all safe pallets god forbid survivors learn how to look properly or play the game, instead they give them enough pallets that they can never run dry. Survivors dont even need to think, they just need 3 on gens while one person runs pallet to pallet across the map, if you dont have a chase abillity they are all safe pallets so you cant really outplay them, so you have to break and with the number of pallets you will run out of time and lose, dropping chase to go after somone else just moves the problem along and doesnt solve it.

1. They have stripped almost any form of hiding/evasion out of the game via perks and the game has turn into just running in circles.
2. New killers are egregiously balanced. (Looking at you ghoul.)
3. I couldn't try and unhook myself with my whole team downed to try and save the game.
4. It feels like there is very little decision making game play in this game now. Just get on generator and stay on generator until you get chased. Hope whoever gets chased first is good at running in circles. Rinse and repeat.

Been playing this game on and off since 2016 back when their was only 3-4 killers in the game. Now their is currently 41 killers at the time of writing this review. Crazy to see where it's at now, the evolution, and how players have adapted to playing the game over the years with many different perk builds and strategy's to win. I'd describe DBD as pretty chill and casual whilst also being simultaneously competitive and sweaty lol. 

A large variety of maps and killers that keep the gameplay fresh and every match playing out differently depending on the killer and perk builds at play. Lots of recognizable licensed characters included in the game and cool original killer designs that're unique and fun to play as. Many different events and content to explore and learn. (And bugs... AKA "Features!")

Whether you wanna play Killer or Survivor... As a new player, you're gonna struggle and lose a bunch in the beginning but that's how you start learning how to play and improving at the game, it takes a couple hours to start getting it and putting the pieces together, both roles have a bit of a learning curve when you first start out. 

I personally enjoy playing as both Killer and Survivor, some players choose to main one or the other... And also complain/whine about the other side being too "Strong" or "OP" lol. 

As a wise man once said... "Skill Issue!" 

Objectively it's pretty straight forward to learn the basics of the game but hard to master it as your more than likely to play against experienced players that know the maps and all the perks inside and out. But I genuinely wouldn't let that stop you from trying it out, their is plenty of fun and goofy moments to be had!

Once you start understanding and getting good at looping on survivor or utilizing a killer's power to it's full potential, the game starts to get pretty fun, enjoyable, and addicting. Out mindgaming an opposing player or looping the killer around the whole map without getting downed during a chase is super satisfying.

Yes, the community can be toxic and angry at times, but what franchise or multiplayer game title isn't nowadays?  

I recommend picking the game up when it's on sale, it goes on sale pretty often. I think it's worth checking out if you're a fan of horror or looking for a different type of multiplayer experience to try out.
