I haven‚Äôt been playing Dead by Daylight for long, but man it hooked me fast. Every match is pure chaos in the best way. One second you‚Äôre fixing a gen trying to stay calm, the next you‚Äôre being chased across the map. It‚Äôs stressful, funny, and insanely fun all at once.

The game balances fear and excitement perfectly. Playing Survivor feels tense and strategic hiding, looping, pulling off clutch saves  while playing Killer makes you feel like a total monster when you outsmart everyone. Each Killer‚Äôs power changes how the match plays out, so it never gets boring.

The amount of content is wild too. There are tons of original characters plus collabs with Resident Evil, Silent Hill, Stranger Things, and more. The devs clearly care  they keep adding new stuff and reworking old content to keep it fresh.

Sure, matchmaking and balance can be a bit hit or miss, but when a game clicks, it‚Äôs pure adrenaline. That moment when you barely make it through the exit gate or land a perfect 4K as Killer? Unreal.

If you like horror, tension, and multiplayer chaos, Dead by Daylight is 100% worth trying  even if you‚Äôre new like me.

üî™ ‚ÄúDead by Daylight‚Äù ‚Äî A Country Boy‚Äôs Guide to Screamin‚Äô in the Dark

Now I done played a lotta games in my day, but Dead by Daylight? That one‚Äôll raise your blood pressure faster than a possum in a henhouse.
It‚Äôs a game where four poor souls try to fix some broke-down generators while one mean ol‚Äô killer hunts ‚Äôem like a coon on a Saturday night.

It ain‚Äôt fair.
It ain‚Äôt peaceful.
And Lord help me, I keep playin‚Äô it anyway.

üå≤ The Setup

You got two sides:

Survivors ‚Äî four of y‚Äôall runnin‚Äô around like chickens with your heads cut off, fixin‚Äô engines and hopin‚Äô you don‚Äôt get grabbed.

The Killer ‚Äî one nasty son of a gun with a big weapon, spooky music, and a hobby for collectin‚Äô screams.

Simple as cornbread, but every match feels like a new brand of chaos.

‚öôÔ∏è What Keeps Folks Comin‚Äô Back

1. The thrill, boy, the thrill.
Ain‚Äôt nothin‚Äô quite like hearin‚Äô that terror radius thumpin‚Äô while you crouch in the bushes whisperin‚Äô, ‚ÄúPlease don‚Äôt see me, please don‚Äôt see me.‚Äù Then BOOM ‚Äî the killer shows up, and you start runnin‚Äô like you just saw your ex at Walmart.

2. The teamwork.
You can‚Äôt make it out alone. You gotta help your buddies off hooks, patch up their boo-boos, and yell when the killer‚Äôs comin‚Äô.
Course, sometimes your ‚Äúteammates‚Äù run off and hide behind a tree while you‚Äôre screamin‚Äô on a hook ‚Äî but that‚Äôs just DBD life.

3. The killers are wild.
They got everything from creepy nurses and chainsaw maniacs to Wesker himself from Resident Evil. Each one‚Äôs got their own tricks, and learnin‚Äô ‚Äôem all‚Äôs half the fun (and half the trauma).

4. Customizin‚Äô your survivor.
You can dress up your character any way you want ‚Äî cowboy hat, bunny suit, Christmas sweater ‚Äî lookin‚Äô good don‚Äôt save you, but it sure feels nice dyin‚Äô in style.

ü™ì What‚Äôll Grind Your Gears

Now I ain‚Äôt gonna lie ‚Äî Dead by Daylight ain‚Äôt perfect.

The matchmaking‚Äôs rougher than gravel. Sometimes you get killers so sweaty they must‚Äôve been born with a mouse and keyboard in their hands.

Bugs and lag. Ever vault a window and get hit through it anyway? Yeah, happens more often than a deer in the headlights.

Toxic players. Some folks teabag at the exit gates like they just won the lottery. Bless their little hearts.

And don‚Äôt even get me started on them flashlight heroes ‚Äî blindin‚Äô you mid-chase like they‚Äôre takin‚Äô senior portraits.

üî• Verdict from the Porch

If I had to sum it up:
Dead by Daylight is a beautiful, broken, nerve-wrackin‚Äô mess ‚Äî and I love it to death.

It‚Äôll make you laugh, it‚Äôll make you rage, and sometimes it‚Äôll make you sit in silence questionin‚Äô your life choices. But every round‚Äôs got that special mix of terror and fun that keeps you comin‚Äô back for ‚Äújust one more game.‚Äù

‚≠ê Rating: 8/10 bloody hooks
üí¨ ‚ÄúLike hide-and-seek, if hide-and-seek involved trauma, teamwork, and bad internet.‚Äù

üß¢ Final Words

If you‚Äôre lookin‚Äô for a scary good time with friends, or you just enjoy chasin‚Äô folks through the woods with a machete (virtually, of course), Dead by Daylight hits the spot.

Just remember ‚Äî when you hear that heartbeat, don‚Äôt look back.

In short, Dead By Daylight is a very fun and addicting game with a well known toxic community.

Though I have not experienced much toxicity during my playtime apart from a few harsh complaints every ten matches or so. There is much to love about this game if you can just focus on the fun. Plenty of killers to pick from, either from your favorite slasher films or completely original killers. My favorite is the cowboy with a harpoon gun, who has a very simple but fun hook-based gameplay. And of course Dracula himself because he looks awesome and I love the Castlevania games. If you are not a competitive person, that being someone who is not focused on winning with the best killer/survivor with the best builds and play purely for your own enjoyment out of either saving your teammates and being scared of and seeking to out smart/manoeuvre the killer or being the killer themself and enjoy the tracking/chasing element, I absolutely recommend to get this game. I may just be lucky but if you are doubtful to get this game because of its community, I've had more wholesome matches and encounters than I have had with the games well known flashlight bullies and very harsh post game commenters. At the end of the day, it's just a game that you have your right to play how you wish, be it a scummy playstyle or not. 

In conclusion from my experiences, ignore the tier lists and the many harsh videos you may see, this game has plenty of love put into it and the community is very large. Play for your own fun, be it losing or winning, as long as you enjoy the many moments in that one match and play how you want to play, I believe you could love this game too.  Hopefully the Pinhead killer will come back with the new Hellraiser game coming out, cause i missed my chance to get him and he looked quite fun.

So, I think I like the game? I think it's good for fun with friends and to hunt down some survivors.... With that said, this game absolutely SUCKS as a new player. The community is pretty toxic to start, but that can be ignored. What really holds me back as a new player is this damn Perk / Bloodweb system. 

I get this crippling indecision when it comes to what killer/survivor I start with or choose and where I should spend my blood tokens. In the early levels, Killers/Survivors with out a decent build kind of suck.... so you're never quite sure if that's how they play, or if you just haven't put ENOUGH blood tokens in. Now the game gives them to you frequently, and I feel like it's something I can get over, but the new player systems in this game are atrocious. 

Outside of the that, the griefing from players is WILD. These people are rude, they hate when you play the killer well, and they hate when you aren't the best either. They will make your games miserable and the match making will make damn sure to put you in groups with folks who are way above your capabilities. 

With all that negative said, the gameplay loop is fun, the Killers are really fun and unique, when you're not in a totally mean game... It's a much better experience with friends.

This game is genuinely the worst that humanity has to offer. The game itself is a laggy, buggy mess, that breaks every two patches if you are lucky. Half the killer roaster experiences huge bugs with game breaking messes being left in the game for months at a time. Developers do not care about you and your experience as a killer as they nerf every viable strategy and have tried to fix base mechanics to prevent you from playing competitively, instead of promoting other ways of play. Meanwhile survivors don't get touched for years and by Behaviour Data Samples they are the victims. Said researched data is collected in nonsensical ways suchs as the little form some players get when uninstalling, where complaining about killer balance is a selectable option....but survivor balance isn't. This on top of a game engine on 15 years on a game that's been developed to be a small project at best, every little bug fix creating game breaking scenarios like cutting off a hydra's head. And of course unnanounced changes such as a recent patch placing around 30% more pallets on most maps....because? We've not had a good explanation as of yet. Balancing Core gameplay mechanics has been rough for them recently as they've given survivors 3-4 major core gameplay buffs and have given killers 700 bloodpoints in return. This is not a valuable currency and not even enough to buy a single small item (of which you need thousants). And then you have the cheating problems with even average players experiencing cheating on weekly basis and streamers being attacked. Biggest recent attack being on the DEVELOPER STREAMS being shut down mid promotional stream, because their private server got hacked. It's insane the amount of neglect this game is receiving. In their "Quality of LIfe" era, an year long break from constant content, in which they promised to try to fix many of the issues this game has, they released MORE content and every update has broken the game even more. The Houndmaster has released and still is a buggy mess, The Walking Dead update made the game physically unplayble breaking core mechanics for more than a week, half the killer roaster is unplayable against semi competent survivor teams, and their attempts to rework an old bad killer have resulted in making them WORSE?!?. The community is a 50/50 of people that genuinely care about the game with amazing content creators and community cultivators and then you have the sc*m of the earth loggin in only to make your afterwork hours unplayable, and take a moral highground in post game chat calling you a tunneler, unskilled killer, you deserved it, you play x, you play y, you camp etc. They will find a reason to blame you even if your only form of tunneling is hooking someone twice in a role in a 12 hook game. Being into the core idea and artstyle of this game has been a STRUGGLE for me with a bunch of hours on epic games instead of this platform. Those are ONLY recent issues and the list can go on and on. This game is on borrowed time until the developers eat themselfs like an ouroboros. They don't care about retaining players they just want your money for the hype dlc so they can fund the next one. This could have been a passion project if anyone on Behaviour cares. The bug report goes directly into their bin aswell as the reported cheaters we've had in our games. Mind you Twins is 5 years old killer and still has gamebreaking bugs with new ones with every patch. On top of everything in their most recent dev blog they blamed 40+ % of killers of tunneling in their games without explaining how they got to that conclussion, which has lead to survivor side using their statement to harrass killer players even more. They also couldn't explain to themselves how on the map "The Game', the most pallet filled map there is, slugging is a more popular strategy. Instead of Embracing Slugging and Tunneling as viable SITUATIONAL options and rewarding you for not always doing them, they wholeheartedly try to remove them. With no such limitations even being suggested towards the survivor side. 

This was all without the new player progression and the crazy monetization and hours needed to farm a character without reaching for your wallet. I was lucky I got the game for free. Paying a crisp 20 for 4ish characters out of 50 is insane and asking players to spend 40+ hours for each one they are missing is even crazier. 

This was a long messy rant but I wanted to put it out there. Every so often they hype me up with a new release I get on and quickly realise that the game is even more PHYSICALLY unplayable than before. Unless they change the code of the game from ground up, and try to listen to their community (Killers uncluded) this game will slowly fade away into irrelevance as it's already doing. I love the concept of this game but that's all I can say so deep into the rabithole. DO NOT SUPPORT THIS COMPANY and it's unholy patch launches. I've seen 10 man studios release more stable products with better quality. The care and love is missing.

Okay, I have joined this game in late 2025 (yes, very late, I'm well aware), but I really want to give my honest thoughts on this game, its community, and overall how I feel after spending the past 2/3 months playing. 


The Good:
[b]- The Community:[/b] I've never played a game were overall, majority of the community are such a decent group of humans. I will also say, as someone LGBTKFCBLT, I greatly appreciate the range of diversity in the player base. Its so warming to see so many pride banners/charms in end game screens and I love being able to go to peoples Twitch streams to friendly banter about the fun game we just played. Yeah, there's a few bad eggs here and there, but go play Overwatch, or (heaven forbid) Valo/League for a day. I promise you this game is nothing like that. I feel very grateful to have only been playing a few months and already built strong friendships. 

[b]- Gameplay:[/b] DBD has found a sweet spot in a genre no other game has been able to even come close to. A asymmetrical horror game which not only feels rewarding to play in both roles but gives you drive to continue to play more. I can't stand the amount of stuff I've seen online about how certain killers are broken or certain perks are horrible to play against. This game has hundreds of things its trying to manage and honestly, I feel like it does a pretty good job! 


The Bad:
[b]- Onboarding experience and early gameplay: [/b] DBD is by far one of the hardest games I have ever had to learn to play in my life. The game does a terrible job at explaining certain nuances the game has such as item usage, displays (like girl, wtf are these icons on the right hand of my screen? I still don't know!), perks, and offerings. Swear I didn't use an offering for the first 100 hours of playing. I fear that this is not just a me issue. Not to mention the amount of killers and survivors in this game makes picking it up at such a late stage to be a very difficult process. You could argue that learning curve is part of the fun, sure! But in 2025 were everyone has a -5 attention span, people need to get into the game and get into it fast a feel like they know what they are doing. 

[b]- Match making:[/b] Christ all mighty. Why am I going against people who have THOUSANDS of hours in this game when I literally just started playing? It loops back to the first point where I have no idea how I'm suppose to learn the game when I'm consistently going against people who live and breath this game. 


The Ugly:
[b]- Your hatred for Behaviour as developers: [/b] Look I'm going to be so real. You (YES YOU), do not understand how good you have it. I get it, you may have played for years, what would little pleb me know, but in the short few months I've played this game, I've seen devs who listen, act and amend errors faster than any other live service game I've played. I'm honestly in awe of how they do it with consist bug updates, regular new content, and gameplay that feels fresh and new. It's YOU who has to whinge and whine about how bad you have it. I fear this is just an issue that will never be resolved for a game that is as old as it is. It's giving very 'bitter old man who didn't get his way' but you've been wined and dined for years on end. 


I hope this is helpful for at least someone. I feel this has to be one of the most rewarding games I've ever played and I hope to continue spending my time playing such an amazing game with (mostly) an amazing community. ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•.

P.S. Fix Houndmaster please, that shit is pissin' me off fr.

This is the first game I've ever bought on Steam, and I loved it. I got into the game by watching people like No0b3 and Otzdarva play it all the time when I was younger, and for the collaborations they did with horror icons. I always played killer since I didn't have friends to play survivor with, but I eventually learned to play both at some point. However, I would be lying if I said I enjoyed playing it anymore. 

I don't know if it's the fact that I'm getting older, that I've played more games I enjoy, or if it's the game itself that has changed, but every time I come back to play, there's always something that makes me step away from the game for a while. Whether it's an adjustment to perks making them more broken or useless, bugs and hackers, new mechanics, or even just toxic players, I just can't find a reason to stick around after getting back into the game.

This game is notorious for being an unbalanced mess and having a toxic community. I haven't encountered many toxic people in the game since around 2019, when I started, but I've seen so many toxic people outside the game that it absolutely makes me hate playing. I cannot recommend playing the game at all in its current state. Playing as the survivor or killer is miserable in their own way, and I have played against more hackers than I ever have during the rest of the time I have played this game.

I think you could also argue this game is pay to win in a way, I don't know if I would call it exactly that, but there's definitely a huge advantage you get from buying certain licensed DLC either for the perks or the killer themselves, but I think using them effectively still requires skill although that still doesn't change how unfair killers can be sometimes as much as I love playing them.

Playing survivor is fun and simple for the most part, especially if you're playing with friends or in a group. But I do think there are some problems that you face when playing against certain killers that just aren't fun to play against.

And playing as killer is horrendous. I love playing killer, but it feels like there's a set list of rules you have to follow, or else survivors will just complain about how you played. On top of that, you have to deal with bully squads that just make the whole game about harassing you. I enjoy friendly survivors, but getting them every other match can be annoying. Sometimes I just want to play the game, and then I'm the one at fault when I kill them because they didn't want to play a normal match.

I want this game to do well, but every year I feel like it just gets worse and worse. The only thing keeping it alive for me now is the collaborations they do, but even that is starting to not feel like enough anymore. In its current state, I just can't recommend it to anyone looking to buy it.

I wish I could delete this game and move on, but I can't without some form of closing remarks. Its like watching a old friend relapse on repeat, begging for a second chance it never earned. 

I swapped to PC recently, so it only shows 150sh hours of playtime, but I have thousands of hours sunk into this game on console from ever since it was released on console years back. 

This game is not worth your time. Its not worth your cash, its not worth your creative talents, like fan-art or anything of that nature. I'd argue its not even worth your pity. Dead by daylight is a game that took over the 4v1 genre by that of sheer luck and the introduction of constant updates. Nothing more, and I will not accept otherwise. If evolve managed to not be owned by 2k, it would still be around. If DBD didn't get a new killer from a horror movie fans already like every two months, other games would have stuck around.

So, being a titan only supported by the fact other games cannot keep up or are dead on arrival because DBD fans would rather eat their own vomit than attempt to try a new game, they crumble, and DBD is once again free to abuse its player-base without failure. 

These people think you are a moron. They ignore issues the community has, famously, until their primary spokesperson plays a game on stream (after being bullied into it) to be repeatedly shown directly what the community had been begging for a change since its inception. Only then did it change. 

They do not care about you, they never have. They do not care for the hundreds of bugs that plague this game, they never have. They do not care what state the game is in, they never have. 

They don't have to. They never have. 

If you want a horror game that's worth it, look into more indie projects, or co-op horror such as the outlast trials, or hell, play physically any other game that isn't DBD. The devs do not care for you. 

And the fan-base? I have never met a more moronic group of vomit chugging idiots in my life. This game is dominated by wanna be twitch streamers (always offline, btw) that endlessly want to farm clips and punch below the belt with bug abuse or "techs" because the devs, shockingly, do not care. Few in this community deserve it, such as Otz and Henz, but lets be real, people watch them for their own personalities, not this clusterfuck of a game. 

Anway, nerf the pig or something, idk.

Dead by Daylight is a great multiplayer game for players of all skill levels. Its easy to learn, and as you play you get better by learning strategy and utilizing perks. You can play as a killer, or as a survivor. There are tons of killers and survivors to choose from, each with their own unique perks. It's great for any horror fan. 

The only negative that is worth mentioning is that the game can feel very killer-sided. This means it feels like the game is in favor of the killer. Can be quite difficult to win as a survivor against certain overpowered killers. If they fix this in the future, it would make the game a better experience.

This game is digital adrenaline.

One moment you're stealthily fixing a generator, the next you're in a full-blown panic sprint as a chainsaw-wielding maniac chases you through a cornfield.

Whether you want to be the one running for your life or the one causing the panic, this game has you covered. It's stressful, it's janky at times, but it's incredibly fun and there's nothing else like it.

Pro Tip: It's 10x more fun (and chaotic) with friends.

This game is not going to survive another year. The developers just had a livestream where they announced that for the third major time they are attempting to stop "camping", "tunneling", and "slugging" by buffing survivors to an insane degree. They have proven time and time again that they don't play their game, are survivor sided, or are listening so hard to their data that they forget that there are 4 more survivors in the game than killers. While Dead by Daylight the game might survive for a year, in a year from now, if the devs balance in the way that they said they wanted to, this game is going to only get worse and worse for killer players. If you're a survivor player the game could be good to play if you can handle increasingly long queue times as people leave the role and increasingly hardcore killers to go up against as the few people remaining play stronger and smarter. I used to love Dead by Daylight, but unfortunately, this game is at the end of its life and I can't do it anymore.

PS: To add on, the devs are currently in an emergency health update for their health update because of how many bugs have gotten in and how little they actually do to fix said bugs.

Do I recommend this game? If you only want to play killer, no lol. If you just want a game to dick around with friends and don't really take seriously? Maybe. The game will be 10 years old next year though and it really feels like it could maybe do better then it is at the moment though.

If you are thinking about starting up this game for the first time my advice would be don't do it. There are bugs galore in the code, Ping issues that cause headaches for both survivors and killers, a rather toxic community, and the new player experience is terrible. The tutorials are bad and there are about twenty bits of knowledge which are considered need to know to play at a basic level that aren't covered or even mentioned in said tutorials. Then once you've got a handle on the basics there are all the perks (both survivor and killer), add-ons, and killer powers that you need to learn in order to use them properly or to counter when playing against them. 

While getting up to speed you'll end up tunneled and slugged as someone in serious need of therapy humps your body as a newbie survivor or bullied with sabotage toolboxes and flashlights and t-bagged at the exit gate as a newbie killer. If you still persist be prepared for most of your friends to rage quit the game at some point and to be constantly disappointed at the devs inability to achieve any sort of balance in gameplay. Solo Queue for survivor is the seventh circle of hell, updates to counter certain OP killers turn other killers into a sad joke, and many of the most useful perks are locked on characters that require cash or in-game grinding to unlock. But Sable got a new $9 outfit so apparently all is right with the world.

When I first started playing Dead by Daylight, I genuinely thought I‚Äôd found one of the most exciting multiplayer horror games ever made. The first 100 hours or so were a blast, running from killers with friends, pulling off clutch saves, and feeling that rush of tension as the exit gates opened. But once your MMR starts to climb, that fun quickly evaporates. The game goes from thrilling to downright miserable, and it‚Äôs honestly shocking how steep the falloff in enjoyment is.

At higher MMR, the game feels completely unbalanced. Killers suddenly move faster, hit from ridiculous distances, and seem to have a supernatural ability to track you no matter what. The supposed ‚Äúskill based‚Äù matchmaking doesn‚Äôt really feel like it takes into account teamwork or playstyle; you just get thrown against sweaty killers with pinpoint accuracy and map knowledge that make most matches feel hopeless.

And the tools survivors get to fight back? Practically useless. Flashlights almost never work properly; you can aim dead on and still get nothing. Pallet stuns feel inconsistent, sometimes they register, other times the killer just powers through like nothing happened. Even perks that are meant to help counter killer pressure barely make a difference at high levels because of how oppressive killer perks and add ons have become.

The worst part is how predictable the experience becomes. If the killer isn‚Äôt brand new, they will catch you, it‚Äôs only a matter of time. There‚Äôs no real comeback potential unless the killer makes a huge mistake or decides to give you a pity escape. That feeling of tension that once made the game fun is replaced by frustration, because it‚Äôs not about skill anymore, it‚Äôs about how long you can delay the inevitable.

Dead by Daylight has a solid foundation, and for casual players or newcomers, it can still be enjoyable. But for anyone who plays long enough to get decent, the experience becomes punishing and unrewarding. It‚Äôs like the game actively punishes you for improving. Until the developers seriously rework MMR and address balance issues between killers and survivors, I can‚Äôt recommend it beyond the first few dozen hours. It‚Äôs fun until it isn‚Äôt. Then it‚Äôs just pain.

My Dead by Daylight Review:

This used to be one of my favorite games ever.
I‚Äôve been playing since 2018 with over 2000 hours across different platforms ‚Äî but every year, it somehow gets worse. It honestly feels like the game is trying to bury itself.

Every update feels like the devs spin a wheel labeled:
‚ÄúBuff random killer,‚Äù ‚ÄúNerf fun perk,‚Äù ‚ÄúAdd useless map,‚Äù ‚ÄúRelease gooner skin.‚Äù
And somehow, they manage to do all four.

Every update brings more frustration: killers with broken or boring powers, perks that are either insanely overpowered or completely useless, and maps that feel like they were made by an AI with zero balance or creativity.

On top of that, the game has basically turned into a Pay-to-Win collab fest ‚Äî every new partnership adds killers or perks that give unfair advantages, unless you spend money. It‚Äôs exhausting.

They even ruined some of the most fun perks, like Dead Hard, which has been nerfed into near uselessness. Add to that the never-ending hackers, the toxic community, and those awful ‚Äúgooner‚Äù skins ‚Äî absolute tragedy. Who asked for that? Not the players who actually cared about this game, that‚Äôs for sure.

I genuinely miss when Dead by Daylight was great ‚Äî fun, tense, and full of real competition.
Now it‚Äôs just a mess.

Attention all who may be interested in this game,

DO NOT buy this game. You'll get it and think "OMG this is scary and exciting!"... You might even think it's a great game for a while.. but then the curtains will rise...

First you will start playing survivor with your friends, using discord to communicate and scream while still thinking its fun but somehow the killer always catches you or finds you way too quickly. You'll escape a few times and think you did really well. This will go on for a few games but then you will get out of the bot Match Making Rating (MMR), and realize you will only ever go against three (3) killers. Blight, Nurse, and Ghoul... You'll think I just need to learn their quirks and I can probably run them forever. Only 300 hours in and you'll still last only two (2) loops at best against any of those three (3) killers that know what they're doing. You and your friends will grow tired of not having all the perks, and the constant tunneling off hook... the frustration will grow until your friends move on to a non-trash game and thus you are now ready to move to the next phase of self hatred.. Playing killer.

With no friends or good teammates left on this trash game you will phase over to the dark side. At the beginning you'll 4k (kill all 4 survivors) every match or get new players who run in straight lines for instant downs.. you'll think "Oh this is so easy!". Then once again you will get out of the bot MMR and learn the reality.  Endless pallets on large maps and the more than often toxic Survive with Friends (SWF) who communicate with each other the entire game, and will body-block or try and flashlight/pallet save on every single down. Endgame becomes a endless walls of bodies for a down, and you'll start to let the bad thoughts consume you... why shouldn't I play Blight, Nurse, or Ghoul.. I am probably really good at them (you're not) and when you start 4k'ing with the sweatiest perks you can use you'll think.. "Wow I am amazing at this game!" (You are not) and you'll continue the vicious cycle. You'll start to turn on all survivors who are trying their best and realize they are the reason the Dead by Daylight (DBD) community sucks and they are the ones who keep running off their DBD playerbase. Then once that hatred really becomes you.. the process starts over and you go back to survivor.

Once you are empty and returned back to your survivor base... you'll think you know everything there is about killers and start to use every cheesy strategy, perk, and trick that once infuriated you as a killer.. and laugh as they now feel your pain and you start to get out at least 50% of the time... you'll think you are top tier with your 500 hours (you're not) and you'll start being toxic in chat against the same killers you play but now they don't play "fair" by community standards. This soul sucking cycle will then repeat until you have 1000 hours... and then 3000 hours.. There truly won't be a day where you don't hate yourself playing at this point.

If you have made it this far I can now truly tell you the real reason to never play this game. The developers. They are selfish, greedy, and tunnel-visioned. They will look at their #s across all DBD games and translate any high % of perk usage to overpowered and thus needing a nerf. They will add requirements like "must heal someone" or "must be unhooked" or "after 2 downs"... they literally make perks have requirements because they can't balance perk combinations. Then while nerfing both sides they will create bugs that will exist over a span of months, and then fix them only to recreate bugs that existed years before. They will blame the community when they get negative feedback, and they will say the next patch will fix slugging and tunneling (it won't). The real tragedy is these developers don't play the game and when they do they are only as good as bot MMR. Probably modeled the bots after their gameplay, tbh. They don't listen to the community and will continue to kill this game with their ignorance. All while keeping the same three (3) killers buffed, and same meta perks for survivors as the only real options. Fun is not a business model for them, greed and stupidity is what powers Behavior.

Final notes, this game will promise greatness and only succeed in making you hate yourself while making you play again the day after. It's a depressing cycle that never gets better, You'll eventually leave and you'll be better off for it, May it come sooner rather than later.

I would recommend the game but at the same time, probably not? Don't get me wrong its really fun sometimes, and with the amount of perks and characters the game has you almost always have something new to play with. But my biggest gripe is the bugs and repetitiveness that the game can cause. Not every perk is good, some barely do anything, and in other cases the killer you want to play just isn't good all round (wassup fellow pig mains). Whether its overbalancing or neglect most killers just don't make the cut, forcing you to play whats meta.

Lets take ghostface for example, great character, love the design and abilities, but hes really good. Undetectable. can instantly down people he marks. Overall really strong.
Then there's the pig, she also has undetectable, but she cant insta down, plus it takes longer for her to crouch that ghostface the only saving grace is a dash ability. And her main ability is just really lackluster. Sure if the person doesn't know how to take off the reverse bare trap then you'll definitely get use out of it but that's usually only when people have never faced her before. Experienced players would get them off instantly (plus you only have a super limited amount). 

The pig is a case of trying to overbalance a character and it ends up being way too weak. Then they never touch them again. So if you don't play the meta then you don't win. Now this isn't a deal-breaker, I'm sure if you're picking the game up for the first time you'll have fun, but just don't main one killer, one second you're on top of the world the next you're struggling to get a single hook

Well let's put out a universal change guised as a "quality of life" change that's just a flat buff to survivors and a titanic nerf to all killers not named Nurse. Developers haven't been able to figure out that if they continue to show blatant favoritism to survivors through some incredibly stupid changes (pallet density update ruining every M1 killer only to amount to barely a nerf to Blight, planned Xenomorph and Knight changes that would've dumpstered the killers had the community not raised a big stink about it, nerfed Weave Attunement and gutted Franklin's Demise just bc killers could read auras if survivors loaded up on items, I could go on), eventually players will just leave. Rank incompetence, favoritism, and disrespect. That's what you will get from BHVR. And after nearly 10 years they've shown it'll never change. Another game in this genre needs to show up and kill this game. BHVR has gotten way too comfortable being this inexcusably lazy.

Dead by Daylight: The Ultimate Slasher Simulation

Dead by Daylight (DbD) is the ultimate realization of a horror slasher scenario turned into a relentless, high-stakes game. This 4v1 asymmetrical horror setup is genius: the Survivors face genuine, cinematic terror, while the Killer gets the pure horror power fantasy.

You are absolutely right‚Äîevery single move matters. The game perfectly translates the horror movie dynamic where every step dictates the fate of the game. That intrigue and tension come from the silence of sneaking, the pounding heart of a chase, and the sheer dread of hearing the Killer's terror radius approach. The way the game forces you to rely on teammates is where the real drama is born; those moments of perfect coordination feel incredible, but the "triggers" you mentioned from an unreliable or selfish teammate are just as intense and true to a horror movie experience.

It‚Äôs a living, breathing horror universe that only gets better with its constant flow of original lore and, crucially, the vast implementation of legendary licensed horror icons. The ability to play as Killers like Freddy Krueger or Michael Myers, and try to escape from classic settings like the Raccoon City Police Station or Haddonfield, transforms the game from a simple survival match into a genuine, terrifying horror cinematic simulator. If you want a game that translates the adrenaline and unpredictability of cinematic horror into endless multiplayer sessions, this is the one.

This game is very, very fun. It takes skill to play but once you got the hang of it, it's lots of fun. It keeps you in the chair for hours when you load in. If you like scary but skilled games, this is a must play. Lots of very known killers and survivers like springtrap, lauracroft, etc.

126 hours in Dead by Daylight and I‚Äôve learned two things: 1) friendship is temporary, and 2) the Killer can definitely hear me scream in real life.

Every match starts with hope ‚Äî "This time, we‚Äôll escape together!" Ten minutes later, I‚Äôm hiding in a bush watching my teammate try to ‚Äú360‚Äù the Killer like it‚Äôs a TikTok tutorial while I miss every single skill check within a 10-mile radius.

At some point, you stop fearing the Killer and start fearing your teammates. You heal someone for 90% of the bar and they run away. You unhook them and they sprint directly back to the Killer. One time I watched a guy crouch behind a rock for the entire match. Respect.

Playing survivor feels like being in a group project where one person screams, one person hides, one person gets sacrificed immediately, and one person actually does the gens. (It‚Äôs never me.)

And then I tried Killer. I thought it‚Äôd be empowering. Nope. It‚Äôs just me getting flash-lighted by three Claudette's while one teabags me at the exit gate.

Would I recommend it?
Absolutely. It‚Äôs the perfect game for testing your fight-or-flight response and your patience for humanity.

Dead by Daylight is one of the most exciting and unique multiplayer horror games available today. Developed by Behaviour Interactive, the game stands out because of its thrilling asymmetrical gameplay, where four survivors face off against one killer in a deadly game of cat and mouse.

One of the main reasons Dead by Daylight is such a good game is its intense atmosphere. The dark maps, creepy sound design, and suspenseful music create constant tension, making every match unpredictable and exciting. Whether you‚Äôre hiding in the shadows or chasing down survivors, the fear and adrenaline never fade.

Another great aspect is its variety and customization. There are dozens of survivors and killers to choose from, each with unique abilities and perks. This allows players to find a playstyle that fits them‚Äîwhether they prefer stealth, teamwork, or aggressive tactics. The constant updates and collaborations with famous horror franchises like Stranger Things, Resident Evil, and Silent Hill also keep the game fresh and interesting.

The game also encourages teamwork and strategy. Survivors must repair generators and help each other escape, while the killer must outsmart and hunt them down. Every match feels different, and success depends on skill, communication, and quick thinking.

Finally, Dead by Daylight has a strong community and continues to grow with new content, events, and balance changes. This keeps players engaged and ensures that the game remains challenging and fun over time.

Buggy/poor scripting that disrupts game play experience. Terrible match-making. Rude, troll players (killers mostly). And a disrespectful community. Luckily, there are other multiplayer games out there that are a better use of your time and money. 

To put things into perspective for those interested, it took 9 years for the developers to realize that players didn't want to wait while being downed, so they added the "abandon" feature. Players now can leave when there's game play abuse. Before, a killer can down all four survivors and wait until they bleed out one-by-one. It's 4 minutes of dying state per survivor; all you do is crawl on the ground while hearing your avatar groan the same looping audio and killer chase music. Now imagine having that for multiple matches per session. 

Is that really an enjoyable game experience? And what about getting off hook and the killer is just outside hook range just to hook you again? Well, that's not fun - solo-queue or with friends. Anyone who complains about SWF (survivor with friends) doesn't understand that not everyone plays squad, and if they are, then its not on a regular basis.

I would have liked to play the original DBD when it was first released. The maps looked bigger, atmosphere moodier, and it was more about stealth. Sure, the game play experience was minimal and simple. But it felt closer to what the game was originally inspired by: the 80s horror/slasher films where killers are unrelentless pursuers and victims needing to hide and outwit with the fewest of meager resources. Really, who was one of the first licensed IP killers for this game? 

Now, DBD has transitioned into a confusing mess of an arcade game where you need a user manual to know what killer/survivors you are grouped with and what overpowered add-ons they have. The steep learning curve for survivors is so laughable that it makes total sense that most players main as killers in this game. It's almost always 1.5 percent bonus blood points for survivors.
 
Over the years, I wished for bigger/diverse maps and unique generators with different skill checks/challenges. After all, with each new survivor and killer for a chapter, you would expect further commitment towards holistic improvement of the game experience. Instead, I have seen corporate miscommunication, mile-long messages noting latest bug patches/kill switches, and unfulfilled promises. One can say that the game is for "casual" players, but that doesn't excuse it being downright unplayable at times. 

But what do I know? Maybe in this day and age, an obviously broken game can manipulate people to actually think it takes skill and mind games to win when it's easy for players to abuse the game play and ruin the fun. At the end of the day, there are no substantial preventive/counter measures towards ensuring fair play despite the so-called initiative for anti-slugging, anti-camping, and anti-tunneling that were made to address DBD's current rework. And by the way, afk killers don't get penalized but survivors do when they're afk? So a boring free win is acceptable and I get penalized for wanting to leave a stalling match? Am I missing something here?

There were moments when I enjoyed the game and its spooky campy vibes. There aren't a lot of multiplayer games in the horror genre which makes DBD one of the few. But this year, there weren't as many good moments. Yeah, let's all gather around the bonfire one more time and laugh about Jim the Pole, but the charm has faded and the air has gotten stale. 

Time for something new and properly tested.

My message to the Entity:
Dead by Daylight is, without question, one of the most infuriating, poorly balanced, and mentally draining experiences I‚Äôve ever subjected myself to. This game doesn‚Äôt just get worse the more you play it actively punishes you for everything in the slightest. Every match feels like a slow descent into a never-ending cycle of frustration where no matter how hard you try, the outcome is suffering.

I've played some games I've struggled with before skill issue or genuinely hard,but nothing compares to the unique agony of Dead by Daylight. It‚Äôs a shrine of misery a game where hope dies first, followed by your patience, your sanity, and finally, your will to continue living. The balance is a joke, the matchmaking feels cursed, and every so-called ‚Äúupdate‚Äù somehow manages break the game entirely. The only entity more cruel than the one within the game is the one behind its design. [h1]Survive in the Fog[/h1]
Dead by Daylight is an asymmetrical horror game featuring a killer against 4 survivors.

While this game may be popular, it's fraught with problems, and the more years go by, the worse they get.
The game is in constant development, with the addition of original or licensed characters to purchase and/or unlock in-game every three months on average, with new perks added each time, and usually a new map available for everyone (for free).

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3243920817
DbD's strong point is clearly the diversity of gameplay around the killers, the numerous perks and the presence of several popular licensed characters (Ghost Face, Resident Evil, Freddy...)

But unfortunately, the positives end there, because everything else is just frustrating... [b]A company that only apologizes for every mistake they do without actually fixing the issues[/b], bugs everywhere that make playing really difficult during some periods, the graphisms are disgusting and drains a HUGE amount of performance for such low quality, settings worthy of a mobile game with very few in-game customization options, decisions made contrary to what the community expects, balancing issues with maps, killers, and survivor/killer perks...

In short... We can only say that DbD remains popular thanks to 3 factors: licensed characters, frequent content (chapters, skins, etc.), and above all, [b]no real game competitor that would make the community move ![/b]

Even though I've spent a lot of time on this game, [b]DbD remains a game I've given too much[/b], hoping for a better version and fixes over the years, but [b]2025 marks a dead end in my opinion...[/b]

[b]I absolutely do not recommend it, especially for beginners: the game has clearly become frustrating and hardly competitive, making it difficult to have fun especially in solo ![/b]

[h1]üèÜ For the Achievements üèÜ[/h1]

[b]~1000h for the 100%[/b]

The overall gameplay is [b] repetitive [/b] and [b] boring [/b]

[h2] Gameplay [/h2]

As a survivor, you walk around until you find a generator, then complete a few quick-time events. If the killer spots you, you‚Äôre probably going to get caught or injured, then you just repeat the same loop again.

As the killer, your task is to camp generators or chase down survivors. That‚Äôs pretty much it.

I honestly don‚Äôt get the hype.

[h2] Community [/h2]

One of the worst communities I‚Äôve seen, full of toxic, tryhard players who take the fun out of it.

[h3] Conclusion [/h3]

A very boring, repetitive game with lackluster mechanics and endless quick-time events. The gameplay loop is always the same: run around, find or defend generators, escape or chase, hook or unhook. That‚Äôs it. Combine that with a terrible community, and it‚Äôs just not worth it.

I think I bought this game years ago, refunded it, and didn‚Äôt really care to write a review.

In my opinion, keep that in mind, MY opinion, this game's boring as hell, sure a few matches once in a while is fine but it's really repetitive, not as fun as I expected but others might find it fun, I mean it is MY OPINION after all, you do you I guess, you don't even have to take this review seriously, in fact, why bother reading it, I'm not saying you shouldn't buy it if you want to, after all it is your choice, I'm just saying I was kinda expecting more but why am I complaining? It did manage to get a lot of players so maybe I'm wrong here, I mean I know I'm not into gaming that much so why am I expecting myself to like this when gaming isn't my main activity? Then again, this is my opinion so yeah, I don't know... buy it if you want, after all YOUR opinion matters when buying something not mine, not a stranger's, it's YOUR opinion that truly counts so I guess you should but this game if you like it, have fun playing if you do

üî™ Dead by Daylight ‚Äì Fear, Salt, and the Circle of Pain (8.5/10)

Dead by Daylight is not just a game ‚Äî it‚Äôs an emotional rollercoaster built entirely out of screams, betrayal, and questionable matchmaking.

One minute you‚Äôre a stealth god, looping the killer for five generators straight. The next, you‚Äôre face-down on a hook wondering how your teammates managed to hide in the corner for the entire match. It‚Äôs beautiful, it‚Äôs chaotic, it‚Äôs absolutely infuriating‚Ä¶ and somehow, you keep coming back.

Each killer feels unique, each survivor has their quirks, and the constant updates keep things fresh ‚Äî or at least, unpredictable. The mix of strategy, skill, and sheer panic makes every round unforgettable. And when that exit gate finally opens? That‚Äôs pure adrenaline.

Sure, there‚Äôs balance drama, salty lobbies, and occasional bugs from the Entity itself ‚Äî but none of that ruins the core magic: the social chaos of four humans versus one monster, and the shared trauma that follows.

ü©∏ Verdict: 8.5/10 ‚Äî Equal parts terror and comedy. Whether you‚Äôre screaming, sweating, or rage-quitting, Dead by Daylight always gets your heart racing. You never escape ‚Äî and that‚Äôs exactly why it‚Äôs brilliant.

This game is the bane of my existence.  My League of Legends.  I just do not have the competitive drive that seemingly everyone else has in order to enjoy playing the game on either Survivor nor Killer side.  Yet I keep coming back like the abusive ex-wife that gave me a heroin addiction because there's just this SOMEthing about it that I somehow enjoy; not that I could put it to words.

Playing Survivor has become a gamble of who's going to get Tunneled first and for me personally dissuades playing in a squad as you'll always have a friend twiddling their thumbs with nothing to do for potentially 10-20 minutes while they wait for the match to be over.  Lesser capable Killers who don't use Meta perks such as myself risk every game being a punching bag to a Bully Squad or Gen-Rushed by a team of Survivors they could just never find.
I hear the development team knows how unfriendly DBD is to beginners, but it's not just the overwhelming amount of Killers with different abilities and Perks with different interactions, but the PLAYERS just as well.  I've seen many times where a Survivor is inadvertently tunneled out of a game because they're not as well knowledged as the rest, and witnessed Killers whom have only JUST downloaded the game absolutely demolished by well-versed Survivors.  As someone who markets themselves as a "Casual" gamer, these are serious turnoffs for myself and I can reason many others as well.

It's just a shame that there isn't anything that properly competes with DBD that'll last.

"Would I recommend Dead by Daylight?"
Absolutely not ‚Äî but I‚Äôll still be logging in tomorrow.

This game is like an abusive relationship, only with more teabags and even less communication. It pulls you in with promises of fun chases, thrilling escapes, and the occasional dopamine hit when you outsmart a killer, and promises of balancing the game from BHVR. You think, ‚ÄúMaybe it‚Äôs different this time. Maybe the playerbase is coming around and getting on the same page that it's supposed to be FUN for all 5 in the lobby." Then it gaslights you; a killer facecamps you, your teammates sandbag you, and somehow you end up thinking it‚Äôs your fault. ‚ÄúIf I‚Äôd just looped better‚Ä¶ if I‚Äôd brought Dead Hard or Decisive Strike or Unbreakable... or Lightborn (for the killers)..." because that's what BHVR and the sweaty players will tell you. But then you get one amazing match where everyone plays fair, you escape through the gate or hatch, and your brain goes, ‚ÄúSee? It‚Äôs not that bad.‚Äù And just like that, you‚Äôre back.

917 hours later, here I am. I wouldn‚Äôt recommend it to anyone I care about ‚Äî but if you do play, welcome to the support group. We meet in the fog.

DBD needs to fix it's game. I'm a streamer who has been live now playing many hours of this game. Not only do they not implement the anti tunnel anti camp systems we were promised, but they also allow racists and sexist individuals to run around in their game and their report system means nothing. To fix their game in a meaningful way they need the following:

1. An anti-camp system
2. An anti tunnel system
3. Better matchmaking in general or a comp option 
4. Their report system needs to actually do something because it creates unsafe situations for streamers as is, there should be report feedback so you actually know when someone gets banned
5. They need to actually listen to their community when we make suggestions. Currently they put out surveys like they are but we are very ignored in actuality, these game devs need to play their game on public servers to really understand bc it's clear that they aren't
6. Additional suggestions: 1-2 killers you can blacklist that you wont match make against for those facing trauma with specific killers, a system in the blood web auto selector to filter for a few items when auto webbing, an "avoid player" option like Overwatch has for people you block etc so you aren't matched with them again

These are just the tip of the iceberg. I've been a big supporter of DBD and was trying to bring joy to my community, but I can't stream it anymore with all the unsafe people in public chats and matches and the game straight up being not fair. I would like to be brutally destroyed by people with true skills at the game in a way where I'm honored to lose to them. Not racist sexist people who know how to tunnel and camp a hook.

Not that anyone will see this, but fix your game and your report system so it's safe and fun to play. Congratulations you've lost and entire streamer community until that happens.

The lore of Dead by Daylight revolves around an eldritch cosmic entity called the Entity, which traps countless individuals from different timelines and worlds into its dimension. The Entity forces them into a perpetual cycle of horror known as Trials, where a Killer hunts down Survivors for the Entity's sustenance, as it feeds on emotions like terror, despair, and hope. Survivors are reset by the Entity after each trial to continue fighting, while Killers are often beings of immense malice or victims of great tragedy who are either forced or find purpose in the cycle.

What this game does well, it does incredibly so. No other multiplayer horror game can give the highs that DBD can, but also no other game can give such incredibly frustrating lows. Each match is a 50/50 on your enjoyment, but ultimately you keep playing, and if not you'll eventually come back like everyone else does. 

What i recommend is this; don't solely make not dying the thread that holds your enjoyment together, and if your a killer don't make killing every survivor as it either. You get bloodpoints and progression from various things, healing fixing gens evading the killer and so on. (and same for being killer). I know it seems like nonsense but if you just let yourself be immersed and accept you might die (as you would if you played a singleplayer horror game) the vibe of the game changes alot. That's just my take on it though.

yes there are bugs and imbalances and all the mishandling by the devs, but ultimately the game perseveres through it all. and if you play this game you'll learn to persevere as well through all the frustrations and lows because at the end of the day it's just so f**king satisfying when you finally outrun the killer and escape or get all 4 survivors on hook.

If you're new, buckle up buttercup. This game is so killer-sided that survivors should come with their own tiny violins. The devs listen to survivor feedback with the same enthusiasm I show for my aunt's Facebook memes‚Äîwhich is to say, I've developed carpal tunnel from how quickly I scroll past that garbage. Yet here I am, logging in daily like an addict who keeps touching a hot stove "just to check if it's still hot." You'll either get tunneled faster than a toddler spotting an unattended birthday cake across the room, or play so well the killer rage-quits‚Äîdenying you the escape, leaving you with all the satisfaction of a sneeze that never happens. The community is so toxic that EPA officials in hazmat suits show up in the chat to declare your gaming chair a biohazard zone. So choose your streamer idols wisely. Just play for fun... and maybe keep your therapist on speed dial.

There are streamers and youtubers that make a living out of criticizing a game that never claimed to or had the intention to be fair/balanced. Skill is a necessary but insufficient condition to wining matches in this game, and the results are mostly determined by luck. However, if you're playing this game with the intention of wining, humiliating other players, doing victory laps or to self aggrandize through the illusion of skill, then you will have a very bad time when luck is not on your side. If you on the other hand have resigned to the idea of control, the unending quest for victory and are unfazed by online trolls then you'll have a lot of fun with this game.

I also have 500 hours as killer , so i now have the pov from both sides, and i can affirm that playing killer is 80% of the time NOT a fun experience, survivors are the biggest crybaby of any games around, they will insult and throw death wishes at you for playing the game how it is intended by the DEVS, its not the people that built this environnement its the devs themselves, the only way for a killer to be able to get a win is to play in the "toxic" way, slugging/camping/tunneling/etc...

In the end its a sad truth but if i can recommend anyone reading this and being a killer main, is : just be toxic and slug/camp/tunnel because, its sad for the 20% of survivors that are good and kind people, but really when you only play killer, you just get teabag and flashed to the infinity and beyond (how are flash still in the game or not nerfed to the ground is crazy to me by how OP it is) so they totally deserve it, also having a match against a full premade squad is unfun as hell, because of how the game is so poorly balanced, in solo queue a killer can tunnel and ruin the life of a specific Survivor while in squad the killer has pretty much no chance of winning or even to do anything.

God awful and incompetent game devs that refuse to play their game, i mean it.

It does not matter what the problem of bug currently affecting the game is, they will find a way to pinpoint the cause of it, announce that their "Amazing Development team" will fix it, brainstorm ideas on the worst possible way they can handle it, and somehow nail it perfect way to make the game worse.

For example, recently they updated the game with a feature that removes "Giving up" on hook, basically you cant take a chance to escape without a luck offering, and it doesn't insta kill on the second skill check failure. Now, in their minds this was the grand save-all solution, now no one will EVER give up since they are discouraged to, and will fight till the last breath! What actually happened, however, is now a rage quitter will now be encouraged to sabotage the game, or just go afk instead of being taken out; a generally better solution to the inescapable baby rage that happens so often in this community.

Another thing, they are a perpetrator of the classic "Release a overpowered character, let people buy it in mass to win, then nerf it to the ground" trope. Well, that is when the Oh-So great dev team can actually make something good, and not being lazy.

An amazing art team being held hostage by a dev team with an combined iq of 4. And if you don't think they don't play their game, look into what happened to Mathieu Cote when he got humiliated with flashlights on TV.

DBD is insufferable on many levels, at least in its current state. I mean i do have lots of joyful memories from playing it and even made lots of friends on it, but now i cant even launch it because EAC doesnt wanna initialize apparently? i tried most "solutions" (from reinstalling, verifying files, restarting PC/steam to other more detailed processes) that i found from forums and threads online, but nothing helps. also BHVR takes excruciatingly long to even respond to tickets, so dont bother. when i do get a response, its usually automated and honestly borders on brainless. so wow thanks, ill just have to wait a few weeks for any upcoming updates (if those r even gonna help, mind u). heard some people say that factory resetting ur pc should work, i dont doubt it, but i am also NOT wiping everything off of mine just to be able to access a game i paid for, its out of the question. I cannot just manually install fresh EAC on my own for DBD either, because their website does not provide an installer or anything at all. I attempted to use the EAC folder from some other game, because that somehow worked for a few people i talked with, but for me, that was just as useless as anything else i tried before that. 


well but anyway, besides the fact that this whole thing with DBD having endless bugs at all times is blatantly ridiculous on its own, no one should be expected to go to crazy lengths and wait for months for a simple anticheat to run correctly, yet here we are...and if this issue is due to the EAC itself being faulty and not about the DBD devs, then by all means, please excuse me. but then again, i doubt its about the EAC and epic devs themselves, because at the end of the day, the other games that i play which use EAC as well, initialize & work perfectly fine, but okay! btw my actual error message is just a simple "EAC client cannot be instantiated" and everything i said above is fully unique to my experience and my pc. 


as for the gameplay or whatever really, i suppose its all fine. for me personally, solo q is unbearable due to how the matchmaking appears to hook multiple people with different skill levels into the same lobbies (im pretty sure that the DBD matchmaking prioritizes fast lobby matching, not so much putting people with similar escape rates together). there has seemingly also been a spike in all the griefing happening in matches, so im not surprised many people just DC, i dont wanna interact with hackers and trolls either, so a team full of friends appears to be the only way to play it rn.

keeping aside, some of the mechanics of this game its one of the best multiplayer games of the horror genre. for me, this was the first game that i bought after i bought a new PC. I would absolutely recommend this game for the players who lovers horror games and this one is multiplayer.

[h2] Where do I start with this game? [/h2]

Note: killer is the only way I had fun in this game, [b]Had.[/b]

This [i]Game[/i] has taken 100 hours from me and it took only [b]30 minutes[/b] for me to Finally get it in my head that these [i]Devs[/i] have no idea what they are doing.

"I want to play a normal game for like 12-20 minutes!" [b]Wrong[/b] it's has been more than 70 seconds since you found a survivor and now 2+ gens are already done by the time you get to one because some of the survivors brought toolkit *Items*, the game will now end in about 3 minutes regardless of any action you take.

"alright! I finally got one! now to bring them to a hook and-" [b]No.[/b] a survivor WILL be there with a flashlight *item* to stun you out of the grab and they WILL do this the rest of the game Every-time [i]*without fail.*[/i]

"The survivor is right there! i'll hit them and-" [b]How?[/b] because there's no way you're hitting anything in this near blinding smoke cloud their *item* made, it's also not the last time this will happen because it has [i]Infinite Uses[/i] on a 70-60 second cooldown that they can reduce even further.

"well damn.. oh wait! I can just get a perk that counters *items!* that way I- [b]What perk?[/b] 
"what? the-there HAS to be a perk for this problem!" 
There [i]was[/i] "Franklins Demise" it drops their items on a melee hit and makes them go away after 90 seconds but then they nerfed it when adding the smoke bomb- "okay?! and?! i'll still use it even if they made the items disappear slower or jus-"
they removed that "...Fu*king [i]what[/i]" they. removed. that. feature. and somehow thought that increasing the range that you can see the items was a proper compensation.

"What if I just fu*king killed the problem survivor first? huh? what if i just leave them there to die ground? what if just do that?" You break [b]The Rules[/b]

"the what?" the rules, the ones that the same survivors who are making your game experience a waking hell *made-up*, to keep killers "non-toxic and respectful" while they play their "co-op game", "rules" that were *made-up* so survivors can use it as a "get out of jail free card" on any consequence from whatever harassment/bullying/hate crime they throw at you, "rules" that are now a *base game mechanic* that you are [b]Required[/b] to follow, lest you become unable to undo any progress they make, [b]forever[/b], and that whole "let them just die on the ground" thing? Gone, removed from the game entirely, as now they can just pick themselves up after staying on the ground for a *Combined Total* of 90 seconds.

"...did they tone-down or nerf survivors to compensate for this so the game can go slowe-" [b]Not at fu*king all[/b] 
"Isn't what the survivors were doing achieving the same as what I was going to do?" [b]Yes[/b]
"Are the Devs going to recognize that?" [b]Never[/b], because these are the same people who let several bugs found in the Public beta test go to live, and let both of the last two+ major updates seemingly go nowhere near QA.

And it has [b]always[/b] been like this.
And it this problem [b]will[/b] continue until it dies [b]again[/b] and [b]again[/b]
And I do not want more hours from anyone at all to be wasted on this [b]""Game""[/b] and it's endless recursive loop of [b]b*llsh*t[/b] and [b]lies[/b]

This game *will* take from you and it will never give anything back.
It has already taken enough from me, and this review is becoming a part of that theft so I'm ending it with this.
[b]Avoid at all Costs, even if there are none[/b]

Dead by Daylight, developed by Behaviour Interactive, stands as one of the most thrilling and unique multiplayer horror games ever created. Its concept is simple yet brilliant: four survivors must work together to repair generators and escape, while one killer hunts them down. This asymmetrical 4v1 setup delivers an intense, heart-pounding experience that never feels repetitive, thanks to the game‚Äôs dynamic maps, diverse characters, and unpredictable match flow.

One of the strongest aspects of Dead by Daylight is its gameplay variety. Every character, both survivor and killer, offers unique abilities and perks that completely change how matches play out. Whether you‚Äôre outsmarting the killer with clever jukes or stalking survivors as a silent predator, the game always manages to keep you on edge. The balance between teamwork and individual skill creates an addictive loop of tension and reward that keeps players coming back for more.

Beyond gameplay, Dead by Daylight also shines in its content model. Players can unlock many characters and cosmetic items for free through gameplay, without needing to spend money. This level of accessibility encourages commitment and fair progression, giving dedicated players the satisfaction of earning their favorite survivors, killers, and skins simply by playing.

The atmosphere and presentation are equally impressive. Each map is beautifully eerie, featuring moody lighting, haunting sounds, and cinematic design that perfectly captures the essence of horror. Combined with an ever-growing roster of original and licensed characters‚Äîfrom classic slasher icons to Behaviour‚Äôs own creations‚ÄîDead by Daylight offers endless replayability.

Overall, Dead by Daylight is a must-play for fans of horror and multiplayer strategy. Its innovative design, rewarding progression, and sheer intensity make it one of the best and most enduring games in the genre.

2000+ hours 50/50 main.
TLDR: The meta is super trash right now with Survivors using sprint burst with the exhaustion cooldown perks and hard gen rushing. Killers are tunneling a lot (Generators are completed so quick they feel like they need a least one kill for the entire match. 

I don't blame the players on either side, they are just playing the game the way it is right now, the problem is with the game balance and direction that the developers are allowing it to go in. Any sense of proper matchmaking is just a facade, coop survivors are ultra unbalanced, and to play killer is just a sweaty stress fest if you are trying to compete in matches against SWFs, Meta-builds, and Gen Rushing (which these are all you get once you have enough time in the game).

Don't get me wrong, I still enjoy this game for the most part under the right circumstances, but when the bad parts of the game come out, it's really bad and makes me okay with taking extended breaks from the game until I feel like checking up on it again. I have been limiting my time and money that I am willing to spend on this game.

I really hope one day enough of our player criticism is heard and BHVR actually cares and does something truly meaningful to mend these issues, I know i'm not the only one and that there are plenty of players you feel the same way.

Additional perspective: From a Killers perspective, you are just here to "chase" the survivors around as the loop you across the map, complete Generators at high speed, you are here just to give them a sense of challenge, some hooks, maybe a kill or two at best, but just to allow them to have their power fantasy, especially against higher level survivors/teams. And if you happen to get to a good start and frustrate a survivor or two, expect them to immediately disconnect/throw the game.  If the matchmaking decides to swing too far in the other direction, you'll feel bad for dominating players who are obviously below average and probably just them go if you're nice. The Devs have even stated that they want this type of matchmaking ratio, which is obvious cope for an inability to actually balance the game and matchmaking. 

From survivors perspective, if you are in a sweaty gen-rushing meta perk pre-running tryhard squad then see above; for everyone else, expect to play against the most desperate bitter traumatized killers ever! Whoever gets the first hook is going to get tunneled out of the game ASAP, they will be so desperate for that early kill to slow down the probable gen-rushing. If you are teamed up with randoms, they'll just be running around the map like chickens with their heads cut off, leaving you to be the last survivor alive if you are competent and not tunneled... but what is your reward? To get slugged, left crawling on the floor while the Killer moves back and forth behind you in a humping motion insinuating Rape, until you bleed out, yes this happens a lot!

I DO NOT RECOMMEND THIS GAME. I have been playing on console from 2017 until late last year so off steam i have at least 4000 hours. To be blunt, it is a really, really bad game, and it has been for the last 3 years. The majority of players who rot in their gaming chairs and play this all day suck, the complete jokes they call events suck, the recent rifts suck and will continue to worsen, the gameplay elements or lack there of suck and lastly the cosmetics given often suck.

BHVR has such an avid incompetence with bugs that release every new update that stack on the pre-existing 300 other bugs they had prior that it takes months and even years for a glimmer of hope that they fix one of them unless it's utterly game breaking. Gameplay wise, it is extremely boring and repetitive and has offered NOTHING new since release besides TIME-LIMITED gameplay modes they decide to bless us with once every 6 months. It is so painfully boring and hopeless unless you have a SWF, since there is no way to communicate with teammates. 

The ENTIRE player base‚ÄîI cannot stress this enough are gut wrenchingly awful at the game, they do NOT value the fun of others if they're playing killer, they do NOT care if you live or not if they're on your team as survivor and on top of that they are quite literally the worst people you can possibly meet and interact with. 

(It is not the community's job to make sure players on either party has fun, I'd just like to note that 90% of the matches you will play will equal that to medieval torture since the game literally feeds off of raw, violent, soul sucking toxicity in order to thrive.)

I DO NOT RECOMMEND THIS GAME, especially for new players. It is 100% NOT new-player friendly; there is an overwhelming mass amount of killers with an amalgamation of new or reused powers in different forms, and honestly don't even bother with learning a killer's power because if enough surv players whine about it, they get the power completely rewritten even after release.
There are 282 perks most of which suck and aren't even worth using, 61 maps that are either unfun on killer or unfun or survivor and overall aesthetically unpleasing. Not to mention hundreds of map tiles/loops you HAVE to learn to even stand a chance in a match despite the fact they are not in the slightest explained in the AWFUL AND OUTDATED tutorial they refuse to change. 
Every month the game receives a new killer with a new indescribably complicated power that is usually an amalgamation of prior killers bunched together in an attempt to make something new (if we're lucky we also get another ugly map no one wants to look at) and 3-6-9 perks that are either; complete utter trash no one is going to use, or insanely broken and instantly become a new extremely powerful meta on already broken killers.

If you want to get into this game, make sure to isolate yourself from the outside world because there is no other asym out there that is even considered a competitor in the slightest involved in the genre, so you stick to this awful game in hopes that the devs will pick themselves up and fix it, which they never will because the code is disgraceful and again, BHVR sucks so you end up in a non-stop cycle of playing this game PURELY because there is no other game similar to it and BHVR are acutely aware of that, it's exactly why they can get away with the sheer unwavering stupidity as a company and objectively lackluster content they offer us.


The cosmetics we do get for killers and survs are typically so overdone with neon glowing colors, ugly patterns and unnecessary accessories in the strangest places that in the end they look like a "Name one thing in this image" meme. overall 70% of the NEW outfits in the game are a complete mess with horrendously absurd themes and a generous amount of vomit inducing millenialness to the point the idea of someone buying them is literally absurd to me.
If you find yourself enjoying a less popular character you will most likely not get an outfit for months or even an entire year, so good luck with that because they prioritise making outfits and emblems, banners and charms for the skinny white women in the game such as Sable Ward over literally anyone else.

But hey, if it goes on sale for 5 bucks, then sure, buy it and mess around in it because the game can somehow be really fun at times, especially with friends. It just really sucks that the biggest pain in this game is that mostly it is a pure gamble whether or not you want to tear your teeth free from your skull at the end of a match, but in my opinion, SAVE YOURSELF, because this game has at least 2-3 years left of life and it isn't worth getting into.

I recommend this game‚Ä¶ but with mixed feelings. I‚Äôve played DBD on and off for years, because it‚Äôs both incredibly addictive and immensely frustrating. It‚Äôs one of those games that can give you the best gaming moments ‚Äî and then immediately make you want to uninstall.

My tip: if you can get one or two friends with the same mindset, do it. DBD shines when you play and learn together. It‚Äôs a fantastic game that constantly rewards you for improving and experimenting ‚Äî the core mechanics are simple, but surprisingly tough to master.

Recommending this game to a normal human being would be like handing someone a fork and telling them to eat soup. It‚Äôs not just bad‚Äîit‚Äôs a psychological experiment disguised as entertainment. Survivors and killers alike behave like escaped NPCs from a cursed simulation, and honestly, I respect their commitment to chaos. But the real monster here? The game‚Äôs balancing, which was clearly designed by someone who can't stand upright.

Every match feels like a rerun of a nightmare. Survivors cling to the same perks like they‚Äôre life vests on the Titanic, while killers show up with the same loadouts like they‚Äôre attending a cosplay convention for sociopaths. Variety? Creativity? Those were sacrificed to the dark gods of meta. It‚Äôs like watching two arsonists argue over who gets to burn down the house first‚Äîwhile they‚Äôre both inside it.

The game needs both sides to function, yet both sides are keen on making the other's life as miserable as they can. It‚Äôs less ‚Äúmultiplayer horror‚Äù and more ‚Äúmutual psychological warfare.‚Äù

Thinking of playing? Great! Just make sure your therapist is on speed dial. The in-game tutorial teaches you about as much as a fortune cookie written by a sleep-deprived raccoon. You‚Äôll need YouTube guides, a support group, and a fuckton of alcohol.

Can the game be fun? Sure‚Äîlike juggling chainsaws. Can it be painful? Absolutely. It‚Äôs digital masochism with a matchmaking queue.
