You know, I've had longstanding opinion that PvP games have suffered from the common issue of players and developers alike assuming that bad sportsmanship and the zero-sum nature of the game are both not only inevitable, but necessary factors. Entirely too many people chase the wild goose that is balance, without affording any thought as to whether or not their game would even be fun were they to achieve the impossible. "Have any of them wondered," I ask myself, "if a 50% winrate truly feels like a 50% winrate?"

Games like Dead by Daylight help answer this conundrum for me. Here it is, standing out from the crowd; unlike most other game's I've played, this one is separate from them all, different to its core. It sits me down, leans over, and whispers sweetly into my ears: "You're completely fucking right actually! I hate people." Then it clubs me over the head and offers to sell me a fashionable bandage for $5.

Leave aside the issues of a horrible and punishing new player experience. Leave aside the richly awful new privacy policy. Do not worry yourself about the game's obsession with DLC and microtransactions, or the fact that interesting gameplay alterations are deliberately and pointlessly locked to time-limited events designed to generate a fear-of-missing-out. All of this pales by comparison.

This thing could scarcely be a better tool for engendering bitterness in its playerbase if it had been specifically engineered to do so. Every game, win or lose, ends up feeling like a hurdle that took something from you. The only people who truly thrive in this environment are the kind who specifically come to spit in the face of others‚ÄîI ask someone why they enjoy playing Survivor, a role I find stressful and impossible, and you know what I was told? "I like to show killers their place." Call me crazy, but I don't think rampant mutual antagonism is a very healthy relationship for players to have with each other.

The role of a game designer is to create a mechanism by which players can explore various emotions. Frustration is a valid one, as games like Getting Over It have proved. But those were deliberate. This? This is callous negligence. As any other review can tell you, the toxicity is rampant. And I can't even blame people for it! How could I, when the game seems designed to [i]teach you[/i] to seek revenge on others and treat them as awfully as possible? I suppose it's at least on-brand for a game about a bunch of merciless bastards, if nothing else.

I feel bad for myself, because of the energy I've lost on games that made my day worse. I feel bad for other players, for having found an environment so rancid it ends up making them venomous just to feel sane. I feel bad for the players who I managed to thoroughly beat, since I know it's likely they had an awful time facing me. And I feel bad for my friends, who hoped that I could have fun playing this; though they too have left negative reviews, so at least I can know they will understand.

Mark my words, this game will never fix itself. Not because it can't be - the concept could be great, if enough work were done to fix it - but because Behavior Interactive is not interested in doing that. They're making money off of people, and that's all that matters. Considering this, and all the pain this game is prone to causing, I can recommend trying this game only in some hypothetical context wherein the publisher loses more money off you than they gain. No game that breeds this much hate deserves to turn a profit.

A word spared for the kind, though: There are a few occasions, and a few players, who when playing Killer will grant you leniency. They will not chase you relentlessly, thus giving you a chance to accomplish something. They will limit how many people they kill, so that at least some survivors can have a win. And especially as a new player, this was wonderful, and win or lose I enjoyed my time with them. Though it can't make up for the tremendous issues embedded in this game's execution, I greatly appreciate their considerate actions.

Dead by Daylight ‚Äì Fun, Frustrating, and Somehow Addicting
This review is completely unbiased, just my honest take after years of playing.

I started playing Dead by Daylight around 2022, so I‚Äôm just judging it based on my own experience. From the moment I jumped in, I found it to be a game that constantly swings between ‚Äúthis is amazing‚Äù and ‚Äúwhy am I still playing this?‚Äù It‚Äôs tense, unpredictable, and unique, but it also has plenty of moments that make you want to take a break and then come back again.

Pros:
- Unique gameplay: There‚Äôs really nothing else like it. The 4v1 setup keeps every match different and unpredictable. They even recently tested a 2v8 mode that was actually a lot of fun, though it was only limited-time. It‚Äôs nice to see the devs experimenting with new ideas.

- Atmosphere: The sound design and overall tension are really well done, especially early on. The heartbeat mechanic and creepy visuals make the first few hours feel intense. But if you‚Äôre looking for a true horror experience, you‚Äôll probably be disappointed. The fear factor fades pretty quickly once you get used to the gameplay, and it becomes more about strategy and skill than actual scares.

- Frequent updates: New killers, survivors, and maps drop often enough to keep things fresh, even if balance can feel off sometimes.

- Crossovers: The licensed killers and survivors from franchises like Resident Evil and Silent Hill are done really well and add a lot of variety.

- Cross-platform play: You can play with friends no matter what platform they‚Äôre on, PC, console, or even next-gen systems. It makes it easy to connect with your friends and keeps the community alive across all platforms.

- Skill expression: Both sides reward game sense and experience. Pulling off a good chase or clutch escape actually feels earned.

- Active dev support: The developers host a lot of events throughout the year with bonus bloodpoints, cosmetics, and limited-time rewards. They also give out compensation when the servers go down or maintenance takes longer than expected, which is always appreciated. Some events are recycled, but they still give players something to work toward.

- Discounts: The game itself and the DLCs go on sale pretty often, so if you‚Äôre patient, you can pick up killers, survivors, and even the base game at really good discounts instead of paying full price.

Neutral:
- Experience depends on friends: The game can be a blast if you play with friends and coordinate, but solo queueing can be rough. Bad teammates, toxic players, and inconsistent matchmaking can make it frustrating when you‚Äôre on your own. I recommend finding a group of people who are already experienced and don‚Äôt mind playing with newer players, as this can make the experience much more enjoyable.

Cons:
- Matchmaking: It‚Äôs hit or miss. Some games are really fun and balanced, others feel completely one-sided.

- Bugs and performance issues: It‚Äôs better than it used to be, but bad hit registration, lag, and rubberbanding still happen more than they should.

- Toxic players: Easily one of the worst parts of the game. The community can be extremely toxic on both sides. As killer, you‚Äôll get teabagged, flashlight-clicked, body-blocked, and spammed with insults in post-game chat just for playing normally. As survivor, you‚Äôll deal with killers who camp and tunnel from the start, or teammates who rage quit and leave you to die. It‚Äôs not every game, but it happens a lot. You‚Äôll need a thick skin and a sense of humor to deal with it because it‚Äôs almost part of the experience at this point.

- Learning curve and meta: The game doesn‚Äôt explain much, so most players learn through trial and error or guides. On top of that, Dead by Daylight has a very defined meta for both survivors and killers. If you don‚Äôt adapt quickly to the most effective strategies, perks, and playstyles, you‚Äôll likely struggle and get frustrated. It rewards players who study and follow trends, which can make it tough for newcomers or anyone who prefers a more casual, experimental approach.

- Grind with little reward: After prestige 3, there isn‚Äôt much reason to keep leveling a character except for cosmetics. It starts to feel like you‚Äôre grinding with little to nothing to show for it.

- Licensed content isn‚Äôt permanent: Some killers and survivors are tied to licensing deals and can be removed. The good news is the devs always alert players ahead of time when that happens, so you‚Äôll have a fair chance to buy or unlock them before they‚Äôre gone for good.

- Pay-to-win elements: Some DLC characters come with very strong perks that can change the game. You can unlock most original characters with in-game currency, but licensed ones require real money. It makes things tougher for new players who don‚Äôt want to spend extra.

Final Thoughts: Dead by Daylight is a love-hate kind of game. When it‚Äôs good, it‚Äôs some of the most fun and intense multiplayer you can play. When it‚Äôs bad, it‚Äôs frustrating enough to make you want to uninstall. But no matter how many times I take a break, I always end up coming back. It‚Äôs chaotic, stressful, and sometimes unfair, but it‚Äôs also addicting.

8/10. You‚Äôll hate it, you‚Äôll love it, and you‚Äôll spend more money than you planned while at it.

I've been playing DBD on and off for a couple of years. This current event, the Haunted Day, or whatever it's called‚Äîis the worst. Okay, I can handle them changing the game into a chase-only experience and nerfing the stealth mechanics for survivors. I can even handle killers being the largest group of sweaty underachievers who rely on the Ghoul to point-and-click instead of using skill, like Dead-Slinger or Krause, which removes the learning curve and guesswork.

But the current event offers no incentive for killers to play. Sweaty, aggressive play has become commonplace, and the fun factor is close to nonexistent compared to what it used to be. Save your money, play Identity V instead. The only remaining draw in DBD is having a good group of friends or streaming on Twitch. Neither of which make DBD a requirement. Otherwise, if you're a first-time player, save your money and your frustrations and get anything else.

I really enjoy this game when I actually get put into playable lobbies, it can be a lot of fun, especially when in a vc with friends. That's why i am giving it a thumbs up. However, as a survivor main, it can get pretty frustrating. I get tunneled, slugged, and hook camped so often, which makes the experience feel one-sided and discouraging. I also run into hackers every now and then, which makes things worse since there doesn‚Äôt seem to be much anti-cheat improvement. I really wish there were some kind of anti-tunnel feature or better balancing between killers and survivors, because right now it definitely feels killer-sided from my experience, even though I know others might disagree. I also feel like the game has a lot of potential if the graphics were updated or improved. The atmosphere is great, but the visuals are starting to feel a bit dated compared to other modern horror games. With a graphical overhaul or more detailed environments, Dead by Daylight could look absolutely amazing and feel even more immersive. Overall, DBD has so much potential and can be an amazing time when things go smoothly, but I just hope the devs focus more on fairness, balance, and quality of matches in future updates.

Dead by Daylight: A Symphony of Screams and Salt
If you're a masochist who thrives on heart-pounding chases, endless gen repairs interrupted by hooks, and teammates who DC mid-trial, this is your twisted paradise.
As a survivor, every match is a therapy session in frustration‚Äîsweaty killers with Mori offerings await, turning you into a pallet-dropping pi√±ata.
Flip to killer? Pure sadism gold: chain saw through noobs, tunnel the last gen-rusher, and cackle at the rage quits in post-game chat.
The licensed icons (Freddy, Michael) add flavor, but the core loop is addictive chaos‚Äîcross-play keeps lobbies fresh, though toxicity is the real final boss.
Graphics? Meh, but the fog-shrouded maps ooze atmosphere. Sound design? Jump-scare perfection.

Ten years later and the devs are still keeping this nightmare alive; respect! 
I love that you can get new survivors and killers with both in-game grind and real money (depending on how patient you are). 
The challenge adjusts to your skill, so whether you‚Äôre a stealthy pro or a panicked button-masher, it‚Äôs equally terrifying. Especially since you never know if your teammates are team players, fending for themselves, or just goofballing in a corner. 
The game‚Äôs gotten darker with age, like fine wine, if that wine screamed a lot. 
My only wish? More lore-inspired killers. Let‚Äôs mix the movie monsters with creatures from folklore! 
Give me chills and mythology!

I love this game, but it's too killer sided so gameplay is very repeatative till the point that you can't try anything knew and have fun except the very strict meta.

As a killer it always feel too easy, like you always in control of a situation, and can allow people to win against you or not. And there always could happen a moment in the game when you hited several survivors in a short period of time, or downed two at once, or killed one, after which there's no challenge at all, you know people will not be able to do gens, but they also will try hide, so the game takes longer, but there's not intrigue it. And you always play with one person, as the game really punish survivors if they play together with a killer, and not sitting at the gen.

As a survivor it requires mach more skills, you mast know layout of every single map to not make a wrong turn and not appear in the dead end, and this game really doesn't forgive mistakes. Also the main part of the gameplay - doing gens, is just boring. You just seat for minutes pressing single button and that's all. Of course you can try to do something else, but it will not make you win. Another minus is most of the perks are absolutely useless. As a killer you can have perks that block gens for minute or more, but as survivor there's perks that stun killer for 3 seconds, and then it's just disabled for the rest of the match. Or perks that makes you broken permanently, or perks that don't really do mach.

I‚Äôve played dead by daylight on other platforms such as PlayStation and Nintendo however I prefer it so much more on PC . Owning it on PC also gives you access to chat before game ( with survivors )  and after game ( with survivors and killer ) You can also vote if your team mates were good at the end of game with a thumbs up and thumbs down icon. Now about the game in more detail. It‚Äôs a  multiplayer game which has 4 survivors vs 1 killer . ( There are events that are limited time throughout the year that‚Äôs 8 survivors vs 2 killers ) The main goal of the game is to repair generators, avoid getting caught,  hooked and killed by the killer while trying to escape .This game is one of those games where you get into it and you love/ hate it down the line.  The game does have a bit of bugs not going to lie . Some of the good perks are behind characters you have to buy ( not that I mind but some people might care as some people think the game paid to win ) Not to worry though as some characters you can unlock by playing the game and getting shards.  I wouldn‚Äôt say the game is beginner friendly as you can get into a game with anyone from any level. I will say if you play as Sable there a 50/50 chance you‚Äôd be tunnelled more by the killer and team mates  help you less. This is because most new players pick Sable  ( and of course when you start a game you aren‚Äôt the best and don‚Äôt know what‚Äôs going on  ) and people just have an issues with the character because of this . I still love Sable though  :) This game may be a horror game but personally to me I find it fun not to many jump scares and there a lot of silly people on here . Very enjoyable hope you try it out !

Killer main  ‚Äî and I genuinely think this is the worst state the game has ever been in.

BHVR has been promising to fix things since the release the Quality of Life Initiative yet here we are ‚Äî no real improvements, and somehow it‚Äôs getting worse. They even had the audacity to drop a repeat event again, paired with an absolutely horrendous Rift Pass. To make things worse, we‚Äôre apparently not getting a new Rift for 110 days and no new content until January. That‚Äôs nearly four months of literal neglect in a live-service game.

Tunneling is at an all-time high, and despite the PTB showing potential solutions (during The Krasue testing), none of that has been rolled out. As a killer main, I felt the only real issue was the anti-slugging measures ‚Äî everything else would‚Äôve been a step in the right direction.

And yet, the devs think they‚Äôre doing great. The game director recently called Sinister Grace (The Krasue chapter) a "success", which is mind-blowing. It could‚Äôve been a strong release ‚Äî maybe even close to All Things Wicked (Sable & The Unknown) ‚Äî but instead, we got an overtuned killer right after what felt like modern days version of the bubonic plague.. You have an experienced friend to walk you through the game.

You binge content from creators to understand the actual meta.

The barrier to entry is ridiculous.

3,382 Hours as a Claudette Main ‚Äì Still One of the Most Unique Multiplayer Experiences

After 3,382 hours in Dead by Daylight, mostly spent crouching in bushes and healing teammates as Claudette, I can confidently say this game is still one of the most intense, frustrating, and satisfying multiplayer titles out there.

What keeps me hooked after all this time is the pure adrenaline. Every match is a mind game. As a Claudette main, I‚Äôve learned to thrive in the shadows‚Äîsneaking past Killers, clutch-saving teammates, and outwitting some of the most brutal foes gaming has to offer. Whether I‚Äôm solo queuing or running a full SWF squad, DBD always delivers those unforgettable ‚Äúlast second escape‚Äù moments.

The game has grown massively since I started‚Äînew Killers, perks, reworks, and collaborations keep it fresh. Behavior‚Äôs commitment to expanding the universe, especially with unique licensed content, gives it unmatched personality. Claudette may be one of the originals, but she‚Äôs still as viable and stealthy as ever.

Yes, there are issues. Matchmaking can be inconsistent. Meta perks rise and fall. And yes, camping and tunneling still exist. But for every frustrating match, there‚Äôs one that reminds me why I‚Äôve stayed this long.

If you enjoy psychological gameplay, high-stakes stealth, and don‚Äôt mind a bit of chaos, Dead by Daylight is absolutely worth your time. Just don‚Äôt underestimate that Claudette crouching in the grass‚Äîyou might not see her, but she‚Äôs the reason you didn‚Äôt bleed out.

Dead By Daylight is one of, if not, the worst game ever. I absolutely abhor this game and I don't know why I keep coming back to it. Every trial is nearly the same scenario, over and over and over over. The micro-transactions could not be more blatant. If you are playing as a Survivor, then it's just dying simulator, unless you are sweaty as hell and blind the killer every few seconds with a flashlight, then you're cooked. This means that if you are beginner, then it's just insanity - the same thing over and over with little to no difference, you will just keep dying and it becomes so depressing and unplayable. If you are a killer, then you have to dodge sweaty survivors flashing you every few seconds, it's so bad that sometimes I can't even hook survivors because one of their buddies is always there ready with a flashlight to save the day. The Survivors in this game are often the most sweatiest players on Earth, they will wait at the exit gate for you so they can rub your loss in your face, along with other things. Combine these two together with bad maps, killer sided and survivor sided games and you have the abomination that is 'Dead By Daylight'. I often contemplate why I spent $11.50 on this stupid game that my friends rarely play but make me download, and sometimes I regret it. Don't buy this stupid waste of time, go do something better that is actually beneficial for your health and that makes you happy - because the only thing this game is going to do is waste your time, make you get sweaty, make you unhappy and stress you out. 4/10, if it wasn't so infuriating and actually fun then it would be higher.

This game is good. I am done with people with so many hours saying it's a trash game. I've played since 2016 and watched this game grow from a small 1-2 killer game to the absolute 4v1 empire that still stands. I was a huge fan of evolve when it first came out. But when it died, there was a void that needed to be filled. In came Dead By Daylight. I was surprised by how fast it was growing, especially with the jump from the release of the Nurse, to the release of Myers. Now, do people enjoy it? Depends. Do you like 4v1 gameplay? Knowing that maps are going to stay relatively the same? With the gameplay being the change depending on survivor, killer, perk, and offering varieties? Then you would maybe enjoy it. I'm not saying this game is perfect, by any means. But if I have 800 hours in the game or more, coming back during periods of time enjoying the game, then I am gonna recommend it. 

   Now there is work to be done, I won't lie. Patches for bugs and quality of life changes have been discussed by Behavior. As well as a little cramming with chapters and quality of life however, and I do hope they slow down their pace. If they keep smashing things together, there are going to be issues. But with issues or not, I still enjoy the game. Just hoping things keep getting better. That's all I can say.

I have mixed feelings on Dead By Daylight.
Overall, there is really no other game like it and thus it offers a very unique experience, with many iconic characters you get to play as all in one spot with an extremely addicting gameplay loop.
On the flipside, it can be very stressful, and has its own ups and downs when it comes to balancing between survivors and killers. With very wishy washy matchmaking at times.
I'd still recommend DBD to people(especially horror fans), but just with a fair warning that it has very high highs, and very low lows.
‚Äé

Got gifted the game a while ago but I never got into it as much until now. Super easy to get *hooked* lol. Gameplay and controls are simple, I find them easier to get used to on here rather than on console. The support team lacks but the game makes up for it. There's a lot of bugs here and there especially after updates, but they're usually funny shit like audio bugs and visual effects.

The cosmetics aren't pricy, which I can appreciate especially with how items are priced in games like Fortnite and Valorant these days. A good DLC will run you $7-$12 but you get new killers and/or survivors and unlock different perks to style different loadouts. Plus you can earn currency for free to purchase any unlicensed killers/survivors and cosmetics but it does take some time. 

Other than all of that its a super fun game to play with friends, but solo queue can be nuts because although it is definitely a game that requires some sort of communication between teams, there's no form of chatting besides before and after matches. Would be fun to have some sort of way to either ping or use voice chat during trials but knowing BHVR, I'll be married with kids by the time that's discussed between them.

For anyone considering buying or getting into the Dead by Daylight universe/fog:

As a player who started in 2019 (around Oni's release) and has nearly 3,300 hours in this game, if asked whether Dead by Daylight is worth purchasing, my answer is no. I recommend saving your money. In my view, Behaviour has damaged Dead by Daylight to the extent that selling the game might be the only way to save it. The developers' repeated apologies for their mistakes have become a laughing stock within the community. I can easily list more negatives than positives, and I will do so. This opinion is based on my personal experience, as well as opinions from other players and content creators.

Engine Source:
--------------------
Dead by Daylight uses spaghetti code in almost everything which causes several bugs to happen such as animation bugs, cosmetic bugs, gameplay bugs, ect. It gets to the point where its frustrating to even play the game when you have to encounter it. Even when they release updates, new bugs often appear, suggesting they don't thoroughly test or care about their own game.

Balancing (-->Non-Existent<--):
----------------
Maps - All maps in DBD are unbalanced due to two main factors: map generation and the killer being played as or against. As a survivor, your chances of winning or losing can depend on the killer's tier (S-Tier or F-Tier) and map generation, specifically the abundance or scarcity of pallets and tiles. Similarly, as a killer, map generation can significantly impact your effectiveness, for example like Myers or Trapper who are weak, if the map is survivor-sided with numerous pallets and windows. Ultimately, the game's maps are designed to be unbalanced, regardless of whether you play as a survivor or a killer.

Survivor Items - Some items for survivor has positive and negatives that could dictate how a match could end in a win or a loss. For example, toolboxes with the addon's scraps and wire spool that can give you 52 charges (half a gen repair) or Brand-New-Part that can turn the tides of a match. Other items like Fog Vials are a complete joke and a useless item you can bring that will have little to 0 impact on a match. Same goes with flashlights which the main use is for flashlight saves (unless killer is facing a wall) then its really a useless item. 

Killers - When looking at Dead by Daylight (DBD) killer tier lists online, opinions on who is S-Tier (strong) versus F-Tier (weak) vary widely. However, the developers often don't prioritize balancing lower-tier killers (e.g., The Hag, The Trapper, Ghost Face) to make them stronger, nor do they sometimes frequently nerf strong killers (e.g., The Nurse, The Blight), despite community requests. A well-balanced killer offers a dynamic back-and-forth in a match, with clear counter-play options for survivors. For example, The Unknown, The Demogorgon, and The Dredge are often considered balanced. They can be strong, depending on the map, but survivors have effective ways to counter them

 Killer Add-ons - Some to many Dead by Daylight add-ons are ineffective or redundant, making them not worth using. For example, The Ghost Face's "Knife Belt Clip" add-on, which reduces his terror radius while crouching, is useless as he can already completely suppress his terror radius. Similarly, The Doctor's add-ons that modify his Shock Therapy cone into a hollowed ring or small beam are widely considered poorly designed and impractical. While Behaviour has undertaken add-on reworks before, these efforts sometimes involve unnecessary nerfs rather than beneficial buffs or reworks.

Perks - The imbalance of perks in Dead by Daylight leads to a prevalent 'meta' for both Survivors and Killers. A significant issue is the overlap of perks, rendering some obsolete or less effective in builds.
For perks that overlap one another:

Survivor:
- Quick & Quiet and Cut-lose (both makes your vaults quiet but Cut-Lose has a Longer cooldown)
- Empathic Connection and Empathy (These are opposite when it comes to seeing auras)
- Do no Harm/we'll make it and Resurgance (Do No Harm/We'll Make It applies to healing over hook, while Resurgence literally gives you 70% heal when you come off)

Killer: 
- Ravenous and Hex: Haunted Grounds (Both provide exposed status for 60 seconds with different conditions) 
- Save the Best for Last and Help Wanted (Different conditions but same reward of reduced attack cooldown) 
- Call of Brine and Hex: Ruin (Both Provide 150% gen regression but Ruin can deactivate if cleansed while Call of Brine does not)

Do i need to go on?? Besides the overlapping perks, there are the "meta" perks. These Perks are what you see in almost 90% of games you play. Perks like:
- Decisive Strike
- Unbreakable
- Sprint burst
- Vigil 
- Dead Hard
- Pain Resonance
- Surge 
Everyone plays to win; there's no casual gameplay or fun in DBD, only competition. Many perks are rarely seen in matches because they're either useless, underrated, or unnecessary for the current game state. To name a few...
- Septic Touch
- Spies from the Shadows
- Territorial Imperative  
- Beast of Prey 
- Insidious
BHVR's perk reworks often lead to them becoming either meta or trash, rarely inbetween. Take Springtrap's perk, Haywire, for example. It went from regressing the gates to 50% minimal in the PTB to regress the gates to 80% minimal in the live build. This change, affecting exit gates, was unnecessary. A better approach, in my opinion, would have been to make it a hex perk, "Hex: Haywire," keeping the 50% minimal regression but requiring survivors to cleanse a totem to deactivate the gates regressing.

I don't believe i have to explain more on how poorly design the perk system for dbd is, especially on how perks can lead to the meta or the trashcan based on design and impact it has on the match.

Community:
--------------------------------------------
Dead by Daylight is characterized by a toxic back-and-forth between survivors and killers, like disagreements turn violence. Survivors often engage in behaviors like flashlight clicking, 'teabagging,' and sending insulting post-game chat messages or hateful Steam wall comments. Killers reciprocate with actions such as mass slugging, 'W&S' ("Get F*ed" on downed survivors), unnecessary tunneling, and hitting survivors on the hook, alongside hateful post-game messages. The developer's don't really monitor post-game chat for such toxic behavior most of the time. This is only one side of DBD. The other side of DBD can include cringeworthy profiles of OC's shipping with DBD characters, Tournament DBD players (which can sometimes lead to killers dodging lobbies), and P100 characters in bio's (which doesn't necessarily mean you're good at the game), among other things I won't discuss here.

Ik there is more to be said for example with matchmaking, cheaters, Quality of life ‚Äúimprovements‚Äù, No casual Gameplay, Ultimately, Dead by Daylight is a game that is built on toxicity and unbalanced mechanics that will cause you to lose your sanity and not want to play the game anymore.

Dead by Daylight is a masterclass in asymmetrical horror multiplayer, blending slasher-movie tension with deep strategic gameplay.
If you're craving a game that captures the adrenaline of a horror film and the thrill of competitive cat-and-mouse, Dead by Daylight delivers in spades. This five-player online experience pits one ruthless killer against four survivors trying to escape a nightmarish arena. The result? A pulse-pounding, unpredictable showdown every match.

If you enjoy horror, strategy, and high-stakes multiplayer, Dead by Daylight is a must-play. It‚Äôs not just a game‚Äîit‚Äôs a living, breathing slasher film where you write the ending.

Dead by Daylight is one of the most unique and thrilling multiplayer horror games out there. Whether you're playing as a survivor or the killer, every match feels different and intense. The game perfectly captures the tension of a horror movie, and the heart-pounding chases never get old.

What I love most is the variety ‚Äì so many killers with different powers and a wide range of survivors, each with their own perks. The game also has awesome crossovers with iconic horror franchises like Resident Evil, Silent Hill, Stranger Things, and more. It keeps things fresh and exciting.

The devs keep updating the game with new content, events, and quality of life improvements, which shows they really care about the community. Sure, there are some bugs here and there, but overall the game is incredibly fun and addicting.

If you enjoy horror, teamwork, or competitive games with high replayability, I totally recommend Dead by Daylight. Just be ready for some sweaty matches!

People may call you a Camper, Tunneler, Gen-rusher, or Toxic player but most of this comes from frustration. Here‚Äôs what‚Äôs really happening in these situations and how both Survivors and Killers can reduce that frustration.

SURVIVORS
We‚Äôve all said it: ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre camping,‚Äù ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre tunneling,‚Äù ‚ÄúOP perks,‚Äù ‚ÄúYou suck.‚Äù These come from feeling powerless or targeted. But instead of blaming, it‚Äôs worth understanding why these things happen and how to counter them.

CAMPING

A killer sitting on a hook for the full 2 minutes feels awful. But camping is actually a huge mistake for the killer.

‚Ä¢ A survivor takes 120 seconds to die on hook.
‚Ä¢ One survivor doing a gen takes ~80 seconds (~100 with Ruin).
‚Ä¢ So if the killer camps, do gens instead of going for risky saves.

If a killer fully camps a first hook, you can finish about 3 gens. If they camp again, that‚Äôs 2 more. A camping killer realistically caps out at about 2 kills max and earns very few points. When you punish camping with gen pressure instead of feeding more hooks, killers eventually learn it doesn‚Äôt work.

TUNNELING

Getting tunneled is miserable, but it's often set up by survivor mistakes that the killer simply capitalizes on.

Killers prioritize:

‚Ä¢ The closest targets
‚Ä¢ Injured survivors
‚Ä¢ Survivors who are already hooked (best value for slowdown and pressure)

If the killer is near the hook when the unhook happens, they will naturally return‚Äîthere are guaranteed survivors there, one of them injured.

To reduce tunneling:

‚Ä¢Don‚Äôt unhook in the killer‚Äôs terror radius unless it‚Äôs absolutely necessary.
‚Ä¢If the killer never leaves the hook, it's camping/proxy camping‚Äîso leave and do gens.
‚Ä¢Communicate with teammates: unsafe unhooks cause tunneling.
‚Ä¢Learn to punish killers through pressure, not insults.

I would recommend this game, but only in moderation and only when it's on a good sale. DBD can be super fun, but it can just as equally turn into a rage-baiting toxicity battlefield.    Getting into the game can feel addictive and it's a lot of fun, but the more you play the more you realize  what's wrong with the game. The biggest thing being for me personally: with all the bugs, the unbalanced game mechanics/ perks/ characters, and the number of hackers i've run into, this feels like it should be a FREE GAME. Dead by Daylight is in an extremely sad state right now, I gathered up the courage to start playing this year after watching multiple YT videos on it since its release. After 200 hours this game gives me headaches especially if you're playing to have a casually match or just enjoy yourself. There's toxic players on both sides. Sweaty Killers just there to ruin the match by camping, tunneling, slugging or a combination of the 3. Survivor working with the killer or purposely throwing the match. As a survivor main i feel like changes need to be made on both sides. There shouldn't be any survivor/killer sided maps. Maps need to balance so whether you're killer or survivor you have a fair chance at achieving your goal. More pallets will not resolve the issue this just allows the game to become more survivor sided, make resources scarce but also place them smartly so its not a 10 second chase nor a 5 minute chase. The DC recognition system should be better to detect loss of connection vs someone actually pressing a button to quit the game. I shouldn't receive a matchmaking ban due to easy anti cheat detecting whatever it detects. I promise you i don't need to cheat to actually win. Perks need to be reworked on both sides, most of the survivor perks are useless and some killer perks are so OP that you never stood a chance in winning the matches. Item add-ons should be more simpler and compacted into 3 or 5 add-ons per item at least for survivors. Ranked matches should be a thing, I shouldn't have matches with survivors who just opened the game for the 1st time nor should I have a killer with thousands of hours compared to my 218 hours. The game needs a better tutorial explains the game in a more detailed way. Hit boxes and collision needs serious rework i shouldn't get stuck on barriers thats doesn't exist in the middle of chase as well as be hit by an hatchet after being clear of a window vault. This is all i could think about now i'll probably add more over time. I suggest devs shut down the server for a couple months to fix long standing issues and bugs but, hey thats just my opinion.

Going to finally make a review for this game. Been playing for years on console before later coming on PC. Right off the bat, I'm going to say this; The game, right now, currently, is dogshit. Absolutely terrible. The developers have absolutely ZERO clue on what they're doing. If you're new and looking to try it, I recommend NOT to at all. Don't even give them a single dime. Why? Because they're ruining the game slowly. "Ruining" is an understatement. The killer role in this game just isn't the power role at all, when it's supposed to be. If you're thinking you're gonna load into a match and stomp survivors as your favorite horror license, think again. The devs give the survivor side WAY too much power and it's pathetic. All because survivors whine everytime they have to go against something strong in a PVP game. It's bullshit. Survivors get: Base kit perks, second chances galore, 100+ pallets all in close proximity to each other, making it almost impossible to get downs if you're not blight or nurse (the strongest killers in the game, but even they feel bad to play because it's just boring.)  Survivors always get what they ask for, always complaining, always whining how every nerf to a killer isn't enough, because how else are they gonna bully the killer for their twitch content? What a joke this game is becoming. They've butchered the killer role: Constantly nerfing killers to near or unplayable for some killers (Most, actually) Gen kick limits exist too now. Don't play the game as killer, you'll hurt the survivors feelings. They added a anti-facecamp feature too. Even though if you do facecamp, you have a much higher precentage of losing anyway, but nerf it I guess, get rid of it. "Its boring!" They also leave the weaker killers down in the dirt, in the deepest caves and don't do anything about them. Instead of making all killers viable and fun to actually play, they focus on making bright rainbow unicorn skins, nerfing more bs survivors whine about, and say they're doing a "pretty good job so far."  Anytime a new killer releases that's a little bit strong, they're gone in a week. They're made weak so survivors can have their easy wins. A brute, monstrous killer like nemesis for example; what stops him? Oh, a piece of wood. Meanwhile the survivor on the other end is just t-bagging you and there's not a damn thing you can do about it.


The survivor role however is just as boring but less. It's WAY easier than killer. Don't even let anyone convince you otherwise. All survivor gameplay is: Hold M1 on gen till done, repeat 5 times, get chased, throw pallet, vault window. But chases are pretty fun, and that's the only good part about the survivor role. They need to give survivors new objectives I feel. Maybe a way to find generator parts or something. More interactive stuff. Because right now, the only things survivors get are: Gens and totems. The other garbage part about survivor is hoping you get good teammates if you're playing alone. Because there have been SO many times where I've died because of a idiotic teammate doing god knows what or why. 


And the #1 thing that makes this game horrid to play is the community. This community is on a whole other level of horrible. They're toxic, horrible human beings some of them (Not all of them of course), but a big amount. You'll get death threats for simply playing the killer. Because you killed them in a way that doesn't meet their standards. Because you played a certain way. Because you did this, you did that, etc, etc, etc. Same goes if you play survivor, too. You do one wrong thing as survivor and you'll get flamed to all hell for it. This game is NOT beginner friendly at all. 


Last thing I wanna warn you about is: The new user experience. It's really bad as well. The tutorial does NOT teach you nearly enough information. It doesn't tell you about different killers powers. It doesn't even teach you looping (Though you can play against a killer bot in the tutorial, but it doesn't teach you looping at all. You're just kinda thrown in there) And it barely teaches anything for killer as well. It only teaches you how to hit and hook survivor. That's basically it. Doesn't teach you intermediate or advanced stuff, doesn't tech you a few other killers powers so the player can decide who they want to learn, it's just not great. But the worse part about starting new? The grind. It's currently horrbile as well. There is so many perks locked behind a paywall, and everyone's excuse is "Oh, just way for the shrine of secrets"  If you don't know what it is, it's a set of 4 perks that changes weekly. You can buy any of the perks that appear on there for shards. The problem is, is that you need to wait an entire week in hopes of the perk you want to appear. Otherwise, you gotta pay. They need to have some sort of store with ALL of the perks available to purchase instead of a weekly refresh. Another big issue is shards. You barely earn them as is, and cosmetics, the ones that aren't for just money, costs 7200 a piece. No, not for the whole outfit, the one piece. For example, let's say you want a outfit for dwight. You'd have to grind so much shards which takes way WAY too long, They are absolutely allergic to giving more shards for some reason. You SHOULD be able to earn them every match and in way high quanitity so the grind isn't that long and dreadful. 


Overall, the game in it's current state, besides very little good things, is HORRIBLE. It's miserable, unfun, and not worth buying in it's current state. Do I have hope for it in the future? Yes and no. I do believe that they could improve it but... yeah, that's not happening anytime soon with how things are going. So it's best to hold off on buying it, or buy it when it's on sale.

I honestly can‚Äôt believe how bad the monetization is for a paid game. You spend around $20 but half the content, especially the killers, is locked behind DLCs and paywalls. This would already be annoying in a free-to-play title, but in a game you pay for, it‚Äôs ridiculous.

Each killer plays differently and has unique perks, many of which are meta. Yes, you can technically unlock things with irridescent shards, but the system is painfully slow. The store only rotates four teachable perks per week, so it can literally take months or even years before the perk you need shows up. And keep in mind that this is a PvP game where most player sweat and tryhard constantly, whether the devs want to acknowledge it or not.

For comparison imagine watching Arcane, getting hyped, and deciding to try League of Legends. You buy it for $20 (because, somehow, it‚Äôs not free anymore), only to find out Jinx, your favorite character, is locked behind the ‚ÄúArcane DLC.‚Äù Fine, you open your wallet again and start playing her. Then you look up some builds and discover the best rune for Jinx is Lethal Tempo but you can‚Äôt use it, because it‚Äôs locked behind another DLC champion. So now you‚Äôre stuck running a weak setup as a new player.

It would be acceptable in coop games/gamemodes like in Payday 2 or Starcraft 2, where the infinite amount of DLCs does not harm players who don't own them. But for PvP games, especially competitive ones, it is totally unfair.


If you‚Äôre considering buying Dead by Daylight without the will to invest money or a significant amount of time, just know that the game will feel very limited and you'll feel like you are being punished even more for being a new player.

I would recommend this to any horror lovers, and party game enjoyers, and anyone who likes a good challenge.

this game is one of a kind and a very toxic relationship i cant stop playing. The gameplay is somehow repetitive and not even though most of survivor gameplay escape wise is holding a button(you can toggle) and hiting quick time events. The game is a balancing nightmare Some killers suck some are broken some maps are good some are butt Some perks are amazing and some are useless. Killers are either so OP you can afford to use any perks for fun or ur forced to use a meta(VERY STALE GAMEPLAY) which encourages the otherside to only run a counter meta or simply die Its very annoying and the community for the most part is toxic af. The game is Very competitive and no longer a party game id argue. The amount of content is overwhelming for new players and even seasoned veterans if you dont read patch notes like ur studying for college. If ur a completionist type who collects EVERYTHING id Run from this game theres a rotating weekly store that offers previous battlepass cosmetics and such but its obviously overpriced and ur not in control of what it offers. The last couple killers released come out absolutely Broken then get nerfed so expect Stale gameplay for like 2 weeks each release of a killer. I hope you enjoy and dont hate it but its BOUND to happen

For context on the low hours, I am a console player who recently just transferred over to PC. I want to in all my heart recommend this game to others, but one singular thing is holding me back on doing so: The developers. These developers are without a doubt the worst I've seen in any multiplayer game ever. They somehow make every wrong decision both in and outside the game. They make every other game developer look like Jesus Christ himself compared to how stupid the DBD devs are. They have not made a single right decision in the last year and the game is now suffering for it. The game barely functions half the time because they refuse to fix bugs and just keep releasing content that brings more bugs. Don't even get me started on the balance team, the actual most incompetent people ever to touch this earth. The only good thing the devs have done recently is finally acknowledge the games issues and are finally going to try and fix them. It only took the community of the game bullying them into doing so. Unless there is ever significant changes inside the studio, I would save your time and not even entertain the devs and what they're trying to pull with this game as of recent. I'll only ever flip my review if I see genuine long term change in the developers.
